editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

The 4th, From all the≈øe laid together, He dwelt among us full of Grace and Truth, p. 250, to 256. The Glory of the Word which the Apo≈øtles beheld con≈øi≈øted in 4 Things. 1. A vi≈øible ≈øplendor and brightne≈øs which encompa≈øs'd him at his Bapti≈øm and Transfiguration, p. 258, 259. 2. Tho≈øe great and ≈øtupendous Miracles which he wrought, p. 260, 261, 262. 3. The ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing Excellency and Divinity of his Doctrine, p. 263, 264. 4. The incomparable Sanctity and Purity of his Life, p. 265, 266, 267. div.head: OF THE Chri≈øtian Life. PART. IV.

q.p: What is a Man profited if he ≈øhall gain the whole World and lo≈øe his own Soul? Or what ≈øhall a Man give in Exchange for his Soul?

div.p:
IN the 24th. Ver≈øe our Saviour urges his Di≈øciples to that nece≈ø≈øary Duty of denying them≈øelves, that is, of ≈øurrendering up their Wills to the conduct of his, and renouncing all their Worldly Intere≈øt when it comes in Competition with their Duty, and of taking up their Cro≈øs, and following him; that is, of preparing them≈øelves to endure Per≈øecution for his ≈øake, and to per≈øi≈øt couragiou≈øly in the Profe≈ø≈øion and Practice of his Religion what≈øoever Oppo≈øitions they ≈øhould meet with from the World. And to pre≈øs them hereunto, he urges this Argument, Ver. 25. For who≈øoever will ≈øave his Life ≈øhall lo≈øe it: and who≈øoever will lo≈øe his Life, ≈øhall find it. Where the Greek Word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ which we render Life, may perhaps be better render'd Him≈øelf, it being

familiar both with Hebrews and Syrians to call a man's Life and Soul Him≈øelf: ≈øo the P≈øalmi≈øt, thou ≈øhalt not leave my Soul in Hell, that is, thou ≈øhalt not leave me Peri≈øhing in my Grave, P≈øal. 16.10. And Levit. 20.25. Ye ≈øhall not make your Souls abominable, i. e. your ≈øelves; And that it ≈øhould be ≈øo render'd here is evident, becau≈øe St. Luke ≈øo expounds it, What is a Man profited, if he gain the whole World and lo≈øe him≈øelf, or be ca≈øt away? Luke 9.25, And indeed the Soul being the Principal Part of a Man, and that which advances him into a Species of Being above that of a meer Animal, may very well be called him≈øelf, according to that of Hierecles,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Thy Soul is Thee, thy Body, thine, and thy outward Goods thy Bodies. And if in≈øtead of Life we render „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Him≈øelf, the Words will be very plain and ea≈øy; for who≈øoever will ≈øave him≈øelf by renouncing me and my Religion, ≈øhall lo≈øe him≈øelf for ever; and who≈øoever will be content to lo≈øe him≈øelf for my ≈øake, ≈øhall ≈øave him≈øelf for ever. And this he farther inforces in the Text, What is a Man profited, if he ≈øhall gain the whole World, and lo≈øe his own Soul? or what ≈øhall a Man give in exchange for his Soul? that is, what will it avail a Man to gain the whole World, if he for ever ruin him≈øelf by it? and when he hath thus ruined him≈øelf, what would he give, if it were in his Power, to ≈øave and recover him≈øelf again? The Words thus explained, I ≈øhall re≈øolve the ≈øen≈øe of them into the≈øe five Propo≈øitions.

I. That a Man; or the Soul of a Man is a Thing of ine≈øtimable Price and Value; for our Saviour
here weighs it again≈øt the whole World, that is, again≈øt all the Plea≈øures, Profits, and Honours that this inferiour World can afford; and declares that in the ju≈øt Ballance of his E≈øteem it out-weighs them all. And certainly that mu≈øt needs be exceeding precious, who≈øe Worth the whole World cannot counter-poi≈øe.
II. That this precious Soul may be lo≈øt. This our Saviour plainly ≈øuppo≈øes in the≈øe Words, if he lo≈øe his own Soul.

III. That our renouncing of Chri≈øt and his Religion will mo≈øt certainly infer this Lo≈øs. For the≈øe Words, as I have ≈øhewed you, our Saviour urges as an Argument to di≈ø≈øuade Men from Apo≈øtacy; but if without lo≈øing our Souls, we might renounce him and apo≈øtatize from him, there would be no Force in all this Argument to di≈ø≈øuade us from it.

IV. That when this Soul is lo≈øt, 'tis lo≈øt irrecoverably. What ≈øhall a Man give in exchange for his Soul? where the Greek Word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which we render Exchange, is u≈øed in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe with „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which ≈øignifies a price of Redemption, denoting that if a Man ≈øhould or could give never ≈øo much to buy his Soul from Perdition, yet no Price of Redemption will be taken for it.

V. That this irrecoverable Lo≈øs of a Soul is of ≈øuch a va≈øt Moment, that the Gain of the whole World is not ≈øufficient to compen≈øate it. What is a Man profited, that is, he is not at all profited, nay he is ≈øo far from that that he is a va≈øt Lo≈øer.

I. That the Soul of a Man is a Thing of an ine≈øtimable Price and Value. And for the Proof of
this Propo≈øition, I ≈øhall endeavour the≈øe two Things.
First, To repre≈øent to you of what va≈øt Worth it is in Re≈øpect of its own natural Capacities.
Secondly, To ≈øhew you of what vast E≈øteem it is in the Judgment of all tho≈øe who, as we mu≈øt needs ≈øuppo≈øe, do be≈øt under≈øtand the Worth of it.

1. I ≈øhall endeavour to repre≈øent to you of what vast Worth it is in Re≈øpect of its own natural Capacities, particularly in the≈øe four. (1.) In Re≈øpect of its Capacity of ∆≤nder≈øtanding. (2.) Of Moral Perfection. (3.) Of Plea≈øure and Delight. (4.) Of Immortality.

1. The Soul of Man is of va≈øt Worth in Re≈øpect of its Capacity of ∆≤nder≈øtanding. For certainly to under≈øtand, is the greate≈øt and noblest Operation that a Being is capable of; for it is this that gives Beauty and Excellence to all our other Operations whether they be natural or moral: 'Tis this that propo≈øes the Ends, and directs the Cour≈øe, and Pre≈øcribes the Mea≈øures of all our other Actions; and tho we had never ≈øo much Force or Power, yet unle≈øs we had ∆≤nder≈øtanding to guide and manage it, it would be altogether in≈øignificant. For Blind Power acts at Random, and if we had the Force of a Whirl-wind, yet without a Mind to ≈øtear and manage it, it would be an equal Chance whether we did well or ill with it. So that unle≈øs there were ≈øome ∆≤nder≈øtanding either within or without us to conduct our active Powers, and determine them to our Good, we were as good be altogether without them; becau≈øe while they act by Chance it is at lea≈øt an equal Lay whether they will injure or advantage
us. Since therefore ∆≤nder≈øtanding is the Rule and Mea≈øure of all our other Powers, it nece≈ø≈øarily follows that it ≈øelf is the greatest and noble≈øt of them all. What an excellent Being therefore mu≈øt a Soul be, in which this great and Sovereign Power re≈øides? a Power, that can collect into it ≈øelf ≈øuch prodigious Numbers of ≈øimple Apprehen≈øions, and by comparing one with the other, can connect them into true Propo≈øitions, and upon each of the≈øe can run ≈øuch long and curious De≈øcants of Di≈øcour≈øe, till it hath drawn out all their Con≈øequents into a Chain of wi≈øe and coherent Notions, and ≈øorted the≈øe into ≈øuch various Sy≈øtems of u≈øeful Arts and Sciences; That can di≈øcern the Harmonious Contextures of Truths with Truths, the ≈øecret Links and Junctures of coherent Notions, trace up Effects to their Cau≈øes, and ≈øift the remote≈øt Con≈øequents to their natural Principles; That can ca≈øt abroad its ≈øharp-≈øighted Thoughts over the whole Extent of Beings, and, like the Sun with its out-≈øtretched Rays, reach the remotest Objects; That can in the Twinkling of an Eye expatiate through all the ∆≤niver≈øe, and keep Corre≈øpondence with both Worlds; can prick out the Paths of the Heavenly Bodies, and mea≈øure the Circles of their Motion, ≈øpan the whole Surface of the Earth, and dive into its Capacious Womb, and there di≈øcover the numerous Offsprings with which it is continually teeming; That can ≈øail into the World of Spirits by the never-varying Compa≈øs of its Rea≈øon, and di≈øcover tho≈øe invi≈øible Regions of Happine≈øs and Mi≈øery, which are altogether out of our ≈øight while≈øt we ≈øtand upon this hither Shore; In a word, That can a≈øcend from Cau≈øe to Cau≈øe, to God who is the
Cau≈øe of all, and with its Eagle-Eyes can gaze upon that glorious Sun, and dive into the infinite Aby≈øs of his divine Perfections. What an excellent Being therefore is that Soul that is endowed with ≈øuch a vast Capacity of ∆≤nder≈øtanding, and with its piercing Eye can reach ≈øuch an immen≈øe Compa≈øs of Beings, and travail through ≈øo va≈øt an Horizon of Truth? Doubtle≈øs if humane Souls had no other Capacity to value them≈øelves by, but only this, this were enough to give them Preheminence over all inferiour Beings, and render them the mo≈øt glorious Part of all this ≈øublunary World.

2. The Soul of Man is of vast Worth in Re≈øpect of its Capacity of Moral Perfection. For by the Exerci≈øe of tho≈øe human Virtues which are proper to it in this ≈øtate of Conjunction with the Body, it is capable of rai≈øing it ≈øelf to the Perfection of tho≈øe Angelical Natures, which of all Creatures do mo≈øt nearly approach and re≈øemble the great Creator, and Fountain of all Perfection. For by keeping a due Re≈øtraint upon its bodily Appetites, and thereby gradually weaning it ≈øelf from the Plea≈øures of the Body, it may by degrees be educated and trained up to lead the Life, and reli≈øh the Joys of naked and immortal Spirits; it may be contempered to an incorporeal State ≈øo as to be able to enjoy it ≈øelf without eating and drinking, and live mo≈øt happily upon the Fare of Angels, upon Wi≈ødom and Holine≈øs, and Love and Contemplation. And then by governing its own Will and Affections by the Laws of Rea≈øon and Religion, it may by degrees improve it ≈øelf ≈øo far in all the≈øe Moral Endowments, which are the proper Graces of every rea≈øonable Nature, as to be at la≈øt as perfectly
wi≈øe and rea≈øonable in its own Choices and Refu≈øals, in its Love and Hatred, in its De≈øires and Delights, as the Angels them≈øelves are. For though it cannot be expected that in this imperfect ≈øtate a Soul ≈øhould arrive to ≈øuch a Pitch as this, yet even now it may be growing up and a≈øpiring to it; which, if it doth, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew you by and by, when this is expired, it hath another Life to live, which being antecedently prepared for by tho≈øe ≈øpiritual Improvements it hath made here, will furni≈øh it with Opportunities of improving infinitely fa≈øter than here it did, or po≈ø≈øibly could. For in that Life it ≈øhall not only be freed from tho≈øe many Incumbrances which do here retard it in its ≈øpiritual Progre≈øs, nor ≈øhall it only be a≈ø≈øociated with a World of pure and ble≈ø≈øed Spirits, who≈øe holy Example and wi≈øe Conver≈øe will doubtle≈øs wonderfully edifie and improve it; but be al≈øo admitted into a more intimate Acquaintance with God, who is the Author and Pattern of all Perfection; the ≈øight of who≈øe ravi≈øhing Beauty will inflame it with a mo≈øt ardent Love to him, and excite it to a mo≈øt vigorous Imitation of him: All which con≈øidered, it is not to be imagined how much the ≈øtate of Heaven will immediately improve tho≈øe happy Souls that are prepared and di≈øpo≈øed for it. But then con≈øidering that Moral Perfection is as infinite as the Nature of God, in which there is an Infinity of Holine≈øs and Ju≈øtice and Goodne≈øs within this boundle≈øs Subject, there will be Room enough for Souls to make farther and farther Improvements in, even to Eternity. And then when they ≈øhall ≈øtill be growing on ≈øo fa≈øt, and yet be ≈øtill forever improving, to what a tran≈øcendent Height of Glory and Perfection will
they at la≈øt arrive? For tho no finite Soul can ever arrive to an infinite Perfection, yet ≈øtill it may be growing on to it, becau≈øe there will ≈øtill be po≈ø≈øible Degrees of it beyond its pre≈øent Attainments; and when it is arrived to the farthe≈øt imaginable Degree, yet ≈øtill it will be capable of farther, and ≈øo farther and farther to all Eternity. And if ≈øo, O ble≈ø≈øed God, of what a Capacious Nature ha≈øt thou made the≈øe Souls of ours, which tho they will doubtle≈øs improve in Goodne≈øs as fa≈øt in the other Life as is po≈ø≈øible for them, with all the Advantages of a Heavenly State, yet will never attain to an utmo≈øt Period, but ≈øtill be growing perfecter and perfecter for ever?

3. The Soul of Man is of vast Worth in Re≈øpect of its immen≈øe Capacities of Plea≈øure and Delight: For its Capacity of Plea≈øure mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be as large and exten≈øive, as its Capacity of ∆≤nder≈øtanding, and of Moral Perfection; becau≈øe the proper Plea≈øure of a Soul re≈øults from its own Knowledge and Goodne≈øs, from its farther Di≈øcoveries of Truth, and farther Proficiency in inward Rectitude and Virtue, and con≈øequently as it Improves farther and farther in ∆≤nder≈øtanding and in Moral Perfection, it mu≈øt ≈øtill gather more and more Fuel to feed and encrea≈øe its own Joy and Plea≈øure. For the Plea≈øure of every Being con≈øi≈øts in the vigorous Exerci≈øe of its Faculties about convenient and agreeable Objects; but the Faculties of a Soul are ∆≤nder≈øtanding and Will, to which the only agreeable Objects are Truth and Goodne≈øs; and therefore the more Truth there is in the Mind, and the more Goodne≈øs there is in the Will, the more vigorou≈øly will they imploy and exerci≈øe them≈øelves about them,
and con≈øequently the more they will be plea≈øed and ravi≈øhed. Since therefore, every new Di≈øcovery of Truth, and every new Degree of Goodne≈øs gives new Life to our Minds and Wills, and renders both more ≈øprightly and vigorous, it hence nece≈ø≈øarily follows that our Souls are capable of as much Plea≈øure as they are of Truth and Goodne≈øs; and how va≈øtly Capable they are of both the≈øe I have already ≈øhewed you. So that it is not to be imagined by us, who have here ≈øo little Experience, what Heavens of Joy a Soul is capable of; only at pre≈øent we find by Experience that the more we improve in Knowledge and Goodne≈øs, the more plea≈øant and chearful we find and feel our ≈øelves, and that our Faculties ≈øtill grow more active and light≈øom the more we disburden them of that Ignorance and Sin that cloggs and incumbers them. And upon great Proficiencies in Knowledge and Virtue we find a ≈øtrange Alacrity within our ≈øelves; we are as it were in Heaven upon Earth, and do feel a Paradi≈øe ≈øpringing up within us, the Fragrance of who≈øe Joys grows many times ≈øo ≈øtrong that our frail Mortality can hardly bear them. When therefore ≈øuch Souls do ca≈øt off this Mortality which now doth only fetter and intangle them, and have made their Entrance into the invi≈øible Regions of Ble≈ø≈øedne≈øs, how ≈øprightly and active, how light≈øom and chearful will they feel them≈øelves? For in the first Moment of their Admi≈ø≈øion, all that Mi≈øt of erroncous Prejudice which now interrupts their Pro≈øpect of Truth, and all tho≈øe Remains of irregular Affection that check and di≈øtract them in their Choice of Goodne≈øs, will be forever cha≈øed from their Minds and Wills by the clear Light of the Heavenly State; and

their Faculties having disburthen'd them≈øelves, and ≈øhaken off every Clog, with what un≈øpeakable Vigour will they move and act, e≈øpecially in the Pre≈øence of ≈øuch ≈øuitable Objects as the Heavenly State will pre≈øent before them? When infinite Truth, and infinite Goodne≈øs ≈øhall be always pre≈øent to their free Minds and undi≈øtracted Wills, and nothing ≈øhall interpo≈øe to hinder them either in ≈øeeing the one, or in chu≈øing the other, here will be work enough for both to all Eternity; and both being freed from all Incumbrance, the one will be di≈øcovering every Moment farther and farther into that infinite Truth which it loves and admires, and the other will be improving every Moment more and more in that infinite Goodne≈øs which it choo≈øes and adores. And then every new Di≈øcovery and new Improvement will ≈øpring new Heavens of Joy in the Soul, and by rea≈øon of tho≈øe new Acque≈øts of Truth and Goodne≈øs, which we ≈øhall every Moment make, we ≈øhall every Moment be entertained with new Plea≈øures, and ≈øo before we have ≈øpent one Joy, another will ≈øucceed, and another that, and ≈øo on forever. For when a God of infinite Truth and Goodne≈øs becomes the Objective Happine≈øs of a finite Nature which cannot comprehend and enjoy him, but in an infinite Succe≈ø≈øion, every new Delight the Injoyment of him creates in us mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily rai≈øe a new De≈øire, and every new De≈øire immediately find a new Delight, and ≈øo round again to all Eternity. Of what a va≈øt Capacity therefore is this Soul of ours, in which there is room enough ≈øucce≈ø≈øively to entertain all the ravi≈øhing Joys and Plea≈øures that make an Everla≈øting Heaven; That can drink in tho≈øe deep Rivers of
Plea≈øure as fa≈øt as they ≈øpring up and flow from God's right hand for evermore? What Tongue can expre≈øs the innumerable Joys that ≈øuch a Soul can hold, who≈øe Capacity is ≈øo large as Heaven, and ≈øo near to infinite as to be able to contain all tho≈øe Joys and Plea≈øures that infinite Truth and Goodne≈øs can create?

4. And la≈øtly, The Soul of Man is of va≈øt Worth in Re≈øpect of its Capacity of Immortality. For by its Operations it is evident that the Soul is not compo≈øed of Corruptible matter, but is a ≈øpiritual and immaterial Sub≈øtance; for if it were Matter, it would act and move only when other Matter pre≈ø≈øes upon it, and not be able to determine the Cour≈øe of its own Motion, but would be forced to move backwards or forwards according as it was thru≈øt on by that outward Matter that continually moves and pre≈ø≈øes upon it, and all its Motions would be as nece≈ø≈øary as that of a Stone in the Air, when it is thru≈øt up by an impre≈ø≈øed Force, and pre≈ø≈øed down again by the weight of the Air above it: Whereas in this Soul of ours we ≈øen≈øibly feel and experience a natural Liberty of acting, a Power to move it ≈øelf and to determine its own Motions which way it plea≈øeth; when it is pre≈ø≈øed forward never ≈øo vigorou≈øly by the ≈øtrong Impul≈øes of outward Objects, it is in its Power to go on or retreat, and to divert the Current of its Thoughts into a quite contrary Channel to that whereinto it is thru≈øt and directed by all the Impre≈ø≈øions of its Sen≈øe. For thus in the mid≈øt of the Alarums and Shoutings of an Army, of the Noi≈øes of Drums and Trumpets ringing in our Ears, our Soul can recollect it ≈øelf, and reduce its ≈øcattered Thoughts into profound Contemplations
of a ≈øweet and Ble≈ø≈øed Peace; and when it is pre≈ø≈øed from without with never ≈øo much Importunity to this or that particular Choice, it is in its Power to reject the Motion, and to choo≈øe the quite contrary. By all which it is apparent that the Soul hath an innate Liberty of acting, that ≈øhe is not nece≈ø≈øitated from without by the different Concour≈øes and Motions of the ≈øeveral Particles of Matter; but that all the Diver≈øity of her Wills and Opinions is principally owing to her own Freedom and Power of ≈øelf-determination, and to make the lea≈øt doubt of it is to que≈øtion the common Sen≈øe and Experience of Mankind. Since therefore the Soul is not determined in its Motions by the different Pre≈ø≈øures of material things as all other Matter is, but hath power to ≈øwim again≈øt the Torrent, and move quite counter to all foreign Impre≈ø≈øions, it hence nece≈ø≈øarily follows that it is immaterial. And indeed con≈øidering how much its Operations do exceed the utmo≈øt Power of dull and pa≈ø≈øive Matter, I cannot but wonder that any Man ≈øhould be ≈øo for≈øaken of his Rea≈øon, as to rank it among material Things; for how is it po≈ø≈øible that a Piece of dull unactive Matter, that a little Gra≈øs or Dirt, or Mire, after all the Refinings, Macerations, and Maturations, that can be performed by the help of Motion ≈øhould ever be able to make a thinking Being, or grow up into the Soul of a Philo≈øopher? That a Company of dead Atoms, which cannot move unle≈øs they are moved, can ever be capable of framing Syllogi≈øms in Mood and Figure, and di≈øputing pro and con whether they are Atoms or no? That ≈øuch inert and ≈øluggi≈øh Bodies ≈øhould by their impetuous jo≈øtling together awaken one another out of their
≈øen≈øle≈øs Pa≈ø≈øivene≈øs, and make each other hear and feel their mutual Knockings and Jo≈øtlings, and then from this ≈øen≈øe into which they have thus awakened one another, and (which they are as incapable of as a Mu≈øical In≈øtrument is of hearing its own Sounds, or taking plea≈øure in the harmonious Aires that are played upon it) ≈øhould proceed and con≈øult together to make wi≈øe Laws, and contrive the be≈øt Models of Government; to inve≈øtigate the Natures of Things, and deduce from them the ≈øeveral Sy≈øtems of Arts and Sciences; in a word, how is it po≈ø≈øible that a Company of fluid Motes and Particles of Matter ≈øhould ever be ≈øo artificially complicated and twi≈øted one with another, as to form an ∆≤nder≈øtanding that can lift up its Eyes, and look beyond all this ≈øen≈øible World into that of immaterial Beings, and conceive ab≈øtracted Notions of things which can never be Objects to any material Sen≈øes; ≈øuch as a pure Point, Equality and Proportion; Symmetry, and A≈øymmetry of Magnitudes, the Ri≈øe and Propagation of Dimen≈øions, infinite Divi≈øibilty, and the like Notions that never were in Matter, nor con≈øequently could ever be extracted out of it: That can correct the Errors of all our material Perceptions, and demon≈øtrate Things to be va≈øtly different from what they apprehend and report them; can prove the Sun, for in≈øtance, to be one hundred and ≈øixty times bigger than the Earth, when to our Eye and Imagination it appears no bigger than a Bu≈øhel; that can lodge within it ≈øelf all that Ma≈øs of ≈øen≈øible Things which taketh up ≈øo much Room without it, and when it hath piled them up upon one another in va≈øt and mo≈øt prodigious Numbers is ≈øtill as capacious of more, as when it was altogether empty; in a
word, that can gra≈øp the ∆≤niver≈øe with a Thought, and comprehend the whole Latitude of Heaven and Earth within its own indivi≈øible Center; how ≈øen≈øle≈øs is it to imagine that ≈øuch Noble Operations as the≈øe can be performed by a meer Complex of dead Atoms and ≈øen≈øle≈øs Particles of Matter? And if they cannot, as doubtle≈øs they cannot, then from hence it will nece≈ø≈øarily follow that the Soul of Man is an immaterial Thing. Furthermore we ≈øee, that tho the Soul takes in Objects of all ≈øizes, yet when once they are in, they are not as Bodies in a material Place in which the Greater take up more Room than the Le≈øs: For the Thought of a Mile, or ten thou≈øand Miles doth no more fill or ≈øtretch a Soul, than that of a Foot or an Inch, or a Mathematical Point; and whereas all Matter hath its Parts, and tho≈øe extended one without another into Length and Breadth and Thickne≈øs, and ≈øo is mea≈øurable by Inches, Yards, or ≈øolid Mea≈øures; there is no ≈øuch Thing as mea≈øurable Exten≈øion in any thing belonging to the Soul. For in Cogitation which is the E≈ø≈øence of a Soul, there is neither Length, nor Breadth, nor Thickne≈øs, nor is it po≈ø≈øible to have any Conceit of Foot of Thought, or a Yard of Rea≈øon, a Pound of Wi≈ødom, or a Quart of Virtue. And if what belongs to a Soul be immaterial, it will nece≈ø≈øarily follow that the Soul it ≈øelf is immaterial too, and as ≈øuch capable of Immortality. For immaterial Natures being pure and ≈øimple, having neither contrary Qualities nor divi≈øible Parts in them, as material Things have, can have no Principles of Alteration and Corruption in them; and being devoid of the≈øe, they mu≈øt needs be capable of living and ≈øub≈øi≈øting for ever. What Noble Beings therefore are the Souls of Men which, together
with tho≈øe vast capacities of ∆≤nder≈øtanding, of Moral Perfection, of Joy and Plea≈øure, are naturally capable of Immortality, and con≈øequently of improving in Knowledge, in Goodne≈øs, and in Joy and Plea≈øure unto all Eternity? And therefore certainly a Soul mu≈øt needs be a mo≈øt precious thing, that can thus out-live all ≈øublunary Beings and ≈øub≈øi≈øt forever in ≈øo ≈øublime a ≈øtate of Glory and Beatitude.
Having thus ≈øhewn you the invaluable Worth of the Soul in Re≈øpect of its own natural Capacities, I proceed

2. To ≈øhew you of what vast E≈øteem it is in the Judgment of all tho≈øe, who we mu≈øt needs ≈øuppo≈øe to be≈øt under≈øtand the Worth of it; and that is the whole World of Spirits. For to be ≈øure Spirits mu≈øt be≈øt under≈øtand the Excellency of Spirits, becau≈øe they have a clearer In-≈øight into each others Natures, and a more immediate Pro≈øpect of the Virtue, Power and Excellency of each others Faculties. For as for us, whil≈øt we are in this imbodied ≈øtate, and do under≈øtand by corporeal Organs, we generally judge of the Worth and Excellency of Things by the Impre≈ø≈øion they make upon our Sen≈øes, and as the≈øe are more or le≈øs gratified and affected with them, we ≈øet a higher or lower Value upon them. Since therefore Spirits are a ≈øort of Beings that cannot touch or affect our Bodily Sen≈øes, it is impo≈ø≈øible we ≈øhould be competent Judges of the true Worth and Value of them; and therefore in this matter we ought to be guided by the Judgment of Spirits, who mu≈øt needs be ≈øuppo≈øed to have a more intimate Acquaintance with one anothers Natures. And if we will be guided by the≈øe, we ≈øhall find the whole World of Spirits, even from the highe≈øt to the
lowest, unanimou≈øly rating the Souls of Men at an ine≈øtimable Price and Value. And to make this appear, I ≈øhall ≈øhew you the vast Price there is ≈øet upon them.

div.p:
1. Let us con≈øider the va≈øt Price which God the Father hath ≈øet upon Souls. For when he intended to form the≈øe Noble Beings, and tran≈ømit them into terre≈øtrial Bodies, that ≈øo being compounded with a ≈øen≈øitive Nature they might cla≈øp the Spiritual and Animal Worlds together; he being ≈øen≈øible of the va≈øt Hazards and infinite Snares they would be expo≈øed too, was ≈øo deeply concerned for their Pre≈øervation, that he thought nothing too dear to ≈øave and ≈øecure them. And fore-≈øeeing their Fall from that terre≈øtrial Happine≈øs which he originally de≈øigned them, notwith≈øtanding the liberal Care he had taken to pre≈øerve them in the State of Innocence, he de≈øigned to remove the Scene of their Happine≈øs from Earth to Heaven, being re≈øolved, if po≈ø≈øible, to repair the Lo≈øs of a terre≈øtrial with a cale≈øtial Paradi≈øe. For which end, in≈øtead of the Covenant of Innocence the Ble≈ø≈øings whereof by their Sin they had forever forfeited, he introduces the Covenant of Repentance, that ≈øo by the help of this Plank after their general Ship-wrack, they might be pre≈øerved, and to ≈øafe to the Shoar of a happy Eternity. And that by this Covenant he might the more effectually
recover them, he de≈øigned to grant it to them in ≈øuch a Way, and upon ≈øuch a wi≈øe and weighty Con≈øideration, as might at once affect them with the greatest ≈øen≈øe of his Love and the deepest A we of his Severity; that ≈øo whil≈øt by the former he allured, by the later he might terrify to Repentance: To which end he determined not to grant it to them upon any other Con≈øideration than that of anothers ≈øuffering for them, and undergoing the Puni≈øhment of their Sin in their ≈øtead; that ≈øo whil≈øt he ≈øhewed his Love to them in admitting another to ≈øuffer for them, he might expre≈øs his Hatred to their Sin in not Pardoning it without anothers ≈øuffering. And that he might manife≈øt this his Love to them, and this his Hatred to their Sin in the highest Degree, as he admitted another to ≈øuffer for us, ≈øo he re≈øolved to accept no meaner Suffering than that of his own beloved Son. And that this his ≈øuffering might be the more effectual, he propo≈øed to ≈øend him down to us into this lower World cloathed in our Natures, that ≈øo he might not only the more familiarly in≈øtruct us by his Doctrine and Example, but the more exactly per≈øonate us in undergoing the Puni≈øhment of our Sin; and upon his undertaking to undergo it, the mo≈øt Merciful Father agreed to this Covenant of Mercy, by which he obliged him≈øelf to receive us into his Favour upon our unfeigned Repentance, and impower'd his Son to govern us according to the Tenour of it, that is, to Crown us with the Rewards of it if we Repented, and inflict on us the Puni≈øhments of it if we went on in our Impenitence. And that there might be nothing wanting to render this Government of his Son ≈øucce≈øsful and us obedient to it, he al≈øo agreed upon this his Mighty
undertaking to ≈øub≈øtitute to him the Holy Gho≈øt to be the ≈øupreme Mini≈øter of his Government, that ≈øo by the Agency of this vicarious Power he might bow and incline the Hearts of Men to ≈øubmit unto him, and comply with the Terms of this Merciful Covenant in which their everla≈øting Welfare is ≈øo abundantly provided for.

This is the mighty Project which, for the ≈øake of the Souls of Men, the Father of Spirits hath contrived, and upon which he hath acted and proceeded even from their fir≈øt Fall to this very Moment; And by this he hath mo≈øt plainly expre≈ø≈øed the high and great Veneration that he hath of them; for doubtle≈øs had they not been exceeding precious in his Eyes, he would never have thought it worth the while to project and act, ≈øuch mighty Things to redeem and ≈øave them: He would rather have left them to their own Fate, and not have concerned him≈øelf about them, or not have concerned him≈øelf to that Degree as to make them the Subjects of ≈øuch a vast De≈øign. For all wi≈øe Agents mea≈øure their De≈øigns by the Worth and Value of the Things they aim at, and do never lay great Projects for the ≈øake of little Trifles; and unle≈øs God had a mighty Value for the Souls of Men, his making ≈øuch va≈øt Preparations to ≈øave them would be like that fooli≈øh Emperors rai≈øing a numerous Army, only to go and gather Cockle-≈øhells.

2. Let us con≈øider the vast Price which God the Son hath ≈øet upon Souls; For it is plain he valued them at that mighty Rate, as that for their ≈øakes he willingly undertook to execute this va≈øt De≈øign of his Father, and that to ≈øave the≈øe precious Beings he thought it would be very well worth his while to
come down from Heaven and vail his Divinity in our Natures, to put on the Form of a Servant and make him≈øelf of no Reputation; to live a Mi≈øerable Life, and die a painful and accur≈øed Death. And can we think he would ever have laid down ≈øo vast a Price, as his Glory and Happine≈øs, his Life and Blood amounts to for Things of a mean and incon≈øiderable Value? Had he ≈øo low an E≈øteem of his Father's Bo≈øom, and his own Heavenly Glory as to part with them for Trifles? Such ≈ølight Apprehen≈øions of Shame and Sorrow, Pain and Mi≈øery, as to ca≈øt him≈øelf into them for the ≈øake of Beings he had little or no E≈øteem of? Could any thing but what is ine≈øtimable countervail to that Glory he parted with, and that Mi≈øery he indured? Or, can you think tho≈øe Souls of little Worth which the Son of God thought worth his dying for? No certainly, if we knew nothing of our Souls but this, that the Son of God thought them a good Purcha≈øe at the dear Price of his Bli≈øs, his Glory and his Blood; yet from thence we have infinite Rea≈øon to conclude them mo≈øt precious and ine≈øtimable Beings, it being impo≈ø≈øible that he who doth ≈øo perfectly under≈øtand the Worth and Value of Things, ≈øhould ever be ≈øo over-≈øeen as to pay ≈øo vast a Sum for ≈ølight and cheap Commodities.

3. Let us con≈øider the va≈øt Price which God the Holy Ghost hath ≈øet upon Souls; For 'tis for their ≈øakes that he doth ≈øo Indu≈øtriou≈øly operate in the Kingdom of our Saviour, that he takes ≈øo much Pains in it, as he doth and hath alway done, ever ≈øince it was fir≈øt erected, to drive on that ble≈ø≈øed De≈øign of making the Souls of Men, the native Subjects of it happy. It is upon their Account that he hath made ≈øo many Revelations of God's Will to
the World, and confirmed them by ≈øo many Miracles, that ≈øo he might extricate tho≈øe precious Beings out of tho≈øe Labyrinths of Error in which they had involved and lo≈øt them≈øelves, and direct them into the way to true Happine≈øs. And it is for their good that he ≈øtill continues ≈øhedding forth his Heavenly Influences upon them, that he ≈øtill in≈øpires them with ≈øo many good Thoughts, importunes them with ≈øuch urgent Motives, pre≈ø≈øes upon them with ≈øuch earne≈øt Struglings and vigorous Efforts, not only of his preventing but of his a≈ø≈øi≈øting Grace too, that if po≈ø≈øible he may awaken them into a Sen≈øe of their Danger, and excite and quicken them to pur≈øue the Methods of their own Safety and Happine≈øs.

So infinitely jealous is this ble≈ø≈øed Spirit le≈øt the≈øe precious Beings ≈øhould Mi≈øcarry, that tho one would think them ≈øufficiently ≈øafe-guarded in their Voyage through this dangerous Sea under the Convoy of their own Rea≈øon, yet he dares not tru≈øt them to them≈øelves, but bears them Company all along, and keeps a watchful Eye over them, and when any Rock is nigh he warns them of it, and when they are be≈øet with evil Spirits, tho≈øe mi≈øchievous Pirates that lie in wait to Captivate and In≈ølave them, he pre≈øently comes into their A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and, unle≈øs they are re≈øolved to betray them≈øelves, always brings them off victoriou≈øly. Nay, tho they many times not only yield to the≈øe Piratical Spirits, but joyn their Forces with them to re≈øi≈øt and beat off their merciful Friend and Deliverer, yet he doth not therefore pre≈øently abandon them, but being infinitely concerned for their Re≈øcue follows them even to the Mouth of the Enemies Harbour with his ble≈ø≈øed Motions and Importunities,
