for in this State of De≈øtruction, they ≈øtill continue to act, to weep and wail, and gna≈øh their Teeth, as Chri≈øt el≈øewhere tells us, Mat. xiii. 42. which Actions plainly ≈øuppo≈øe their Continuance in Being, though in a mo≈øt wretched and deplorable Ill-being. So that by the Lo≈øs of the Soul here is not meant the De≈øtruction of its Being, but its being expo≈øed to an irreparable Damage in the other World. And to prove that in this Sen≈øe a Soul may be lo≈øt, I ≈øhall endeavour the≈øe two Things.

list.item: Fir≈øt, To ≈øhew you what Damages the Soul is liable to in the other World.
Secondly, Upon what Accounts it is liable to, and in Danger of them.

div.p: I. What Damages the Soul is liable to in the other World. To which I an≈øwer, that there is a ≈øevenfold Damage whereunto the Soul of Man may be expo≈øed hereafter.

list.item: 1≈øt. It is liable to be deprived of the highe≈øt Happine≈øs it is capable of.
2ly. It is liable to the mo≈øt dreadful Puni≈øhment and Correction of the Father of Spirits.
3ly. It is liable to the Fury and Violence of Devils, and other malignant Spirits.
4. It is liable to be confined to the mo≈øt di≈ømal and uncomfortable Abodes.
5ly. It is liable to the perpetual Vexations of its own cro≈øs, wild, and furious Pa≈ø≈øions.
6ly. It is liable to the intolerable Angui≈øh of its own guilty Con≈øcience.
7ly. It is liable to indure all the≈øe di≈ømal Things for ever.

div.p:
1≈øt. The Soul of Man is liable to be deprived of the highe≈øt Happine≈øs it is capable of. The highe≈øt Happine≈øs that a Soul is capable of is to enjoy God, that is, to know, and love, and re≈øemble him; and to be admitted into the noble Society of tho≈øe pure, and ble≈ø≈øed Spirits that do thus enjoy him; of all which Happine≈øs a Soul may be for ever deprived by its own vicious and depraved Temper. For be≈øides that by ≈øuch a Temper it may provoke the ju≈øt and holy God, who hath the Di≈øpo≈øal of the fate of Souls, to deprive it of, and bani≈øh it from this Happine≈øs for ever; it may thereby al≈øo utterly incapacitate it ≈øelf from ever enjoying it; it may promote and rai≈øe that Temper to ≈øuch a Degree of Averfation and Antipathy to God, and canker it into ≈øuch an inveterate Enmity to all the Perfections of his Nature, as that at la≈øt it may be utterly incapable of any ≈øuch beatifical Knowledge of them, as can any ways incline it to love and imitate him: For the Apo≈øtle tells us, that the carnal Mind is empty to God, Rom. viii. 7. From whence it is evident, that in every Degree of Sin, there is a Degree of Aver≈øation to God, which Aver≈øation may be improved into ≈øuch an implacable Malice again≈øt him, as that our Knowledge of him, in≈øtead of endearing him to us, or ingaging us to imitate him, may only avert us from, provoke, and irritate us again≈øt him, and by pre≈øenting to us tho≈øe immen≈øe Perfections, for which he de≈øerves our deare≈øt Love, and deepe≈øt Adoration, may only fill our Minds with the greater Rage and more invincible Horror. And when
the Soul is arrived to ≈øuch a Degree of Malignity again≈øt God, it is as impo≈ø≈øible for it to injoy him, as to be recreated with Torment, or delighted with the Objects of its own Antipathies. And for the ≈øame Rea≈øon al≈øo it mu≈øt be incapable of enjoying the Society of ble≈ø≈øed Spirits, becau≈øe it hath acquired a Temper that is infinitely repugnant to their Heavenly Genius; ≈øo that if ≈øuch a prejudiced Soul ≈øhould, when it is arrived into Eternity, find the Gates of Heaven open to receive it, it would doubtle≈øs be ≈øo offended at every thing that is Heavenly, ≈øo ≈øtartled at the Sight of God, and the Di≈øplays of his hated Perfections, and ≈øeized with ≈øuch a Horror again≈øt tho≈øe god-like Beings that dwell there, and are perpetually contemplating and adoring, loving and imitating him, that it would fly away of its own Accord from that bli≈øsful Habitation, as Bats and Owls do from the Light of the Day, and rather chu≈øe to bani≈øh it ≈øelf into eternal Darkne≈øs and De≈øpair, than be ≈øhut up for ever in a Heaven ≈øo infinitely repugnant to its Nature. And certainly to be thus excommunicated from the ≈øupreme Happine≈øs of our Natures, and be forced to live in everla≈øting Exile from God and ble≈ø≈øed Spirits, and wander about like wretched Vagabonds that are cha≈øed and driven from all Hopes of Contentment, will be un≈øpeakable Damage to our Souls.

2ly. The Soul of Man is liable to the mo≈øt dreadful Puni≈øhment and Correction of the Father of Spirits. There is no Doubt but ≈øpiritual Agents can ≈øtrike as immediately upon Spirits, as bodily Agents can upon Bodies; and though we who are Spectators only of corporeal Action cannot di≈øcern the Manner how one Spirit acts upon another, net there
is no Rea≈øon to Doubt of the thing; and if there be ≈øuch a mutual Communication of Action between them, there is no Doubt but they can mutually make each other feel each others Plea≈øures and Di≈øplea≈øures; and if ≈øo, then it is only to ≈øuppo≈øe that the le≈øs powerful Spirits are ≈øubject to the violent Impre≈ø≈øion of the more powerful ones, and con≈øequently that all finite Spirits are liable to the La≈øh of an infinite one; for why ≈øhould it be more difficult for the Father of our Spirits to correct our Spirits, than it is for the Parents of our Fle≈øh to correct our Fle≈øh? For though our Souls are no more impre≈ø≈øible with material Stripes than Sunbeams are with the blows of a Hammer, yet are they liable to horrid and di≈ømal Thoughts, and to be as much pained and aggrieved by them, as our Bodies are by the mo≈øt exqui≈øite Torments. So that if God be di≈øplea≈øed with us, he can imprint his Wrath upon our Minds in black and gha≈øtly Thoughts, and cau≈øe it perpetually to drop like burning Sulphur upon our Souls. He cannot only abandon us to the furious Reflections of our own natural Con≈øciences, which, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew you by and by, will be hereafter extreamly painful and vexatious, but he can al≈øo infu≈øe ≈øupernatural Horrors into us, and pour in ≈øuch Swarms of terrible Thoughts upon us as will give us no Re≈øt, but ≈øting us perpetually Day and Night with inexpre≈ø≈øible Angui≈øh. And of this you have a woful Example in that mi≈øerable Wretch Francis Spira, who, upon that fearful Breach he made in his Con≈øcience by a cowardly Renouncing of his Religion, was without any Symptoms of a bodily Melancholy immediately ≈øei≈øed with ≈øuch an inexpre≈ø≈øible Agony of
Mind as amazed his Phy≈øicians, a≈øtoni≈øhed his Friends, and ≈øtruck Terror into all that conver≈øed with him. For he was ≈øo near to the Condition of a damned Gho≈øt, that he verily believed Hell it ≈øelf was more tolerable than tho≈øe invi≈øible La≈øhes that were continually laid upon his Soul; and therefore wi≈øhed he were in Hell, and would gladly have di≈øpatched him≈øelf thither in hope to find Sanctuary there from tho≈øe vengeful Thoughts which continually preyed upon his Soul. And if in this World our Soul is ≈øo liable to the Rod of the Father of Spirits, we may be ≈øure it will be ≈øo in the other too, where God, if he plea≈øes can render it an eternal Hell to it ≈øelf by pouring continually into it fre≈øh Floods of horrible Thoughts, which being thru≈øt on by an Almighty Power, and perpetually urged and repeated on the Mind, mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily create in it not only exqui≈øite, but uninterrupted Torment. And it being in his Power thus to la≈øh our Souls, to be ≈øure when once he is implacably incen≈øed again≈øt them, (as he will be hereafter, if we do not appea≈øe him) he will let loo≈øe his Power upon them, and make them feel his wrathful Re≈øentments in tho≈øe dire and frightful Thoughts with which he will Sting and Scourge them for ever. And if the Soul carry into Eternity with it tho≈øe provoking Lu≈øts which do here incen≈øe God's Di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt it, it will there have no Shelter from the Storm of his Vengeance, which like a Shower of Fire and Brim≈øtone, will be continually pouring down upon it. For while it continues in this Shop of Vanities, it hath a great Variety of Objects to divert tho≈øe di≈ømal Thoughts which God many times infu≈øes
into it; but in the other World all the≈øe diverting Objects will be removed, and then every di≈ømal Thought which God lets loo≈øe will ≈øei≈øe and fa≈øten upon it, and like Prometheus's Vultures, prey on its wretched Heart for ever.

3ly. The Soul of Man is liable to the Fury and Violence of Devils, and other malignant Spirits. For when ever the Souls of Men do leave their Bodies, they doubtle≈øs flock with the Birds of their own Feather, and con≈øort them≈øelves with ≈øuch ≈øeparate Spirits as are of their own Genius and Temper; for be≈øides that Likene≈øs doth naturally congregate Beings, and cau≈øe them to a≈ø≈øociate with their own Kind, good and bad Spirits are by the eternal Laws of the other World di≈øtributed in two ≈øeparate Nations, and there live apart from one another, having no other Communication or Intercour≈øe but what is between two ho≈øtile Countries that are continually de≈øigning and attempting one again≈øt another. So that when wicked Souls do leave this terre≈øtrial Abode, and pa≈øs into Eternity, they are pre≈øently incorporated by the Laws of that invi≈øible World into the Nation of wicked Spirits, and confined for ever to their mo≈øt wretched Society and Conver≈øe; and then how mi≈øerable mu≈øt their Condition be, who are damned to ≈øuch a helli≈øh Neighbourhood, and are allowed no other Company but Devils and devili≈øh Spirits? For ≈øince, as I have already ≈øhewed you, Spirits can as well act upon one another as Bodies, what can be expected when ≈øuch malignant Spirits meet, but that they ≈øhould be continually ≈ønarling among them≈øelves, and baiting and worrying one another? When Wrath and Envy, Malice and Ill-nature
are the common Genius that in≈øpires and acts the whole Society, what can their Conver≈øation be, but a continual Intercour≈øe of mutual Mi≈øchiefs and Vexations; e≈øpecially con≈øidering how they have here laid the Foundations of an eternal Quarrel again≈øt one another? For there the Companions in Sin will meet, who by their ill Coun≈øels, wicked In≈øinuations, and bad Examples did mutually contribute to each others Ruin; and when the≈øe ≈øhall meet in that woful State, how will the tormenting Sen≈øe of tho≈øe irreparable Injuries they have done each other incite them to exerci≈øe their helli≈øh Fury upon, and play the Devils with one another? And when a Company of wa≈øpi≈øh Spirits ≈øo implacably incen≈øed again≈øt one another ≈øhall meet, and like ≈øo many Scorpions, Snakes, and Adders be ≈øhut up together in the infernal Dens, how is it po≈ø≈øible they ≈øhould forbear hi≈ø≈øing at, and ≈øtinging, and ≈øpitting Venom in one anothers Faces. But then be≈øides the mutual Plagues which tho≈øe incen≈øed and furious Spirits mu≈øt needs be ≈øuppo≈øed to inflict upon one another, they will be al≈øo nakedly expo≈øed to the powerful Malice of the Devils, tho≈øe fierce Executioners of Gods righteous Vengeance, who, as we now find by Experience have Power to ≈øugge≈øt black and horrid Thoughts, and to torture our our Souls with ≈øuch dreadful Imaginations, as are far more ≈øharp and exqui≈øite than any bodily Torment. And if now they have ≈øuch Power over us when God thinks fit to let them loo≈øe, what will they have hereafter, when the≈øe our wretched Spirits ≈øhall be wholly abandoned to their Mercy, and they ≈øhall have a free Scope to exerci≈øe their Fury upon us, and glut their hungry
Malice with our Vexations and Torments? It ≈øeems at lea≈øt a mighty probable Notion that that horrid Agony of our Saviour in the Garden which cau≈øed him to ≈øhriek and grone, and ≈øweat as it were great Drops of Blood, was only the Effect of tho≈øe preternatural Terrors which the Devils, with whom he was then in Combat, impre≈ø≈øed upon his innocent Mind. And if they had ≈øo much Power over his pure and mighty Soul that was ≈øo ≈øtrongly guarded with the mo≈øt perfect and un≈øpotted Virtues, what will they have over ours when God hath abandoned us to them, and throws us as Preys into their Mouths? with what an helli≈øh Rage will they fly upon our guilty and timorous Souls, in which there is ≈øo much Tinder for their injected Sparks of Horror to take Fire on? When therefore our guilty Spirits ≈øhall not only be liable to the Scourge of God, but Devils and damned Gho≈øts too ≈øhall have their full Swing at them, doubtle≈øs the Hell within them will be far more intollerable than any Hell of Fire and Brim≈øtone without them.

4ly. The Soul of Man is al≈øo liable to be confined to the mo≈øt di≈ømal and uncomfortable Abodes. What or where the Abode of wicked Spirits is till the Morn of the Re≈øurrection, is no where expre≈øly determined in the Holy Scripture; but ≈øince, where≈øoever they are, they are doubtle≈øs under the Power and Dominion of the Devil, who, as the Scripture a≈ø≈øures us, is Prince of the Power of the Air; it is highly probable that their pre≈øent Re≈øidence is in the≈øe lower Regions of the World; that either being cha≈øed by tho≈øe infernal Powers under who≈øe Tyranny they are, they are continually
hurrying about in the≈øe inferiour Tracts of Air, or, which perhaps is more probable, that they are impri≈øoned by tho≈øe invi≈øible Mini≈øters of the divine Ju≈øtice within the dark Aby≈ø≈øes and under-ground Vaults of the Earth, and not permitted, but upon ≈øpecial Occa≈øions, to come abroad into this upper Region of Light and Liberty. But where≈øoever they are, it is doubtle≈øs in ≈øome ≈øuch horrid and di≈ømal Pri≈øon, as is fit only to receive ≈øuch vile and de≈øperate Malefactors, and ≈øecure them till the great A≈ø≈øizes, when they ≈øhall be brought forth to receive their Tryal and final Judgment: And then being united to their Bodies, and thereby made liable to corporeal Torments, the Scripture expre≈øly affirms that they ≈øhall be ≈øhut up in everla≈øting Flames, and be tormented for ever in a Lake of Fire and Brim≈øtone; for then the Lord him≈øelf ≈øhall come in Flames of Fire to render Vengance to all tho≈øe that obeyed not his Go≈øpel; and having with tho≈øe raging Flames ≈øet every Part of this lower World on Fire, he will re-a≈øcend with all his Train to the cele≈øtial Man≈øions, and leave the Wicked weltring for ever in this burning Vault below; for it is plain, that the everla≈øting Fire to which he will then Sentence them is the Conflagration of the World, which, after the Ju≈øt are rai≈øed, and caught up in the Clouds above the Reach of its a≈øpiring Flames, ≈øhall break forth on every ≈øide, and turn all this Atmo≈øphere into a Furnace of inquenchable Fire, and therein ≈øhall tho≈øe wicked Mi≈øcreants that would not be reclaimed, be condemned to live for ever. For the Judgment being ended, the Judg and all his Retinue ≈øhall return, and leave them in the mid≈øt of a burning World
≈øurrounded with Smoak and Fire, Darkne≈øs and Confu≈øion, and wrapt in fierce and mercile≈øs Flames, which ≈øhall ≈øtick clo≈øe to and pierce through and through their Bodies, and for ever prey upon, but never con≈øume them. And what an intolerable Mulct this is, I leave every Mans natural Sen≈øe to judge.

5ly. The Soul of Man is al≈øo liable to the perpetual Vexations of its own cro≈øs, wild, and furious Pa≈ø≈øions. We have ≈øufficient Experience in this Life how vexatious our cro≈øs and exce≈ø≈øive Pa≈ø≈øions are; for when our Pa≈ø≈øions are divided, and contrary Objects have rai≈øed contrary De≈øires and Appetites in us, how do they rend and di≈øtract our Souls, and cau≈øe perpetual Mutinies and Tumults within us? But by Rea≈øon of tho≈øe many ≈øen≈øual Gratifications with which we now make a ≈øhift to ≈øtop the Mouths of tho≈øe Daughters of the Hor≈øe-Leech, when they cry out give, give; we cannot be ≈øo ≈øen≈øible of the Trouble and Vexation of them; unle≈øs we now ≈øubdue and mortifie them, we we ≈øhall be forced to carry them into Eternity along with us. For by being ≈øeparated from their Bodies the Souls of Men are never ≈øeparated from their prevailing Tempers, but in their ≈øeparated State are for the main of the ≈øame Di≈øpo≈øition as they were here: and do retain the ≈øame Pa≈ø≈øions and Appetites. 'Tis true, they cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed to retain their bodily Appetites after they have thrown off their Bodies, but when they have wholly accu≈øtomed them≈øelves in this Life to fle≈øhly Plea≈øures, and have never Experienced ≈øpiritual ones, it is impo≈ø≈øible but that in the other they ≈øhould be tormented with an outragious De≈øire of
being imbodied again; that ≈øo being incapable of reli≈øhing any other, they may repeat tho≈øe fle≈øhly Plea≈øures which heretofore they were accu≈øtomed to, and act over the bruiti≈øh Scene anew. And this vehement Hankering of the≈øe earnalized Souls to return into their Bodily State, is perhaps the only Sen≈øuality that a ≈øeparate Soul is capable of; but it is ≈øuch a Sen≈øuality as mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily render ≈øuch Souls extremely mi≈øerable; for in that State it will be like the Hunger of a Starving Man that is Immured between two dead Walls, that is, it will be a fierce De≈øire without Hope of Satisfaction, a corroding Hunger, ≈øharpened with De≈øpair of Food, than which there is nothing more intolerably grievous and tormenting. For how will it vex the wretched Spirit to look back from the Shores of Eternity into this corporeal World, and to ruminate thus with it ≈øelf; O mi≈øerable Creature that I am! here am I ca≈øt away for ever upon a ≈øtrange and de≈øolate Shore, where I mu≈øt Fami≈øh for want of Food, pine away a long Eternity, and wander to and fro for ever tormented with re≈øtle≈øs Rage and hungry un≈øatisfied De≈øires; where is not one Plea≈øure that I can reli≈øh, not an Object that I can ta≈øte any ≈øweetne≈øs in. We is me! yonder are all my Joys and Comforts, all that is dear and precious to me. O that I might go back again, and be once more re≈øtored to the Injoyment of them! but alas! between me and them there runs an impa≈ø≈øible Gulph, that deprives me of all hope of returning! For thus will the unhappy Soul torment it ≈øelf with an outragious Longing for that which it can never hope to enjoy. But then be≈øides this Appetite of Sen≈øuality which it will there be vexed with, it will al≈øo carry along with it all that Envy and
Malice, that Wrath and Impatience, Pride and In≈øolence which it here contracted; which Black and Helli≈øh Pa≈ø≈øions will prove perpetual Furies in its Bo≈øom; For in that wretched State it will not only have Objects always pre≈øent. to excite them, but ≈øuch Objects too as will excite them all at once to the mo≈øt outragious Exce≈ø≈øes. For when all at once it ≈øhall ≈øee others advanced to the greatest Heights of Glory and Happine≈øs, and it ≈øelf not only rejected but abandoned to endle≈øs Mi≈øery, the Sen≈øe of this mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily irritate all its devili≈øh Pa≈ø≈øions to the highest Extremities, and cau≈øe its Pride to ≈øwell, its Envy to bur≈øt, and its Wrath to boil into a Diabolical Fury; and what a continual Hell mu≈øt this create in the Soul, to be perpetually worried with ≈øo many black and rabid Pa≈ø≈øions, to have all its inferiour Parts and Affections, like tho≈øe of the Mon≈øter Scylla whom the Poets talk of, as ≈øo many Dogs continually barking and ≈ønarling at one another, and yet remain un≈øeparable, as being Comparts of the ≈øame Sub≈øtance?

6ly. The Soul of Man is al≈øo liable to the intolerable Angui≈øh of its own guilty Con≈øcience. The Spirit of a Man, ≈øays Solomon, can bear his Infirmities, but a wounded Spirit who can bear? Intimating that of all the Pa≈ø≈øions which humane Nature is liable to, there are none ≈øo grievous as that of a Mind awakened with a ≈øen≈øe of Guilt. And of the Truth of this we have ≈øome Experience even in this Life, tho now we can make a ≈øhift either to divert our ≈øelves by our ≈øen≈øual Mirth and Jollities, from li≈øtening to the Clamours of our guilty Minds, or el≈øe to deceive our ≈øelves into a groundle≈øs Peace by indulgent and fallacious Principles; but unle≈øs
we expiate our Guilts here, we ≈øhall carry them into Eternity with us, where all tho≈øe ≈øen≈øual Plea≈øures, with which we now divert our ≈øelves from reflecting on our Actions, will be removed, and all tho≈øe fallacious Principles, with which we cheat and deceive our ≈øelves, will be baffled by a woful Experience. So that then our Soul will be nakedly expo≈øed to the La≈øh of its own furious Thoughts, and having nothing to guard or defend it ≈øelf again≈øt the cutting Reflections of a guilty Con≈øcience, which being rou≈øed up and kept awake by the unintermitting ≈øen≈øe of our Mi≈øery will be always clamouring upon us, and continually torturing our wretched Minds with ≈øharp and vexatious Reflections: and be≈øides, whil≈øt our Soul doth act by bodily In≈øtruments, and work in this Mire of Fle≈øh, it is impo≈ø≈øible it ≈øhould be ≈øo nimble and expedite in its Motions, as it will be when it is a naked Spirit. For then its Perceptions will be much clearer, its Convictions more ≈øtrong and evident, and all its Reflections active as the Lightning, and quick as the Wing of an Angel. So that whereas now the ≈øharpe≈øt Stings of our Con≈øcience have an Intermixture of Fancy and Imagination in them, being gro≈øs and material Powers do dull and rebate the Edge of them, and render them le≈øs pungent and ≈øen≈øible; when we are ≈øtripped out of our Fle≈øh, and ≈øent naked into the other World, we ≈øhall have no Clog about us to break or allay tho≈øe ≈øharp Reflections with which we ≈øhall be forced to la≈øh our ≈øelves for ever. And then our Con≈øcience will cut to the quick, and ≈øting with a corroding Venom; then will the Remembrance of tho≈øe Guilts which brought our
Mi≈øeries upon us, rouze up ≈øuch a Swarm of Horrors in our Minds, as we ≈øhall be able neither to avoid nor indure. For the Sen≈øe of our Mi≈øery will be every Moment ≈øugge≈øting tho≈øe Guilts to our Minds that were the Cau≈øe of it, and continually upbraiding us with tho≈øe de≈øperate Follies by which we ran our ≈øelves into it; the Con≈øideration of which will cau≈øe us to hate and cur≈øe our ≈øelves for ever, and to di≈øcharge our Fury upon our own Heads, which will make our Soul turn Devil to it ≈øelf, and force it to be its own Executioner. For it being now con≈øcious to it ≈øelf that its Mi≈øeries are nothing el≈øe but the rueful and pitile≈øs De≈øerts of its own Folly and Madne≈øs, it will be continually meditating horrible Reflections and ≈øinging Satyrs on it ≈øelf. So that while it is wandring among wretched Gho≈øts through the di≈ømal Shades below, it will never cea≈øe la≈øhing it ≈øelf with its own ≈øharp and ≈øtinging Thoughts, till it hath chafed it ≈øelf into a Fury, and boiled up its ≈øelf-condemning Rage into everla≈øting Madne≈øs.

7ly. And la≈øtly, The Soul of Man is al≈øo liable to endure all the≈øe di≈ømal things for ever: For that our Souls are naturally immaterial and immortal, I have already proved; ≈øo that if God in his infinite Ju≈øtice ≈øhall think fit to ≈øentence wicked Souls irrecoverably to all the≈øe above named Mi≈øeries, they mu≈øt by the Con≈øtitution of their own Natures live in, and undergo them for ever. And that he doth think to pronounce and execute ≈øuch a Sentence upon them, he him≈øelf hath a≈ø≈øured us; for ≈øo in Scripture he hath plainly declared, that their Puni≈øhment ≈øhall be everla≈øting, Mat. 25.7. The≈øe, ≈øaith he ≈øpeaking of the Wicked, ≈øhall go
away into everla≈øting Puni≈øhment: and accordingly the Fire in, and with which they are to be puni≈øhed, is called everla≈øting fire, Mat. 25.41. and that that they ≈øhall ≈øub≈øi≈øt for ever in this Fire, and be co-eternal with it, is evident by tho≈øe Pa≈ø≈øions and Actions that are attributed to them in it; for Rev. 14.11. they are ≈øaid to have no re≈øt day nor night in it, but to be in a continual unintermitting Fever, that will nece≈ø≈øary burn and ≈øcorch them, and not allow them the lea≈øt Intervals of Ea≈øe or Comfort. And in Mat. 13.42. the bitter Angui≈øh which they ≈øhall endure in this Fire is de≈øcribed by their weeping, and wailing, and gna≈øhing their Teeth; which Actions are plain Indications not only of their ≈øub≈øi≈øting in this everla≈øting Fire, but of the extream Horror and Angui≈øh that they ≈øhall therein endure. And indeed when God ≈øentences any immortal Being to Mi≈øery, its Mi≈øery mu≈øt be ≈øuppo≈øed to continue as long as it lives, and con≈øequently to continue for ever, ≈øince it is to ≈øub≈øi≈øt and live for ever. And what a fearful Acce≈ø≈øion is this to all tho≈øe above named Mi≈øeries? If we were to endure the ≈øofte≈øt and mo≈øt gentle Pain without any Interval for thirty, forty, or a hundred Years, the Pro≈øpect of that which is to come would render that which is pre≈øent ≈øo intolerable, that we ≈øhould quickly grow weary of our Lives, and wi≈øh our ≈øelves in our Graves. Lord! what ≈øhall we then do when we come to langui≈øh out a long Eternity in the tormenting Agonies of damned Gho≈øts? How will it imbitter every pre≈øent Torment to us, to think of that never-ending Duration of Torment to come, that after we have con≈øumed Millions of Millions of Ages on the
Rack, we have ≈øtill an eternal Hell behind, and are as far di≈øtant from the End of our Mi≈øery, as we were when it fir≈øt began? O! now if we could die and be in≈øen≈øible for ever! what welcome Tidings would it be? how gladly ≈øhould we receive that fatal Blow that could put an End to a woful Eternity? But now it will be in vain for us to cry, O Death, Death, have mercy upon us, and di≈øpatch us quickly into an eternal Grave! For Death is deaf and cannot hear, every Moment it ≈øtabs and wounds, but woe is me! it cannot kill; it ≈øtrikes and ≈øtrikes but cannot ≈øtrike home, and ≈øo is forced to continue as ≈øtrugling under the Pangs of an immortal Death. If there were any Pro≈øpect of an End of our Mi≈øery, though it were after a Million of Ages, this would give ≈øome Ea≈øe to the langui≈øhing Sufferer; But never, never‚Äî O how that fatal Word ≈øtabs the wretched Soul, and rankles its Angui≈øh into eternal De≈øparation! For to be in extream Mi≈øery, and ≈øee no End of it, is the Perfection of Hell, and the utmo≈øt Po≈ø≈øibility of Damnation.

And thus have I endeavoured to repre≈øent unto you the fearful Mulcts our Souls are liable to in the other World; which are ≈øuch as, one would think, were ≈øufficient to awaken the mo≈øt ≈øtupid and in≈øen≈øible Creature.

II. I now pa≈øs on to the ≈øecond thing propo≈øed, which was to ≈øhew you upon what Accounts it is that our Souls are liable to the≈øe dreadful Things; or what it is that expo≈øes us to the Danger of them. In general, it is our own Sin and Wickedne≈øs, which doth not only incen≈øe the holy God
again≈øt us, who is of purer Eyes than to behold Iniquity, and provoke and urge him to inflict the≈øe endle≈øs Mi≈øeries upon us as the ju≈øt Retributions of our de≈øperate Folly and Ob≈øtinacy; but doth al≈øo by its own natural Cau≈øality prepare us for, and ≈øink us into that mi≈øerable State: So that if God ≈øhould not damn us, yet our own Wickedne≈øs would; the Mi≈øery of Damnation being little el≈øe but the Perfection and Con≈øummation of Sin. For the Sting of eternal as well as temporal Death is Sin, and it is Goodne≈øs and Wickedne≈øs that makes Heaven and Hell, tho≈øe two oppo≈øite Hemi≈øpheres of the Invi≈øible World; and as, if Goodne≈øs were plucked out of Heaven, it would cea≈øe to be Heaven, and be overca≈øt immediately with the di≈ømal Shades of Hell; ≈øo if Wickedne≈øs were bani≈øhed out of Hell, it would be Hell no longer, but pre≈øently clear up into Light and Serenity, and ≈øhine forth into a glorious Heaven; But where≈øoever Sin and Wickedne≈øs reigns, there is Hell and Damnation in its nece≈ø≈øary Cau≈øes. Since therefore in nece≈ø≈øary Cau≈øes that which is the Cau≈øe of the Cau≈øe is al≈øo the Cau≈øe of the Effect, our be≈øt way to be re≈øolved what it is that renders us liable to the≈øe future Mi≈øeries, will be to enquire what it is that renders us liable to fall into a ≈øinful Condition at the pre≈øent; for what≈øoever renders us liable to Sin, mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily expo≈øe us to the Danger of Mi≈øery. Now the Danger of our falling into and continuing in a State of Sin, proceeds from the≈øe following Cau≈øes.

list.item: 1. From the natural Liberty of our Wills to Good and Evil.
2ly. From the many Temptations to Evil among which we are placed,
3ly. From the more clo≈øe and intimate Acce≈øs which the≈øe Temptations have to us, than the contrary Motives to Goodne≈øs.
4ly. From the great Corre≈øpondence of the≈øe Temptations with the corrupt Inclinations of our Nature.
5ly. From the unwearied Diligence and great Subtilty of the Devil to make U≈øe of, and apply the≈øe Temptations to us.
6ly. From the plau≈øible Pretences we are furni≈øhed with to excu≈øe, and ju≈øtify our Compliance with them.
7ly. From the extream Difficulty which this our Compliance brings us under to reject and vanqui≈øh them for the future.

div.p:
1. We are liable to fall into a ≈øinful State, and from thence into eternal Mi≈øery from the natural Liberty of our Wills to Good and Evil. If indeed we were nece≈ø≈øarily determined to Good, our Happine≈øs would be intailed upon our Natures, and it would be as impo≈ø≈øible for us to be mi≈øerable, as it is for the Fire to freeze, or for the Ice to burn; but to be ≈øo determined I am apt to think is not con≈øi≈øtent with the condition of a Creature. For to be good by a natural Nece≈ø≈øity requires an infallible Under≈øtanding, or a Mind that is infinitely removed from all Po≈ø≈øibility of being deceived and mi≈øtaken; and this no finite Mind can be: But how ≈øhould the Will be in all particulars nece≈ø≈øarily determined to what is Right, ≈øo long as it is
under the Conduct of a fallible Mind that hath a natural Po≈ø≈øibility of mi≈øleading it? So that to be naturally, nece≈ø≈øarily, and e≈ø≈øentially good, ≈øeems to be an incommunicable Prerogative of the Divine Nature, according to that of our Saviour, There is none good ≈øave one, and that is God, Luke 18.19. For ≈øince no Will can be e≈ø≈øentially good but that which is guided by an infallible Mind, and no Mind can be e≈ø≈øentially infallible but that which is infinite in Knowledge, it hence nece≈ø≈øarily follows, that to be free to Good and Evil is as natural to rea≈øonable Creatures, as it is to be finite in Knowledge and Under≈øtanding. 'Tis true the greater Light of Knowledge there is in the Mind, the le≈øs Freedom to Evil there mu≈øt be in the Will, unle≈øs it hath ≈øome antecedent Bia≈øs and Inclination to Evil; and con≈øequently the Angels being of far more intelligent Natures than we Men, mu≈øt needs be naturally le≈øs free to Evil; but yet that even they are naturally free to it is evident, for that ≈øome of them have actually lap≈øed into Devils; and if they are ≈øo by their Natures, then much more are we by ours, who are ≈øo much their Inferiours in the rational World. For as we are finite Intelligences we mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily have ≈øome Degree of Freedom to Evil in us, but as we are of the lowermo≈øt Rank of Intelligences, we mu≈øt naturally have greater Degrees of this Freedom in us than any other Order of intelligent Natures; And if this were all, yet this very Condition of our Natures renders us more liable to degenerate into an evil and ≈øinful State, than any other kind of rea≈øonable Creatures. If we were now in a State of perfect Innocence, yet of all intelligent
Creatures, we ≈øhould have the greate≈øt Rea≈øon to apprehend the Danger of our Fall; becau≈øe being the lea≈øt intelligent we have the greate≈øt Freedom to Evil, and con≈øequently are on that Account in the greate≈øt danger of falling into it. By the very Condition of our Natures we are of all rational Creatures placed neare≈øt to the Brinks of the fatal Precipice, and therefore have mo≈øt Rea≈øon to apprehend the Danger of falling headlong into it. For doubtle≈øs among innocent Creatures, there are none ≈øo near the Danger of ≈øinning as tho≈øe who≈øe Wills are least re≈øtrain'd from it, and therefore though we were now as innocent as the ble≈ø≈øed Angels are, yet our Condition would be un≈øpeakably more un≈øafe; becau≈øe by how much we fall ≈øhort of them in Knowledge and Under≈øtanding, by ≈øo much we ≈øhould exceed them in our Freedom to Evil, and con≈øequently be ≈øo much the more liable to it. But this alas is the least of our Danger; For

2ly. We are liable to fall into a ≈øinful State, and from thence into eternal Mi≈øery, from the many Temptations to Evil among which we are placed. For this State of Being in which we now are, being intended by God for our Tryal and Probation, it was requi≈øite in order thereunto that we ≈øhould be placed among Difficulties, that we might have ≈øufficient Opportunity to exerci≈øe our Skill and Courage in Religion; for unle≈øs we had ≈øome ≈øuch Difficulties to encounter, there could no Proof or Tryal be made of our Virtue. Hence therefore hath God placed our rational Souls in mortal Bodies, which do naturally abound with bruti≈øh Appetites and De≈øires, and compa≈ø≈øed us round with this
World of ≈øen≈øual Goods and Evils, which continually importunes and excites them, that ≈øo we might have ≈øufficient opportunity to exerci≈øe tho≈øe humane Virtues which con≈øi≈øt in the Dominion of our rational Faculties over the≈øe our bodily Appetites and De≈øires, that we might never want occa≈øion to give the mo≈øt glorious Proofs of our Patience and Cha≈øtity, Temperance and Equanimity, Meekne≈øs and Sobriety; all which are proper to us as Beings made up of Soul and Body whence all tho≈øe bruti≈øh Appetites ari≈øe, in the good or bad Government whereof con≈øi≈øts the Nature of humane Virtue and Vice. So that this pre≈øent State of humane Life is intended by God for a Field of Combat between Rea≈øon and Sen≈øe, between the Law in our Minds, and the Law in our Members; and that the Victory of Rea≈øon might, through the Difficulty of it, be render'd more glorious and remarkable, he hath furni≈øhed its Antagoni≈øt, viz. the bodily Appetite with various Weapons, with the Temptations of a World of ≈øen≈øitive Goods and Evils to a≈ø≈øault and oppo≈øe it, to try its Metal, and exerci≈øe both its active and pa≈ø≈øive Virtues; and upon the ≈øucce≈øs of this Combat depends the everla≈øting Fate o the Soul. If Sen≈øe prevail, and lead her finally Captive into Vice and Wickedne≈øs, ≈øhe is lo≈øt for ever; but if Rea≈øon ger the Victory, and finally reduce the De≈øires and Appetites of Sen≈øe under the Dominion of Virtue, when this mortal Life ends She ≈øhall triumph for ever, and be tran≈ølated hence into a free and di≈øintangled State, where ≈øhe ≈øhall be vexed and inticed no more with the Importunities of ≈øen≈øual Lu≈øts and Affections, but to all Eternity enjoy
the Serenity and Plea≈øure of a pure Intellectual Being. This being therefore the true State of Affairs, it is too too obvious how liable the Soul is to mi≈øcarry when it is placed in a Body among ≈øo many bruti≈øh Pa≈ø≈øions and Appetites, and that Body is placed in a tempting World, among ≈øo many ≈øen≈øitive Goods and Evils that are continually importuning tho≈øe Appetites to mutiny again≈øt Rea≈øon, and carry us away Captive into Folly and Wickedne≈øs. How much Rea≈øon have we to look about us, when we are placed in the mid≈øt of ≈øo many Dangers, and have ≈øuch numberle≈øs Snares on every ≈øide ready to decoy and intangle us? But this is not all neither; For

3ly. We are liable al≈øo to fall into a ≈øinful State, and from thence into eternal Mi≈øery, from the more clo≈øe and intimate Acce≈øs which the≈øe Temptations have to us, than the contrary Motives to Goodne≈øs. For the great Advantage which the≈øe Temptations to Vice have over the mo≈øt powerful Motives to Virtue is this, that they are all of them per≈øent and ≈øen≈øible; for as for tho≈øe grand Motives to Goodne≈øs that are drawn from the Con≈øideration of our future State, they propo≈øe to our Hopes and Fears, tho≈øe Ma≈øter-Springs of our Motions, ≈øuch Goods and Evils as are a great way off, and beyond the pro≈øpect of our bodily Sen≈øes, which makes the Land-skip of them appear exceeding dim and faint upon the Mind; their Futurity, which is one ≈øort of Di≈øtance, cau≈øing them like Things afar off to look confu≈øed and indi≈øtinct, by rea≈øon of which they cannot affect us ≈øo powerfully, and draw ≈øuch ≈øtrong and la≈øting Draughts of them≈øelves upon our minds: For Goods, like
Magnets, have always the ≈øtronge≈øt Attractions when they are neare≈øt; but as for tho≈øe invi≈øible Goods of the other World, they are at ≈øuch a Di≈øtance from us that they can hardly reach us who live upon the remote≈øt Circumference of the Sphere of their Attraction. And as Di≈øtance le≈ø≈øens all Objects to to the Eye, and renders them much ≈ømaller in Appearance than they are in Reality; ≈øo the remote Futurity of tho≈øe eternal Goods which the Motives of Virtue do propo≈øe, detracts from their ju≈øt Magnitude, and makes them, tho un≈øpeakably va≈øt in them≈øelves, appear exceeding ≈ømall and incon≈øiderable to our ≈øhort-≈øighted Minds. And the ≈øame is to be ≈øaid of tho≈øe future Evils al≈øo, which they denounce again≈øt us; and be≈øides, being not only remote, but invi≈øible too, they cannot ≈øtrike upon our Sen≈øes, by which the mo≈øt vigorous Impre≈ø≈øions of Things are made upon our Minds; whereas the Temptations of Vice are all pre≈øent and ≈øen≈øible, and do ≈øo circle us round as ≈øoon as we look abroad into the World, that which way ≈øoever we turn our Eyes they are ≈øtill before us thru≈øting them≈øelves into our Minds, and with their con≈øtant Importunity ≈øtirring and working our De≈øires. So that whenever the≈øe outward Goods or Evils do a≈ø≈øault us, we lie bare and open to them, and they continually pre≈øs ≈øo clo≈øe upon our Sen≈øes, that we are not able to avoid their Impre≈ø≈øions: When any outward Good invites us to a ≈øinful Action, it hath the vast Advantage of being pre≈øcnt and ≈øen≈øible; by Rea≈øon of which, it having a more immediate Acce≈øs to our Minds doth many times prevail before we can Rally up a ≈øufficient Strength of Con≈øiderations again≈øt it; and when we ≈øet our ≈øelves to re≈øi≈øt and ≈øtruggle
with it, the best of our Weapons is a Company of thin and faint Notions of Things afar off; Things that we never ≈øaw nor felt; which whil≈øt we are recollecting, the Vice we are Tempted to, hath its Powers ready to ≈øeize upon the Will, which having oftentimes experienced the Plea≈øure it invites to, is the more ea≈øily ≈øeduced to a fre≈øh Compliance. And whil≈øt our Enemies are ≈øo near us, and our Helps and Succors ≈øo far off, we mu≈øt needs acknowledge our Danger very great and urgent.

4ly. We are liable to fall into a ≈øinful State, and from thence into eternal Mi≈øery, from the great Corre≈øpondence of the≈øe Temptations with the corrupt Inclinations of our Natures. For by Rea≈øon of the Nearne≈øs and Sen≈øiblene≈øs of tho≈øe outward worldly Goods by which we are continually tempted and ≈øolicited to Evil, they have the Advantage of preingaging our Affections to them before we arrive to the U≈øe of our Rea≈øon; for in our tender years the≈øe are the only Goods that we can reli≈øh, they are the≈øe that do feed, clothe, and furni≈øh us in hand with what≈øoever our natural Appetites do gape for; that are the ≈øole Entertainment of our childi≈øh Fanices, and the only Objects our yet unfledg'd Thoughts and De≈øires can reach at; and our Youth being thus intirely inured to them, by that time we are grown up to the Age of Rea≈øon and the Capacities of Virtue and Religion, we have generally contracted ≈øuch an exce≈ø≈øive Inclination towards them, and are ≈øo ≈øtrongly bia≈øs'd with the Love of them, that when≈øoever they beckon to us we are ready to follow them through all the forbidden Tracts that lead to
everla≈øting Ruin. For our Natures being thus vitiated, the Temptations without us have a ≈øtrong Party within us, a Party of traytorous Inclinations which upon every Summons ≈øolicites us to yield, and ≈øurrender up our Virtue and Innocence; and no ≈øooner can any Temptation from without give the Alarm, but pre≈øently our own Lu≈øts are up rai≈øing a Mutiny within us, and with the Heats of our corrupted Fancy do many times ≈øo di≈øorder our Under≈øtanding that it cannot rally up its Con≈øiderations again≈øt them. For before ever our Under≈øtanding could be Furni≈øhed with Con≈øiderations, our Hearts were prepo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with ≈øuch an exce≈ø≈øive degree of ambitious, covetous, and luxurious Inclinations, that when afterwards the Plea≈øures, Profits, and Honours without begin to hold forth their grateful Lures to us, and to tempt us away to Fraud or Treachery, to Vanity or Licentiou≈øne≈øs, tho≈øe depraved Inclinations have gotten ≈øuch Head within us, that they prove mo≈øt commonly too ≈øtrong for all our Con≈øideration, and with their impetuous Current carry us away, and drive us headlong down towards eternal Ruin; and unle≈øs we put forth all the ≈øtrength of our Rea≈øon and Re≈øolution, and the Grace of God al≈øo come in to our Aid, it will be impo≈ø≈øible for us to ≈øtem ≈øuch a furious Tide when it is driven by the Wind of an outward Temptation. When therefore our own Inclinations do ≈øo vigorou≈øly con≈øpire with the Temptations without to thru≈øt us on into Sin and Perdition, how we can be in≈øen≈øible of the eminent danger we are in of Mi≈øcarrying for ever? But

5ly. We are liable al≈øo to fall into a ≈øinful State, and from thence into Eternal Mi≈øery, from the unwearied
Diligence and great Subtilty of the Devil to make U≈øe of, and apply the≈øe Temptations to us. For that the Devil doth commonly, as an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant Genius to the Corruption of our Natures, excite and provoke Men to Wickedne≈øs is very evident from Scripture; where he is ≈øaid to work in the Children of Di≈øobedience, Eph. 2.2. To fill the Heart of Ananias to lie to the Holy Gho≈øt, Acts 5.3. And to take away the Word out of Mens hearts, le≈øt they ≈øhould believe and be ≈øaved, Luke 8.12. All which Expre≈ø≈øions do plainly imply that the Devil is a con≈øtant Agent in the Sins of Men. And being a Spiritual Agent, he mu≈øt needs be ≈øuppo≈øed to have a nearer Acce≈øs to the Soul than any material Cau≈øe what≈øoever. For tho he be totally debarr'd from all kind of Intercou≈øe with the immediate Operations of the rea≈øonable Soul, and can no more look into the Thoughts than we can into the Bowels of the Earth; yet he can ea≈øily get into the Fancy which ≈øtands next to that my≈øterious Chamber that is open to no Eye but Gods, and make what u≈øe he plea≈øes of the infinite Images and Phanta≈øms that are in it, and di≈øpo≈øe, and order, and di≈øtingui≈øh them into the Pictures of what Objects he plea≈øes, ju≈øt as the Painter doth his numerous Cojours that lie confu≈øedly before him in their ≈øeveral Shells, and continue and repeat tho≈øe Pictures and Repre≈øentations as long and as oft as he plea≈øes. And then con≈øidering what the natural U≈øe of the Fancy is, both to the ∆≤nder≈øtanding and Will, how it prompts the one with matter of Invention, and ≈øupplies it with Variety of Objects to work on, and draws forth and excites the other to chu≈øe or reject tho≈øe Objects it pre≈øents, according as they
are plea≈øing or di≈øplea≈øing; we mu≈øt needs ≈øuppo≈øe that the Devil hath a vast Advantage of in≈øinuating his black Sugge≈øtions into the Soul, by having ≈øuch free Acce≈øs into the Fancy. And accordingly he is ≈øaid to put it into the heart of Judas to betray Chri≈øt, John 13.2. But then he being not only a ≈øpiritual, but al≈øo an intellectual Agent, of a va≈øt and capacious Under≈øtanding by Nature, and particularly improved in the black Art of temping by a long Experience of its Wiles and Stratagems, having been a Tempter almo≈øt ever ≈øince he hath been an Angel; he mu≈øt needs be ≈øuppo≈øed to be wonderfully expert and fagacious in it; that after having had five Thou≈øand years experience of the Methods of ≈øeducing Souls to increa≈øe and perfect his natural Subtilty, he mu≈øt by this be fully in≈øtructed when and how to apply him≈øelf to every Age and Con≈øtitution. For this hath been his ≈øole Bu≈øine≈øs wherein he hath been infinitely intent and active ever ≈øince he became a Devil, and if from a Man, then much more from a Devil of one Bu≈øine≈øs. Good Lord deliver me, from a Devil that for five Thou≈øand Years hath been continually making Experiments of Temptation, and drawing them into Rules to direct and order his mi≈øchievous Practice on the Souls of Men. But be≈øides, as the Devil is of a ≈øpiritual and ingelligent Nature, ≈øo he hath a va≈øt Number of his black Angels continually roving about the World to ≈øeduce and captivate us into Sin and Ruin. And tho the≈øe malignant Spirits have no ligament of natural Love between them to tie and oblige them to one another, yet by that perfect Hatred which they all bear to God and Men they are united together in
an inviolable League, and go hand in hand with one another in pur≈øuance of their de≈øperate De≈øign to involve our wretched Souls in the ≈øame eternal Ruin with them≈øelves, which renders their Force ≈øo much the more formidable. And when we have ≈øo many ≈øpiritual, ≈øubtil, and Powerful Adver≈øaries combining again≈øt, and continually wandring to and fro like roaring Lyons to devour us, we cannot but apprehend our Danger exceeding great; e≈øpecially con≈øidering the infinite Temptations from without, that this World affords the great Variety of ≈øen≈øual Goods and Evils which they have to object to our carnalized Minds. For the≈øe mi≈øchievious Spirits, having ≈øo great In≈øight into our Tempers, and ≈øo great a Choice of Objects to ≈øugge≈øt to our Fancies, can never be at a Lo≈øs how they may nick us with a convenient Temptation; and that which gives their Temptations a va≈øt Advantage over us is, that we know not how to di≈øtingui≈øh them from the Motions of our own Hearts; For could we ≈øee the Devil at our Elbows, or hear him whi≈øpering at our Ears every time he in≈øinuates his wicked Sugge≈øtions into our Minds, we ≈øhould doubtle≈øs reject them with an un≈øpeakable Horror; but becau≈øe when they are convey'd into us, we know not how to di≈øtingui≈øh them from the natural Births of our own Minds; therefore we do make no ≈øcruple to hug and dandle them in our Thoughts and entertain them with an actual Complacence. And when the Devil can convey his Poy≈øon into us in ≈øuch an invi≈øible manner, without di≈øcovering his Devils Face; when he can thus prompt us behind the Curtain, and ≈øo di≈øgui≈øe his Whi≈øpers that we can't di≈øcern them from the
≈øecret Lu≈øtings of our own Hearts; how can we be ≈øafe, without great Care and Watchfulne≈øs, from the Malice of ≈øuch a formidable Enemy? But

div.p:
1. We lo≈øe and forfeit our Souls, when we for≈øake Chri≈øt by a total Apo≈øtacy from him: When after we have been Baptized into his Name, and thereby have made a vi≈øible Profe≈ø≈øion of our believing his Doctrines, and obeying his Laws, we turn Runagadoes, and ca≈øt off our Belief of the one, and di≈øown our Obligation to the other; we do mo≈øt ju≈øtly incur the Lo≈øs and Forfeiture

For ≈øo strong and cogent is the Evidence of Chri≈øtianity, that it is not to be ≈øuppo≈øed that any profe≈ø≈øed Christian can be either innocently or excu≈øably ≈øeduced into a Disbelief of it; For Religion being a Matter of the va≈øte≈øt Moment and Concern, he is a Traytor to him≈øelf that either takes up his Religion without Examination, or that upon Examination refu≈øes to be ≈øwayed by the ≈øtronge≈øt Rea≈øon; And I am ≈øure it is impo≈ø≈øible for any Christian to turn Infidel that is but ≈øo hone≈øt to him≈øelf as first to examine carefully the Rea≈øons of his Faith, and then to re≈øolve ≈øincerely not to reject it till better Rea≈øons appear to the contrary; But if either through their wilful Ignorance of the Evidence of Chri≈øtianity, or vicious Prejudice again≈øt the Purity of it, they ≈øuffer them≈øelves to be ≈øeduced into Apo≈øtacy, they are fal≈øe Traytors to them≈øelves, and as ≈øuch are ju≈øtly liable to all tho≈øe eternal Damages they expo≈øe them≈øelves to. And hence it is ≈øaid of tho≈øe that draw-back, that is, apo≈øtatize from Chri≈øtianity, not only that God's Soul ≈øhall have no plea≈øure in them, but al≈øo that they draw back to perdition, Heb. 10.38, 39. and 2 Pet. 2.20. It is ≈øaid of tho≈øe Apo≈øtates, that their latter end is wor≈øe than the beginning; and that it had been better for them not to have known the way of Righteou≈øne≈øs, than after they have known it, to turn from the holy Commandment; which implies that Apostates from Chri≈øtianity do not only forfeit their Souls, but that without Repentance they will be for ever forfeited to the mo≈øt wretched Condition, even to the nethermo≈øt Degree of Perdition.

2ly. We lo≈øe our Souls when notwith≈øtanding we do ≈øtill believe, and are convinced of the Truth of Chri≈øt's Doctrine, we do cowardly renounce the Profe≈ø≈øion of it, or any Part of it. For when once we have received the Faith of Chri≈øt, we are thereby obliged not to renounce the Profe≈ø≈øion of it what≈øoever Hazard it may expo≈øe us to, our ble≈ø≈øed Lord having a≈ø≈øured us that if we deny him before Men, he will al≈øo deny us before his Father which is in Heaven, Mat. 10.33. Not that in Times of Per≈øecution we are always bound to make an actual Profe≈ø≈øion and Publication of our Faith, to run to the Tribunals of our Per≈øecutors before we are ≈øent for, and accu≈øe our ≈øelves of tho≈øe Doctrines for which we are Per≈øecuted; but whenever we are apprehended, accu≈øed, and examined by them, either upon knowledge or ≈øu≈øpicion, we are bound under the Penalty of forfeiting our Souls to own and confe≈øs our Faith, and not to deny any Doctrine or Article of it, what≈øoever the Con≈øequence may be. For in this Ca≈øe to deny our Belief is not only a wilful Lye, which is in it ≈øelf a damnable Crime, but an Act of High-Trea≈øon again≈øt our Lord and Saviour; for by renouncing any Doctrine which he hath revealed and committed
to us, we do not only betray his Tru≈øt, but bla≈øpheme his Veracity; to deny what we believe he hath revealed, being in effect to declare him a Cheat and an Impo≈øtor. And having thus incurred the Guilt of ≈øo black a Trea≈øon again≈øt our Saviour, and wilfully per≈øi≈øting in it, what can we expect the Con≈øequence of it ≈øhould be, but the eternal Lo≈øs and Perdition of our Souls?

3ly. We for≈øake Chri≈øt to the Lo≈øs and Forfeiture of our Souls, when by ob≈øtinate Here≈øy we add to, or ≈øubtract from that Heavenly Doctrine which he hath revealed to us. By Here≈øy I do not mean barely a fal≈øe Opinion in our Religion whether it be of greater or le≈ø≈øer Moment; for I doubt not but the ≈øame Error May be an innocent Mi≈øtake in one Man, and a damnable Here≈øy in another; that in the one it may be the Effect of a weak Under≈øtanding, but in the other, of a perver≈øe and ob≈øtinate Will; and when the Under≈øtanding mi≈øleads the Will it is Weakne≈øs, but when the Will mi≈øleads the Under≈øtanding it is Wickedne≈øs. When therefore by the wicked Prejudice of our corrupt Wills again≈øt the Purity of Chri≈øtianity, our Under≈øtanding is betrayed into loo≈øe and erroneous Principles; when we under≈øtand by our vicious Affections, and adapt our Opinions to the Intere≈øts of our Lu≈øts; when we believe for the ≈øake of any darling Vice, and ≈øuffer our own factious, covetous, and extravagant Pa≈ø≈øions either to tempt us to profe≈øs tho≈øe erreneous Opinions which

So that if out of a vicious Propen≈øion of Will we ob≈øtinately per≈øi≈øt in any Religious Errors, we are not only guilty of that wicked Propen≈øion which is of it ≈øelf ≈øufficient to ruin our Souls; but we are al≈øo accountable for vitiating our Religion with tho≈øe erroneous Mixtures by which we have rendered it a Shelter and Protection to our Lu≈øt. And what the Con≈øequence of this will be St. Jude will inform us, who ≈øpeaking of certain Hereticks, who to gratifie their own wicked Inclinations, had ≈øophi≈øticated Christianity with ≈øundry black and poi≈øonous Principles, pronounces this fearful Doom on them; for whom is re≈øerved the blackne≈øs of darkne≈øs for ever, ver. 13.

4ly. And la≈øtly, We for≈øake Chri≈øt to the Lo≈øs and Forfeiture of our Souls, when by any wilful Cour≈øe of Di≈øobedience we do virtually renounce the Authority of his Laws. And accordingly, Tit. 1.16. the abominable and di≈øobedient are ≈øaid to deny God in their works, even while they profe≈øs to know him; and what the Fate of ≈øuch will be, St. Paul hath forewarned us, Rom. 2.8, 9. The≈ø. 1.8, 9. But before we di≈ømi≈øs this Argument, it will be requi≈øite more particularly to explain what tho≈øe wilful Cour≈øes of Sin are by which they thus renounce him; all which may be reduced to the≈øe three Heads. Fir≈øt, We renounce the Authority of his Laws, when we ≈øin again≈øt him out of wilful Ignorance of them. Secondly, When we ≈øin on again≈øt him out of wilful Incon≈øideration of our Obligation to them. Thirdly, When we per≈øi≈øt in our ≈øin again≈øt Knowledge and Con≈øideration.

1. We vertually renounce the Authority of our Saviour, when we ≈øin on again≈øt him out of wilful Ignorance of his Laws. But then

2ly. We vertually renounce the Authority of our Saviour, when we ≈øin on again≈øt him out of a wilful Incon≈øideration of our Obligations to obey him. For we being rea≈øonable Creatures, are bound by the very Con≈øtitution of our Natures to act con≈øiderately, e≈øpecially in matters of Religion, which are of the greate≈øt Moment and Importance to us; ≈øo that if we mi≈øcarry herein through wilful Incon≈øideration, we are every whit as inexcu≈øable as if we had con≈øiderately betrayed our ≈øelves. Now wilful Incon≈øideration is either actual or habitual; Actual, is either, fir≈øt when notwith≈øtandin we have been ≈øufficiently warned by precedent Surprizes, we take no care for the future; for though it cannot be expected we ≈øhould always keep ≈øo strict a Guard upon our ≈øelves, as never
to be ≈øurprized by an Enemy; yet when we have been overtaken, there is all the Rea≈øon in the World we ≈øhould take warning by it, and grow more wary and vigilant for the future; that we ≈øhould awaken in our Minds ≈øuch Con≈øiderations as are nece≈ø≈øary to prevent our being ≈øurprized again, which if we do not, our next Surprize will be inexcu≈øable. And if the ≈øen≈øe of the Lap≈øe which was perhaps but an innocent Error, or at mo≈øt but a Sin of Infirmity, doth not make us more careful of our ≈øelves for the future; the next will be a wilful Fall: Or el≈øe in the ≈øecond Place, this actual wilful Incon≈øideration is, when upon the pre≈øenting of any beloved Temptation we either quench the good Motions of our Minds, and refu≈øe to con≈øider the Evil and Danger of the Sin we are tempted to, le≈øt we ≈øhould be thereby deterred from committing it; or purpo≈øely contrive to ba≈øfle our own Con≈øideration by oppo≈øing it either with ≈øome ungrounded Hope of Impunity, or ≈øome fallacious Promi≈øe of future Amendment; and if to make way for our ≈øin, we do either of the≈øe ways wilfully drive all good thoughts from our Minds le≈øt they ≈øhould di≈øturb and interupt us in the Injoyment of it, our Incon≈øideration is to be re≈øolved into the Wickedne≈øs of our Wills, and not into the Weakne≈øs and Infirmity of our Natures. And he that will not con≈øider becau≈øe he will ≈øin, and afterwards extenuate his ≈øin by his Incon≈øideration, urges one ≈øin in excu≈øe for another, and makes that which is his Fault. his Apology. When≈øoever therefore we ≈øin out of any actual and wilful Incon≈øideration, we ≈øin wilfully, and con≈øequently do thereby vertually renounce the Authority of
our Saviour; the final Event of which, without our Repentance, will be our everla≈øting Ruin and Perdition. But then be≈øides this actual there is al≈øo an habitual Incon≈øideration, which is wilful; and that is, when by often ≈øtifling the Convictions of our Con≈øciences we have ≈øeared them into a deep In≈øen≈øibility of Good and Evil, ≈øo as that now we ≈øin on without any Remor≈øe or Reluctancy, and return to our Lu≈øts with the ≈øame indifferency as we do to our Beds or our Tables, without either con≈øidering what we are doing, or reflecting on what we have done; And this is ≈øo far from palliating our ≈øin, that it is one of the highe≈øt Aggravations of it: For as it is no excu≈øe that we ≈øin out of an evil Habit which we voluntarily contracted by frequent Acts of ≈øin, ≈øo neither will it at all excu≈øe us that we ≈øin out of an habitual Incon≈øideration which we wilfully contracted by often refu≈øing to con≈øider. But as vicious Habits have a proper Evil and Guiltine≈øs in them di≈øtinct from tho≈øe vicious Acts that produced them; ≈øo habitual Incon≈øideration hath in it a peculiar Venom of its own beyond what was in tho≈øe actual Incon≈øiderations whereby it was acquired. And accordingly it is de≈øcribed in the Scripture as the wor≈øt, the mo≈øt de≈øperate and incurable ≈øtate of a Sinner: It is called a reprobate-Mind, Rom. 1.28, 29. a ≈øcared Con≈øcience, 1 Tim. 4.2. a hard and unrelenting heart that trea≈øureth us wrath again≈øt the day of wrath, Rom. 2.5. So that if we go on in ≈øin without con≈øidering, with a Mind habitually regardle≈øs and in≈øen≈øible, we are hardned and inveterate Rebels, that have not only renounced the Authority of our Saviour, but have al≈øo forfeited our
Selves, and that almo≈øt irreparably again≈øt all his Methods of conquering and ≈øubduing us. But then

3ly. And La≈øtly, We vertually renounce the Authority of our Saviour, when we per≈øi≈øt in our ≈øin again≈øt Knowledge and Con≈øideration. For to ≈øin on ob≈øtinately again≈øt Knowledge and Con≈øideration, argues an invincible Malice of Will; for tho' the Condition of the ignorant and incon≈øiderate Sinner be very ≈øad and deplorable, yet there is much more Hope of him becau≈øe he hath never yet had the Force and Efficacy of Knowledge and Con≈øideration, which perhaps, if ever he be brought to experience, may prove a ≈øucce≈øsful Means of his Cure and Reformation. But the knowing and con≈øiderate Sinner hath tryed and conquered the Remedy, hath experimented the only means of his Cure, and yet it grows wor≈øe and wor≈øe under the Application; he knows what his ≈øin is, and con≈øiders the Con≈øequence of it, and yet ≈øins on; which argues a de≈øperate Re≈øolution of Will in him thus to run him≈øelf upon a fore≈øeen Ruin, and leap into Hell with his Eyes open. And what Hope is there of di≈ø≈øuading him from his ≈øin, that knows and con≈øiders the Arguments again≈øt it, and every day breaks through them all at the Call of every ≈øinful Temptation? And as his Condition is mo≈øt de≈øperate, ≈øo his Soul is mo≈øt guilty and criminal; for every Act of his ≈øin is an open Defiance to the Authority of God and his Saviour; his Rebellion is barefac'd, and hath no manner of Pretence wherein to mask or di≈øgui≈øe it ≈øelf; and he knows and owns him≈øelf to be in a Rebellion, and yet per≈øeveres in it, which extreamly aggravates and inhan≈øes the Guilt
of it. For the Sinfulne≈øs and Immorality of Actions is to be mea≈øured by the Degrees of Will that are in them, and the Degrees of Will in them are more or le≈øs proportionably, as the Nature and Evil of them is more or le≈øs known and con≈øidered. Hence is that of St. James 4.17. To him that knoweth to do good, and doth it not, to him it is ≈øin. Had he not known the Nature of his Action, the Weakne≈øs of his Under≈øtanding would have excu≈øed the Error of his Will, and render'd it pardonable at lea≈øt, if not altogether innocent: But when his Under≈øtanding hath di≈øcharged its Office, and ≈øhewed him the Evil that he ought to avoid, that hath fairly acquitted its ≈øelf, and can ≈øtand no longer chargable for his Mi≈øcarriages: So that now the Man choo≈øes his own Peril, and if he ≈øtill choo≈øe what he ought to avoid, his Under≈øtanding is clear, and his Will alone is Culpable. And when our Rebellion again≈øt our Saviour is not only wilful, but the wilfulne≈øs of it is ≈øo extreamly aggravated by our Knowledge and Con≈øideration, what the Con≈øequence of it will be that fearful Pa≈ø≈øage will a≈ø≈øure us, Luke 12.47. The Servant that knoweth his Ma≈øters will and doth it not, ≈øhall be beaten with many Stripes. And thus I have endeavoured to repre≈øent to you what that For≈øaking of Chri≈øt is, which expo≈øes us to the Hazard of lo≈øing our Souls.
II. I proceed in the next Place to ≈øhew you upon what Accounts it is that our for≈øaking of Chri≈øt infers this fearful Lo≈øs; of which, I ≈øhall Briefly give you this four-fold Account.

list.item: 1. Our thus for≈øaking of Christ infers the Lo≈øs of our Souls, as it is a mo≈øt inexcu≈øable Contempt of the greate≈øt Mercy.
2ly. As it renders us the mo≈øt unfitting Objects of Mercy for the future.
3ly. As it is an open Violation of the fixed and ≈øtated Condition of Mercy.
4ly. As it is an utter Rejection of our la≈øt Remedy.

div.p:
1. Our for≈øaking of Chri≈øt by any of the aforenamed In≈øtances infers the everla≈øting Lo≈øs of our Souls, as it is a mo≈øt inexcu≈øable Contempt of the greate≈øt Mercy. For when the Son of God came down from Heaven, he brought from thence with him the large≈øt Offers of Mercy that Heaven it ≈øelf could make to a ≈øinful World; he did not only bring down with him a Grant of univer≈øal Pardon and Indemnity under the Broad-Seal of Heaven for every Sinner that would lay down his Arms, and return to his Allegiance, together with the mo≈øt endearing Invitations of the God of Heaven, to woo and win us to accept it; but he al≈øo brought along with him all that an everla≈øting Heaven means, Crowns of Immortal Glory and Plea≈øure to encourage us to, and reward our Acceptance of them. And what greater Mercy could the God of Heaven have expre≈ø≈øed to us, than to ≈øend down his ble≈ø≈øed Son, not only to tender to us an Indemnity, but al≈øo to invite us to accept it with a Promi≈øe of Heaven? So that if now we reject him, now he is come to us with ≈øuch vast and endearing Propo≈øals, what an intolerable ≈ølight will it be to the tender Mercies of God? When we ≈øhall declare by our Actions that we will not exchange the ≈øordid Plea≈øures of our Lu≈øt for the Pardon of Heaven, for the Favour of God, and for all the Hopes of a glorious Immortality? How can we expect any farther
Relief from God's Mercy, after we have put ≈øuch an intolerable Affront upon it by preferring ≈øuch an unworthy Rival before it? When God hath laid his Pardon, his Love, and his Heaven in our Way, to ≈øtop us in our ≈øinful Cour≈øes, what a barbarous Indignity will it be to trample upon them all, and run over them into Hell? With what Face can we hope for any farther kindne≈øs from Heaven, after we have treated its Kindne≈øs with ≈øo much Rudene≈øs and Contempt? Certainly for ≈øinful Men to reject and run away from their Saviour, when he comes to them with ≈øo much Kindne≈øs, when he courts them with ≈øuch a≈øtoni≈øhing Expre≈ø≈øions of Mercy, is a Provocation ≈øufficient to incen≈øe an infinite Goodne≈øs, and turn the tendere≈øt Mercy into an implacable Fury. And when infinite Love is ≈øo infinitely provoked, what le≈øs Expiation can it claim and exact, than the everlasting Ruin and Perdition of our Souls?

2ly. Our For≈øaking of Chri≈øt infers the everla≈øting Lo≈øs of our Souls, as it renders us the mo≈øt incapable Objects of Mercy for the future. For when we are arrived to that Height of Wickedne≈øs as finally to reject Chri≈øt, and the Mercies of his Go≈øpel, there is no farther Mercy that we are capable of; if after this God ≈øhould be ≈øo kind and indulgent as to pardon us, alas! what would it ≈øignify? for we ≈øhould ≈øtill be wretched and mi≈øerable in De≈øpight of his Pardon; and that wicked Temper of Mind which made us reject our Saviour, would be an everlasting Hell to us though it ≈øhould indemnifie us. What will a Pardon avail a Man that is dying of the Stone or Strangury? He can but die if he be not pardoned, and die he mu≈øt though he be.
And as little Advantage it would be to a wicked Soul to be pardoned and ab≈øolved by God, while ≈øhe hath a Di≈øea≈øe within her that preys upon her Vitals, and ha≈øtens her to a certain Ruin. She could have been but mi≈øerable in the future Life if ≈øhe had not been pardoned, and mi≈øerable ≈øhe mu≈øt be if ≈øhe continues wicked, whether ≈øhe be pardoned or no; there being an everlasting Hell in the very Nature of Wickedne≈øs, which no outward Act of Pardon can quench or extingui≈øh. Nay, if after our rejecting Chri≈øt, and the Mercies of the Go≈øpel, God ≈øhould not only pardon, but admit us into Heaven, and indulge us the free Enjoyment of all its Plea≈øures and Felicities; yet that vicious Temper of Mind which finally ≈øeduccd us from our Saviour, would render us for ever incapable of reli≈øhing the Joys of it. Tho≈øe Rivers of Heavenly Plea≈øure would never agree with the helli≈øh Temper of our Minds, which, like a feveri≈øh Tongue, would utterly di≈øgu≈øt their delicious Streams by Rea≈øon of its own overflowing Gall. So that after we have finally rejected our Saviour, we are neither capable of being indemnifyed from Hell, nor of enjoying Heaven; and having ca≈øt our ≈øelves beyond the Reach of all Mercy, into a State wherein we can neither begin to be happy, nor cea≈øe to be mi≈øerable, our Ca≈øe is de≈øperate, and there is no Remedy but our Souls mu≈øt be lo≈øt and undone for ever.

3ly. Our for≈øaking of Chri≈øt infers the everla≈øting Lo≈øs of our Souls, as it is an open Violation of the fixed and ≈øtated Condition of Mercy. The fixed and immoveable Condition of the Mercy of the Go≈øpel is, that we ≈øhould con≈øtantly adhere to our
Saviour by a true Faith and a ≈øincere Obedience, and that whenever we fall off from him either into Infidelity, or Here≈øy, or Di≈øobedience, we ≈øhould remember from whence we are fallen, and return again to him by a deep and ≈øerious Repentance. And indeed this Condition is ≈øo low and conde≈øcending, that it was impo≈ø≈øible for the wi≈øe God and Governour of the World, to propo≈øe his Mercy to us at a lower or ea≈øier Rate; and if God ≈øhould have asked our Con≈øent upon what Conditions he ≈øhould propo≈øe to us the Mercies of his Go≈øpel, this would have been the utmo≈øt Favour that we could in Mode≈øty have craved of him, that he would be ≈øo gracious as to accept our unfeigned Faith and ≈øincere Obedience; and that whenever we fall off either from the one or the other, he would admit us to Repentance, and receive us again upon our Return and Amendment. And ≈øhould he have propo≈øed his Mercy to us upon lower Terms, he mu≈øt of Nece≈ø≈øity have let go the Reins of his Government, and given us a free Toleration for all manner of Wickedne≈øs. Had the Condition of his Mercy been but one ≈øtep lower than Repentance, it had totally di≈ø≈øolved the Obligation of his Laws, and reduced the humane World into a perfect Anarchy. For ≈øhould be have pro≈øtituted his Mercy to impenitent Sinners, he mu≈øt have made it a Refuge for ob≈øtinate Rebels to fly to, and ≈øhelter them≈øelves from the Reach of his Authority; and how incon≈øi≈øtent would this have been with the Wi≈ødom of his Government? This therefore being the lowe≈øt Condition upon which the wi≈øe and holy God can propo≈øe his Mercy to us, there is no Ground to hope that after we have rejected this, and are
finally fallen off from it, he will make any new Propo≈øal to us. For he hath yielded as much already to the Weakne≈øs and Incon≈øtancy of our Natures, as he could po≈ø≈øibly do with ≈øafety to his Government; and if this will not ≈øuffice, we may depend upon it that he will rather con≈øent to ≈øacrifice our Souls to his righteous Vengeance, than his own Authority to our ob≈øtinate Wills. So that when once we have finally rejected our Saviour, and ≈øhaken hands for ever with Faith and Obedience, and Repentance too, we are quite beyond the Reach of any wi≈øe Mercy; and then how deplorable mu≈øt our Condition be, when Things are reduced to this de≈øperate I≈ø≈øue, That God mu≈øt either con≈øent to be fooli≈øhly merciful to us, or to abandon our Souls to everla≈øting Perdition?

4ly. And la≈øtly, Our for≈øaking of Chri≈øt infers the everla≈øting Lo≈øs of our Souls, as it is an utter Rejection of our la≈øt Remedy. For the la≈øt Remedy which God hath prepared for Mankind to heal the Malignity of their Natures, and recover them from eternal Mi≈øery, is the meritorious Death and Sacrifice of his Ble≈ø≈øed Son, who voluntarily undertaking to be the Attorney-General, and Common Repre≈øentative of ≈øinful Men, ≈øuffered Death in our ≈øtead as a vicarious Mulct and Puni≈øhment for our Sins; upon which the mo≈øt merciful Father hath granted to all believing and truly penitent Sinners, a general Indemnity from eternal Puni≈øhments, to which they were bound over by their Sins and Rebellions; by virtue of which Grant as ≈øoon as we believe in Chri≈øt, and do thereupon ≈øincerely Repent of our Sins, we are totally ab≈øolved from tho≈øe everla≈øting Puni≈øhments whereunto they have
expo≈øed and obliged us. And this Sacrifice of Chri≈øt being the la≈øt Remedy which God hath provided for our Guilt, and the Grant of Pardon God hath made in Con≈øideration of it, being confined to believing and penitent Sinners, it hence nece≈ø≈øarily follows, that they who finally per≈øi≈øt in ∆≤nbelief or Impenitency, do thereby for ever cut them≈øelves off from all Intere≈øt in that Sacrifice; and from all Title to that Pardon that is granted upon it, and con≈øequently leave them≈øelves for ever de≈øtitute of all Hope of Pardon and Indemnity for the future. So that by renouncing Christ we do renounce his Sacrifice, which is the la≈øt and only Remedy we have to depend upon. Hence Heb. 10.26. we are told, that if we ≈øin wilfully after we have received the knowledge of the truth, there remaineth no more ≈øacrifice for ≈øin; that is, after we have been Baptized, and Initiated into Chri≈øtianity, we relap≈øe into Infidelity or wilful Di≈øobedience, we do thereby forfeit our Intere≈øt in Chri≈øt's Sacrifice; and when we have once rejected our Intere≈øt in that, there remains no other Sacrifice for Sin, i.e. no other Sacrifice upon which God will Pardon and Indemnify us. So that now all that remains to us, is that which follows in the next Ver≈øe, viz. A certain fearful looking for of judgment, and fiery indignation, which ≈øhall devour the Adver≈øaries. For when we have finally baffled our la≈øt and utmo≈øt Remedy, the Condition of our Souls mu≈øt needs be de≈øperate and incurable. When by our ob≈øtinate Unbelief or final Impenitence we have out-≈øinned the Virtue of our Saviour's Sacrifice, we are out of the Reach and Compa≈øs of God's Pardon, and ≈øo con≈øequently are ≈øunk beyond all
Hopes of Recovery, into endle≈øs and irrever≈øible Damnation. For now that precious Blood which, if we had believed and repented, would have ≈øpoke better things for us than the Blood of Abel, will ri≈øe in Judgment again≈øt us, and, like the Blood of tho≈øe Souls that are under the Altar, will Charge and Impeach, and be continually imprecating the Vengeance of Heaven upon us. And when that which was prepared for the la≈øt and utmost Remedy of our Souls ≈øhall be converted into their Bane, and that which was intended for their Advocate ≈øhall become their Accu≈øer; when that vocal Blood and tho≈øe ≈øpeaking Wounds which pleaded for, ≈øhall plead again≈øt, and cry out in≈øtantly for Judgment upon them; what can they henceforth expect but everla≈øting Ruin and De≈øtruction?

What then remains, that ≈øince our for≈øaking of Chri≈øt will ≈øo infallibly infer the Ruin of our Souls, we all return to, and cleave fa≈øt to our Saviour in our Belief and Obedience: That we, who are fallen off from him into a Cour≈øe of wilful Sin and Di≈øobedience, immediately return again by a deep and ≈øerious Repentance. For the Way in which we are walking leads directly to De≈øtruction; every Step of it is a De≈øcent into Hell, and next to the lowermo≈øt is the bottomle≈øs Pit, and for all we know, the very la≈øt Step we took brought us to the Brinks of the flaming Aby≈øs; and if it did, one Step further will ≈øet us beyond all Hope of Recovery. For in our ≈øinful Progre≈øs we are wading forwards in a ≈øhelving Pool, which the farther we go, the deeper it is, and ≈øo deeper and deeper till we come to the Bottom of it; ≈øo that at every
Step we are in Danger of going beyond our Depth, and plunging our ≈øelves into in irrecoverable Ruin; for we know not how ≈øoon we may be ≈ønatched away in our Iniquities; and if it ≈øhould ≈øo happen, that after we have ≈øinned this Moment, we ≈øhould die the next, this will determine our everla≈øting Fate, and ≈øink us into eternal Mi≈øery.

Wherefore as we tender the ≈øafety of our precious Souls, let us ≈øpeedily for≈øake this dangerous Road in which Perdition way-lays, and Hell gapes to devour us every ≈øtep we go; and return unto our Lord in whom our ≈øafety lyes. As yet the Opportunity of Salvation is in our Hands, but before to morrow Morning it may ≈ølip away from between our Fingers, and vani≈øh for ever, and we that are this day wallowing in our Sins, may before the next be roaring in Hell. So that while we defer and put off our Repentance from day to day, we do as it were ca≈øt Lots for our Souls, and venture our everla≈øting Hopes upon a Contingency, that is not in our Power to di≈øpo≈øe of. As yet the Gate of Mercy is open to us, and our ble≈ø≈øed Lord ≈øtands ready with his Arms out-≈øtretched to welcome and receive us; but for all we know if we enter not pre≈øently, the Gate may be ≈øhut within a few Moments, and then though we knock and cry till our hearts ake, Lord, Lord open to us, we ≈øhall receive no other An≈øwer, but Depart from me I know you not. O Good God, how are we be≈øotted then, that rather than begin our Repentance to day we will wilfully run the Hazard of being eternally mi≈øerable before to morrow Morning! For if this ≈øhould be the Evening of our day of
Tryal, as for all we know it may, our Life and Eternity depends upon what we are now doing; and therefore one would think it ≈øhould highly concern us wi≈øely to manage this la≈øt ≈øtake, the winning, or lo≈øing whereof may prove our making or undoing. In pity therefore to our per≈øhing Souls let us return to our Saviour, before it be too late, before our Feet ≈øtumble on the dark Mountains, and we fall down into everla≈øting Darkne≈øs. And being returned and re-united to him, let us have a Care we do not revolt again; for if we draw back we cancel our Repentance, and forfeit all its ble≈øed Fruits and Benefits; and unle≈øs we ≈øtedfa≈øtly per≈øevere and hold out to the end, all the Pains we have taken in our Chri≈øtian Cour≈øe will be for ever lo≈øt, and the Remembrance of it will only admini≈øter to our future Mi≈øery. For how will it vex us in the other World to con≈øider the Labour it co≈øt us to take Heaven by Storm? How vigorou≈øly we ≈øtrove to mount the Scaling Ladder, through how many Difficulties we had forced our way to that height of Vertue and Religion we were arrived to, and then when we are got as it were to the topmo≈øt Rounds, and had laid our Hands upon the Battlements of Heaven, ju≈øt ready to leap in and take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all its Joys; how ba≈øely we let go our Hold, and ≈øo tumbled down from that ≈øtupendious height into the bottomle≈øs Aby≈øs of endle≈øs Mi≈øery? Doubtle≈øs this Con≈øideration mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily ≈øting our woful Souls hereafter, and for ever inrage them again≈øt them≈øelves. Wherefore as we value the Safety of our precious Souls, let us, who by our wilful Rebellions have gone a≈øtray, return, and con≈øtantly adhere
to our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour. Alas, where can we be happier than in his Service, who impo≈øeth nothing on us but what contributes to our Welfare? Where can we be ≈øafer than in his Arms, and under his Protection, who hath the Command and Di≈øpo≈øal of all Events, and to whom all Power is given in Heaven and Earth? Where can we be placed more to our own Advantage than under his Guidance and Authority, who never permits any to ≈øerve him for nought, but hath engaged him≈øelf to recompence our Labour with a Crown of Glory that fades not away? And is it not ≈øtrange that after ≈øo many advantagious Invitations, we ≈øhould need to be ≈øcared to our Duty? that after our ble≈ø≈øed Ma≈øter hath enjoyned us ≈øuch a rea≈øonable, gnetle, and infinitely beneficial Service, he ≈øhould be forced to terrify us into it with the Flames of Hell?

IV. I proceed now to the Fourth Propo≈øition, That when the Soul is lo≈øt, 'tis lo≈øt irrecoverably; where the Greek word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which we render Exchange, is u≈øed in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe with „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which ≈øignifies a Price of Redemption, denoting that when once a Man hath ≈øold his Soul to Perdition, it is unredeemable, and that no Price will be accepted for its Ran≈øom and Deliverance; when a Man's Soul is in Hell under the wretched Bondage of a Damned Spirit, how little ≈øoever he regards it now, he would give all the World, if it were in his power, to be relea≈øed again; but if he had a thou≈øand Worlds it will not do, his bondage being ≈øuch as will admit no Ran≈øom. For the≈øe Words of our Saviour ≈øeem to
have been a common Proverb of the Age he lived in, and that derived from tho≈øe words of the Devil in Job, All that a Man hath, will he give for his Life; that is, when a Man is dying, he would willingly part with all to redeem his Life, but all will not do. Which Proverb our Saviour adapts to his own Argument, in which he proceeds from temporal to eternal Life: If a Man would give ≈øo much for his temporal Life, what would he not give for his eternal one? But as our temporal Life is not to be redeemed, ≈øo neither is our eternal one when once it is lo≈øt; for when once our Soul is lo≈øt or abandoned to the State of the Damned, it is lost for ever, and there is no „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or Ran≈øom that will be accepted of by God for its Redemption thence. In the Pro≈øecution of which Argument I ≈øhall endeavour the≈øe two things.

1. To ≈øhew you that if God be ≈øo determined he may, without any Injury either to his Ju≈øtice or Goodne≈øs, detain lo≈øt Souls in the Bondage of Hell for ever, and ab≈øolutely refu≈øe to accept any Ran≈øom for them.
2. That he is actually determined ≈øo to do.

1. That if God be ≈øo determined, he may without any Injury either to his Ju≈øtice or Goodne≈øs, detain lost Souls in the Bondage of Hell for ever, without accepting any Ran≈øom for them. And this I doubt not will plainly appear upon the due Con≈øideration of the≈øe following Propo≈øitions.

list.item: 1≈øt. That God being the Soveraign Being of the World, hath an unalienable Right to impo≈øe Laws upon all other Beings.
2dly. That having this Right, he may ju≈øtly inforce tho≈øe Laws with what≈øoever Penalties he ≈øees nece≈ø≈øary or convenient.
3dly. That when tho≈øe Laws he impo≈øes are for the good of his Subjects, it is not only Ju≈øtice but Goodne≈øs in him to inforce them with the ≈øevere≈øt Penalty.
4thly. That the Penalty of eternal Bondage under Mi≈øery, is the ≈øevere≈øt and mo≈øt effectual Way to inforce tho≈øe beneficial Laws, and oblige us to the Ob≈øervance of them.
5thly. That if God think good to inforce his Laws with this Penalty, he hath as much Right to exact it when we di≈øobey, as he had to threaten and impo≈øe it.
