div.p:
1. that God being the Sovereign Being of the World, hath an unalienable Right to impo≈øe Laws upon all other Beings. For he being the greate≈øt and mo≈øt powerful Being, can him≈øelf be ≈øubject to no other Law but only that of his own Nature; and his Power being infinite and unconfined as well as his Wi≈ødom, Ju≈øtice, and Goodne≈øs, doth ≈øufficiently warrant him to do what≈øoever is con≈øi≈øtent with them. For to be ≈øure a Being of infinite Power and Greatne≈øs, can have no Superiour, but mu≈øt be nece≈ø≈øarily exalted above all other Authorities by this incommunicable Prerogative of his Nature; and being rai≈øed above all Authorities, he mu≈øt have Authority above all, and his e≈ø≈øential Dominion having no other Law to bound it, but only that of his own Nature, he mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily have
a Right to command what≈øoever is con≈øi≈øtent with his Wi≈ødom, Ju≈øtice, and Goodne≈øs. His Will therefore being by the infinite Pre-eminence of his Power and Greatne≈øs ≈øupreme, all other Wills are obliged to bow before, and pro≈øtrate them≈øelves to its Sovereign Authority; and there is no Law what≈øoever but he may ju≈øtly impo≈øe upon them, provided it be not repugnant to that ≈øupreme Law that is founded in his own Nature. This therefore being premi≈øed, that God hath a Right as he is the Sovereign Being to give Laws to all other Beings; it hence follows,

2dly. That he may ju≈øtly inforce tho≈øe Laws with what≈øoever Penalties he ≈øees nece≈ø≈øary or convenient. For Laws without penalties are rather Petitions than Commands; and unle≈øs they carry force enough with them to over-aw the subject, and make them≈øelves obeyed, they want the formal Sanction and Obligation of a Law. To have a Power therefore of impo≈øing Penalties mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be in≈øeparable from the Power of making Laws, becau≈øe they are the Penalties that make the Laws to oblige, that give them Power to command, and inforce them with an awful Authority. And as the Power of giving Laws ≈øuppo≈øes the Power of impo≈øing Penalties, ≈øo it ≈øuppo≈øes a Power of impo≈øing ≈øuch Penalties as may be ≈øufficient to incline and aw the Subject into Obedience, again≈øt all Rea≈øons to the contrary. For unle≈øs the Penalty be great enough to outweigh all other Con≈øiderations, the Law which it inforces will be extreamly defective in Point of Obligation, and leave the Subject as much rea≈øon to di≈øobey as to obey. God therefore being by his own natural
Right the Supreme Lawgiver of the World, mu≈øt be ≈øuppo≈øed to have an equal Right of inforcing his Laws with ≈øuch Penalties as in his own infinite Wi≈ødom he ≈øhall think nece≈ø≈øary to oblige his Greatures to obey him; and there is no Penalty can be too rigorous or ≈øevere which is nece≈ø≈øary to inable his Laws to oblige and command us. Wherefore according as he ≈øees his Subjects more or le≈øs tempted, or inclined to di≈øobey him, ≈øo will he need greater or le≈øs Penalties to oblige us to Obedience; and therefore fore≈øeeing what a ≈øtrong Propen≈øity to Evil there would be in our Nature, and with what importunate Temptations this would be excited and wrought upon, he could not but fore≈øee that the ≈øevere≈øt Penalties would be nece≈ø≈øary to back and inforce his Laws, and being nece≈ø≈øary for that end, he mu≈øt needs have a Right to impo≈øe them, how ≈øevere ≈øoever they might be; nor is this ≈øeverity le≈øs good than it is ju≈øt; con≈øidering.

3dly. That when tho≈øe Laws he impo≈øes are for the good of his Subjects, it is not only an Act of Ju≈øtice in him to impo≈øe them with the ≈øevere≈øt Penalties, but of Goodne≈øs. And this is really the Ca≈øe as to tho≈øe Laws which God hath impo≈øed upon us; for the Matter of them all is ≈øomething tending to our good, ≈øomething or other that is perfective of our Natures, and conducive to our Happine≈øs; and being ≈øo, the greater the Penalty is which they are backt and inforced with, the greater Demon≈øtration it is of God's Care and Zeal for our Happine≈øs. For the End of Penalty is to oblige us to Obedience; and when all Obedience is for our good, the more ≈øtrictly he obliges
us to it, the more he befriends us. When a di≈øtracted Man is endeavouring to mi≈øchief and de≈øtroy him≈øelf, it is Kingne≈øs to bind him though it be with Chains of Iron. When therefore God found us ≈øo prone to injure our ≈øelves by wicked and mi≈øchievous Actions, it was Mercy to bind our Hands with his Threatnings of Puni≈øhment; and the ≈øtronger his Bands are, the more they expre≈øs his Kindne≈øs; becau≈øe the more they oblige us to be kind to our ≈øelves, and true to our own Intere≈øt. And certainly for God to lay us under the ≈øtronge≈øt Obligations to be happy, is ≈øo far from being a Blemi≈øh to his Goodne≈øs, that it is a mo≈øt glorious Expre≈ø≈øion of it; but if we will be ≈øo ob≈øtinate as to run into the mouth of tho≈øe Threatnings which he hath levelled again≈øt us to ≈øcare us into Happine≈øs, it is ju≈øt with him to di≈øcharge them upon us, and make us feel the E≈ø≈øects of our Folly and Madne≈øs. Since therefore the Rea≈øon of the Penalty wherewith God hath inforced his Laws, is to oblige us to be happy; and ≈øince the greater it is, the more force it mu≈øt have to oblige us, it hence nece≈ø≈øarily follows, that though it be not only a great, but an eternal one; yet it is not at all incon≈øi≈øtent with his Goodne≈øs; e≈øpecially if we con≈øider,

4thly. That the Penalty of eternal Mi≈øery, as it is the ≈øevere≈øt, ≈øo it is the mo≈øt effectual to inforce tho≈øe beneficial Laws which God hath impo≈øed on us, and to oblige us to the Ob≈øervance of them. For to deter us from Sin, who are ≈øo vehemently prone to it, it was very requi≈øite that the Penalty denounced again≈øt it, ≈øhould not only be great as to the Degree, but endle≈øs al≈øo as to the
Duration of it; that ≈øo it might cut us off from all pretence of Pre≈øumption, and leave us no ground of Incouragement to be wicked. For we are exceeding apt to ≈ølight and undervalue tho≈øe Evils which are propo≈øed to deter us from the Goods which we vehemently de≈øire, e≈øpecially when the≈øe Goods are pre≈øent and ≈øen≈øible, and tho≈øe Evils future and invi≈øible. For thus we conclude, the Good that is before us we may injoy a great while; and, which is very con≈øiderable, we may pre≈øently enter upon the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it; but as for the Evil that is con≈øequent to it, it may be a long while before it befalls us; and when it doth, there is this Comfort, that it will at la≈øt have an end; and therefore let what will follow, let us ever ≈øeize the pre≈øent Good, and make the be≈øt u≈øe we can of it; and as for the future Evil, whenever it happens, the Pro≈øpect of its End, though it be never ≈øo remote, will enable us to bear it more chearfully. For ten Years pre≈øent Plea≈øure vehemently de≈øired, will far more effectually per≈øuade us, than a future Mi≈øery of double the Duration; and therefore if the future Penalty denounced again≈øt our Sin were finite and temporary, it would not be ≈øufficient to ballance tho≈øe pre≈øent Plea≈øures with which we are continually importuned and ≈øolicited; for the Penalty being propo≈øed to deter us from Plea≈øures which we dearly love, we are upon that account inclined to make as light of it as may be, and to flatter our ≈øelves with the ≈øofte≈øt and ea≈øie≈øt Repre≈øentations of it; ≈øo that to be ≈øure if there were any one comfortable Circum≈øtance in it, our Thoughts would pre≈øently in≈øi≈øt upon that, and urge it as a Rea≈øon why we ≈øhould
not be afraid of it. So that if the Penalty of our Sin had in it but the Circum≈øtance of being finite, to be ≈øure when ever it controuled our vicious De≈øires, we ≈øhould ≈øtill make this a Pretence to de≈øpi≈øe it; Well, let it be never ≈øo terrible, it will have an end. Wherefore to inable it to terrify us effectually, it was requi≈øite that it ≈øhould not only be great, but endle≈øs; that it being ≈øtripped of all tolerable Circum≈øtances, we might be able to find nothing in it to qualify the Terror of it. But now it being not only great but eternal, the Threat of it, which, like a Cloud, hangs lowering over us, hath no bright ≈øide to divert our Thoughts from the Blackne≈øs and Horror of it; ≈øo that whenever we think of it, and weigh it in the Ballance with our Sins, we mu≈øt re≈øolve to for≈øake them, or chu≈øe to be de≈øperate. Since therefore an eternal penalty was ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to inforce God's Law; and ≈øince his Law is for our good, it is plain that his ≈øo inforcing it can blemi≈øh neither his Ju≈øtice nor Goodne≈øs. Wherefore though we ≈øhould ≈ømart for ever for our Di≈øobedience hereafter, we can have no ju≈øt Rea≈øon to complain, of God; e≈øpecially con≈øidering,

5thly. That if God ≈øhall think good to inforce his Law with ≈øuch an eternal Penalty, he mu≈øt be ≈øuppo≈øed to have as much Right to exact it upon our Di≈øobedience, as he had to threaten and impo≈øe it. For as Supremacy over all other Beings gives a Right to make Laws, and inforce them with Threatnings of Puni≈øhment; ≈øo when he hath actually impo≈øed Laws upon us, our Di≈øobedience to them gives a Right to inflict on us the Puni≈øhments which he threatned when he impo≈øed them. For
in all legal Funi≈øhments the Right of Threatning them is founded on the Power of the Soveraign; but the Right of executing them in the Di≈øobedience of the Subject; and if the Penalty be ≈øuch, as that upon the Subjects Di≈øobedience the Sovereign cannot ju≈øtly execute it, it was unjust for him to threaten it; for to threaten legally, is to claim a Right to puni≈øh upon Condition the Law be broken and violated; and that Soveraign who upon Condition of the Subjects Di≈øobedience, claims a Right to mcre Puni≈øhment than he can ju≈øtly exact of him when he di≈øobeys, pretends to more Right than he really hath, and ≈øo by con≈øequence his Claim is unrightcous. If therefore by the Threat of his Law God may ju≈øtly claim a Right to puni≈øh us for ever if we di≈øobey, then doubtle≈øs when we have actually di≈øobeyed, he may as ju≈øtly exact it, and doth no more exceed his Right when he inflicts what he threatned, than he did when he threatned to inflict it. If he had Right to ≈øay, I will puni≈øh you for ever upon Condition you tran≈øgre≈øs my Laws, then upon our performing that Condition he mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily have Right to do as he ≈øaid. So that our tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing his Law being a ≈øufficient Condition for him to found a rightful Claim to puni≈øh us eternally, by our doing this Condition we ju≈øtly forfeit our ≈øelves to eternal Puni≈øhment, and by our own Act and Deed voluntarily re≈øign up our precious Souls to the ju≈øt la≈øh of an everla≈øting Vengeance; which as the Justice of God is no way obliged to ≈øu≈øpend, ≈øo neither is his Goodne≈øs, which now is our only Re≈øerve; con≈øidering.

6thly. And la≈øtly, That God's exacting this eternal Penalty of us can no more impeach his Goodne≈øs than his threatning and denouncing it. That it is highly con≈øi≈øtent with his Goodne≈øs to threaten it, I have already proved; but if it were not al≈øo con≈øi≈øtent therewith to inflict it, to be ≈øure his own Wi≈ødom would never admit him to threaten it. For to what end ≈øhould he threaten to act contrary to the Goodne≈øs of his Nature? Either he mu≈øt de≈øign to make us believe that he intends to act, or not; if the first, he mu≈øt thereby de≈øign to abu≈øe, and mi≈ørepre≈øent him≈øelf in the Opinion of his Creatures, to blemi≈øh the Reputation, and expo≈øe the Honour of his own infinite Goodne≈øs. But if he did not de≈øign to make us believe it, to what end ≈øhould he threaten it, ≈øince unle≈øs we believe it, it can no more affect us than the firing of a Gun that is charged with nothing but Powder, and was de≈øigned to make a noi≈øe only, but to do no Execution? So that if it be repugnant to God's Goodne≈øs to execute this Penalty, it mu≈øt be repugnant to his Wi≈ødom to denounce it; but it being not only con≈øistent with, but an Expre≈ø≈øion of his Goodne≈øs to denounce it, when he de≈øigns thereby to oblige us more firmly to our Duty, in which our everla≈øting Happine≈øs is included, it may be no le≈øs an Expre≈ø≈øion of the ≈øame Goodne≈øs to execute it upon us, when we by our ob≈øtinate Per≈øi≈øtance in Sin have render'd our ≈øelves incapable of Mercy. For now there being no more good to be done upon us, it will be an Act of Goodne≈øs in God to puni≈øh us for ever, if thereby any good may be done to others by us; if by making us everla≈øting Monuments of his ju≈øt Indignation, he can everla≈øtingly
warn and ≈øecure others from tho≈øe de≈øperate Cour≈øes that ruined us. For in this Ca≈øe his puni≈øhing us for ever, may be an effectual means to do that good to others which he intended to do to us by threatning to puni≈øh us for ever, and they may take warning by our Puni≈øhment, though we would take none by his Threatning. And when by being ob≈øtinately deaf to the Threat of eternal Perdition, which God denounced on purpo≈øe to oblige us to be happy, we have not only forfeited our ≈øelves to it, but have al≈øo ≈øinned our ≈øelves into an Incapacity of having any good done upon us; the only U≈øe which the Divine goodne≈øs can make of us for the future, is to do good to others by us; which it can no otherwi≈øe do, but by making our everlasting Suffering an everla≈øting Example for them to take warning by. For though there is no doubt but every virtuous Soul ≈øhall be hereafter ≈øo confirmed in its ≈øtate of Beatitude, as that it ≈øhall never fall from it, yet ≈øhall it be confirmed no otherwi≈øe than by the force of tho≈øe Rea≈øons and invincible Motives which ≈øhall then continually urge, and immoveably determine it unto that which is good: One of which Rea≈øons, as we may rea≈øonably ≈øuppo≈øe, will be their pro≈øpect of the endle≈øs Mi≈øeries of the Damned, which will be an everla≈øting Monitor to them, and together with their own fen≈øe of the ravi≈øhing Plea≈øures of Goodne≈øs, will ≈øecure them for ever from falling. For if the Angels of Heaven took warning by the Fall and Ruin of their Apo≈øtate Brethren, as doubtle≈øs they did, and thereupon became more immovably confirmed in Innocence and Goodne≈øs; why may we not as well ≈øuppo≈øe, that one of
tho≈øe Rea≈øons b which the Spirits of ju≈øt Men are ≈øo immovably confirmed in their Heavenly State, is the ≈øad Example of the endle≈øs Mi≈øeries of the Wicked? If therefore when God hath denounced eternal Mi≈øery again≈øt us on purpo≈øe to threaten us into Happine≈øs, we will take no warning it is an Act of Goodne≈øs in him to inflict it upon us, ≈øince thereby he may ≈øo effectually contribute to the confirming of others in eternal Happine≈øs. For if we will not be wrought on by ≈øuch a dreadful Denunciation there is no good can be done upon us; and when we are pa≈øt Recovery, and are forfeited by our own Ob≈øtinacy into the hands of God's Vengeance, it will be an Act of Goodne≈øs in him ≈øo to di≈øpo≈øe of us as may be mo≈øt for the good of others, and con≈øequently to di≈øpo≈øe of us to eternal Mi≈øery, and by ≈øo doing to make u≈øe of us as Arguments to confirm and e≈øtabli≈øh othes in eternal Happine≈øs; that ≈øo our Sufferings may be to them what hs Threatnings were to us, Arguments to oblige us to be happy for ever. And ≈øo I have done with the Fir≈øt Thing propos'd, which was to ≈øhew you that if God be ≈øo determined, he may, without any Injury either to his Ju≈øtice or Goodne≈øs, retain lo≈øt Souls in the Bondage of Hell for ever, and ab≈øolutely refu≈øe to accept any Ran≈øom for them.
I now proceed to the Second Head of Di≈øcour≈øe, namely, to prove that God is actually determined ≈øo to do. And this I ≈øhall endeavour to demon≈øtrate by the≈øe three Rea≈øons.

list.item:
1. Becau≈øe he hath already exacted a Ran≈øom for the Souls of Men, to which no other can
be equivalent; from whence we may rea≈øonably infer, that if this be rejected he will accept no other.
2. Becau≈øe he hath expre≈øly declared him≈øelf to be thus determined.
3. Becau≈øe having thus declared him≈øelf, we mu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe that either he intended this Declaration only for a Scare-crow, or that he is determined to act accordingly.

div.p:
2dly. That God is really determined to conclude lost Souls under endle≈øs Mi≈øery, and admit no Ran≈øom for them, appears al≈øo from hence, Becau≈øe he hath expre≈øly declared him≈øelf to be ≈øo determined. For ≈øo our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour, who was the great Me≈ø≈øenger of his Will to the World, hath expre≈øly told us, that the final Sentence of the Wicked ≈øhall be to everla≈øting Fire, Matth. 25.41. and that the Fate of ob≈øtinate Sinners, whom he compares to Chaff, ≈øhall be to be burned up with unquenchable fire. But perhaps you may object, that the≈øe Texts only prove the Everla≈øtingne≈øs of the Fire in which they ≈øhall ≈øuffer, and not their everla≈øting Suffering in it; for this Fire perhaps may immediately con≈øume, and utterly de≈øtroy them, and render them in≈øen≈øible of Mi≈øery for ever. To which I an≈øwer, That the contrary is mo≈øt evident; for they are expre≈øly ≈øaid to live in this Fire, and to perform the Functions of living Beings in Mi≈øery; to weep and wail, and gna≈øh
their teeth, Matth. 13.42. and in the Parable of Dives, he is ≈øaid to life up his eyes in Hell, being in torments, and to ≈øee Abraham afar off, and Lazarus in his bo≈øom; and to cry out to Abraham, Father Abraham have mercy on me, and ≈øend Lazarus, that he may dip the top of his finger in water, and cool my tongue, for I am tormented in this flame, Luke 16.23. ‚Äî A plain Evidence that this Fire is to torment and not to con≈øume them. Well, but this you will ≈øav imports no more than their being tortured in hell for ≈øome period of Time, after which, it may be, they may cea≈øe to be, and con≈øequently to be mi≈øerable. To which I an≈øwer, That el≈øewhere it is expre≈øly a≈ø≈øerted, that this Torture is to endure for ever; for the≈øe, ≈øaith our Saviour, ≈øpeaking of the Wicked, ≈øhall go away into everla≈øting Puni≈øhment, Matth. 25.46. And how can their Puni≈øhment be everla≈øting, unle≈øs we ≈øuppo≈øe them to ≈øub≈øi≈øt everla≈øtingly in it? If you ≈øay it is everla≈øting, only as it is an everla≈øting De≈øtruction, or Privation of their Being: I an≈øwer, That in other Places of Scripture it is expre≈øly a≈ø≈øerted, that this everla≈øting puni≈øhment is a po≈øitive thing; for it is ≈øaid to be a Worm that never dieth, Mark 9.44. that is, that to all Eternity lives and preys upon the wretched Sufferers; and more expre≈øly yet, Revel. 20.10. tho≈øe that are ca≈øt into the lake of fire and brimstone, are ≈øaid to be tormented there day and night for ever and ever: Where the Greek word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ doth plainly denote po≈øitive Torment, and referring peculiarly to a Rack, denotes the kind of this po≈øitive Torment to be ≈øuch as is not de≈øigned to put an end to our Lives, but to continue them with inexpre≈ø≈øible
Pains. For this we know is the proper U≈øe and De≈øign of a Rack; and accordingly upon this tormenting Rack of Hielli≈øh Puni≈øhment they are ≈øaid to have no re≈øt day nor night, Rev. 14.11. So that the eternal Mi≈øery of lo≈øt Souls is as fully and expre≈øly a≈ø≈øerted in Scripture, as it could well have been, had it been expre≈ø≈øed with a De≈øign to leave no pretence of Exception for Gain≈øayers; and when a thing is as plainly a≈ø≈øerted to be as it could well have been if it really were, either we mu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe the Thing to be, or el≈øe the A≈ø≈øertion to be fallacious. So that if we think that God's own Word doth truly ≈øignify his Determination, we mu≈øt from hence be forced to conclude, that he is really determined to ≈øhut up lo≈øt Souls in eternal Mi≈øery, and admit no Ran≈øom for them.

3dly. And la≈øtly, This al≈øo appears, becau≈øe if after he hath thus declared him≈øelf, there were any Rea≈øon to think that he is not determined to act accordingly, that Rea≈øon would warrant us to believe that this Declaration was only intended for a Scare-crow, and con≈øequently to contemn and de≈øpi≈øe it. And yet, God knows, the≈øe Plca≈øures are not comparably ≈øo di≈øproportionate to tho≈øe Pains, as the Plea≈øures of this World are to the Pains of Eternity. How then is it po≈ø≈øible that ≈øuch Batter≈øweets as the the≈øe are, Sweets that are chequered with ≈øo many Cares, and allayed with ≈øo many Di≈øcontents, and Di≈øappointments, ≈øhould be ≈øufficient to countervail tho≈øe intolerable Mi≈øeries which the Lo≈øs of our Souls implies?

5thly. The Good that is in the Gain of this World is full of Intermi≈ø≈øions; but the Evil that is in the Lo≈øs of a Soul is continual. If I were Lord of all the World, I ≈øhould never be able to live in a con≈øtant Injoyment of it. For ≈øuch wretched Counterfeits are all the Plea≈øures of Sen≈øe, that they will not indure the Te≈øt of a long Fruition; for at the be≈øt they are but Frolicks of Delight that never ≈øerze us but when we are turned up to them in Moods and Fits, and all the Complacencies we have in them are nothing but the little Starts of our Appetite, which, as ≈øoon as it hath done craving, grows a meary of them, and ≈øo injoys and loaths them by Turns; for they can dwell no longer upon the Appetite than while the Nece≈ø≈øities of Nature do continue; and every fre≈øh Mor≈øel after the Hunger is ≈øatisfied, is but a new Labour to a tired Dige≈øtion, and ≈øo in≈øtead of being a Plea≈øure becomes an Oppre≈ø≈øion. So that it is but a very little while that the Plea≈øure of any outward Injoyment continues; for till it hath plea≈øed us it is not a Plea≈øure, and when it hath, it cea≈øes to be ≈øo; and ≈øo it dies as ≈øoon as it is born, and its Nativity is only a Prelude to its Funeral. Thus all our Injoyments are ≈øtinted by our Appetites, which are naturally incapable of a continued Fruition. But then be≈øides this, our Injoyments are liable to a thou≈øand other Interruptions, which are are not in our power to prevent or avoid; for whether we will or no, we mu≈øt be ≈øome times out of Humour, and then all the Plea≈øures in the World are mo≈øt tedious Impertinencies; and ≈øome times we mu≈øt ≈øleep, and then we are in≈øen≈øible of them; and ≈øometimes be ≈øick, and then they are as ta≈øtle≈øs as
a Cork; and ≈øometimes be griped with guilty Thoughts, and ill-aboding Reflections, and then, in≈øtead of Plea≈øures, they are our Horrors and Vexations. Thus our Injoyment, like an Ague, is full of Intermi≈ø≈øions; now we are plea≈øed, and anon we are di≈øplea≈øed, and immediately after the hot Fit is over, the cold One returns; and thus it would be if we had all the World in our Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. And indeed the Intervals of our Injoyment of the≈øe Terre≈øtrial Goods are u≈øually longer than the Injoyment it ≈øelf, and the hot Fits of our Plea≈øure and Fruition are generally ≈øooner over, than tho≈øe cold Ones of Di≈øplea≈øure and Di≈ø≈øatisfaction that ≈øucceed them. So that if I could command all the Goods in the World, they would be ≈øo far from yielding me a continued Happine≈øs, that in all Probability the Interruptions of my Happine≈øs would take up a greater Part of my Life than the Injoyment of it; and perhaps for every one moment of Fruition, I ≈øhould ≈øpend two either in Pain, or in Non-perception of Plea≈øure. How then is it po≈ø≈øible that ≈øuch a broken and di≈øcontinued Happine≈øs as this ≈øhould ever make us amends for tho≈øe Mi≈øeries that are included in the Lo≈øs of our Souls? For to lo≈øs our Souls is to be mi≈øerable without any Interruption, to be eternally grieved and tortured without any Intervals of Ea≈øe or Refre≈øhment. For the State of Perdition is a continual Torment ≈øpun out into an endle≈øs Duration, wherein there are no Days of Rest, nor Nights of Sleep, nor intermeditae Pau≈øes of Ea≈øe; where the Fire never cea≈øes burning, nor the Worm gnawing, but Wo ≈øucceeds Wo without Intermi≈ø≈øion, and Mi≈øeries, like the nimble Minutes of Time, follow Mi≈øeries,
and tread clo≈øe upon one anothers Heels. Hence, Rev. 20.10. tho≈øe that aee ca≈øt into this Lake of Perdition, are ≈øaid to be tormented day and night for ever; which plainly implies that their Mi≈øeries are all but one uninterrupted Torment, or continued Succe≈ø≈øion of dolorous Perceptions for ever. And if ≈øo, O ble≈ø≈øed God, what a poor Compen≈øation for it are the broken Joys of this World? For if the Mi≈øery of Hell were to la≈øt no longer than the Happine≈øs of this World, yet if for one Week's Happine≈øs here I were to indure another Week's Mi≈øery there, I ≈øhould have a mi≈øerable Bargain of it; becau≈øe the Happine≈øs being ≈øo interrupted, and the Mi≈øery ≈øo continued, I mu≈øt in the ≈øame ≈øpace undergo at lea≈øt double the Mi≈øery that I injoyed Happine≈øs. And what Man would be contented to live all the next Week in a Cauldron of boyling Oyl, wherein he knows he ≈øhall be continually tormented, provided he may ≈øpend this Week in an uninterrupted Injoyment of the mo≈øt grateful Luxuries, which he knows he mu≈øt be as often and as long in≈øen≈øible as he can be ≈øen≈øible of?

6thly. And la≈øtly, The Good that is in the Gain of this World is fading and tran≈øitory; but the Evil that is in the Lo≈øs of the Soul is eternal. For ≈øo impotent are all this World's Goods, that they cannot in≈øure us of oue moment's Injoyment of them. it may be as ≈øoon as ever we have filled our Bags and Barns with the Wages of our Iniquity, and have a plentiful Provi≈øion for many Years Ea≈øe and Luxury, we may be ≈ønatched away upon the very Brinks of Injoyment, and hurried into a woful Eternity, there to con≈øume tho≈øe Years in Mi≈øery and Torment,
which we promi≈øed to ≈øpend in Plea≈øure and Voluptuou≈øne≈øs. This you know was the Ca≈øe of the rich Epicure in the Go≈øpel; how did the jolly Wretch congratulate and applaud him≈øelf in the golden Purcha≈øe of his Frauds and Oppre≈ø≈øions? How did he vaunt of his own Prudence, and good Conduct, and ≈øtrut and ≈øwell with munificent Conceits of the happy Condition he was now arrived to, when all of a ≈øudden his unprepared Soul was ≈øurprized with a Summons to Eternity? And then how blank did the Fool look upon the fatal News, that that Night mu≈øt put an End to all his Hopes and Plea≈øures, and deprive him of all tho≈øe future Injoyments with which he had promi≈øed to recompence all his pa≈øt Toils and Labours? With what Regret and Reluctancy was he dragg'd from the dear Purcha≈øe of his Sweat and Sin? and in what Agonies of Horror did he groan out his wretched Spirit, when in≈øtead of injoying the Goods he had laid up for many Years, he felt him≈øelf ≈øinking into a woful Eternity, and lie weltring there in unquenchable Flames, whil≈øt he hoped to have been wallowing here in Ea≈øe and Voluptuou≈øne≈øs? But ≈øuppo≈øe we ≈øhould injoy the many Years Ea≈øe which this vainglorious Fool was di≈øappointed of; alas tho≈øe Years will quickly expire, and Three≈øcore and ten, or Four≈øcore at mo≈øt, is the utmo≈øt Period we can hope to arrive to; but then from thence commences an Eternity of Mi≈øery which Millions of Millions of Ages can neither ≈øhrink nor exhau≈øt, and compared with the longe≈øt Life of Plea≈øure hath not the Proportion of one ≈øingle moment. So that if in Exchange for our Souls we could purcha≈øe a Lea≈øe of Life as long as Methu≈øelah's, and a Lea≈øe of Happine≈øs
parallel to that Life, yet in the Conclu≈øion we ≈øhould find it a mo≈øt woful Bargain; becau≈øe when both the≈øe Lea≈øes are expired, as they mu≈øt at la≈øt though it be long fir≈øt, we mu≈øt remove into a State of intolerable Mi≈øery, who≈øe Duration will be always equally becau≈øe it will be always infinitely di≈øtant from a Period; and when we are there, all that long Train of Happine≈øs that is pa≈øt will ≈øeem but a Minute's Dream in Compari≈øon of that Eternity of Mi≈øery that is to come. But O good God, when for thirty or forty Years Plea≈øure upon Earth, I have ≈øuffered a thou≈øand Years Torment in Hell, and after that have endle≈øs Thou≈øands of Thou≈øands more to ≈øuffer, how dearly ≈øhall I rue my own Folly and Madne≈øs, that for the ≈øake of a few Moments Plea≈øure have run my ≈øelf headlong into ≈øuch an endle≈øs Mi≈øery! Con≈øider therefore, O my Soul! within a little while all the≈øe outward Goods which I have purcha≈øed by my Sin, will ≈øignify no more to me than if they had never been, and all their alluring Reli≈øhes will be gone and forgotten for ever; but then for Ten thou≈øand Millions of Ages after I ≈øhall be feeling the Smart, and enduring the Stings of them. When all my ill-gotten Wealth is ≈øhrunk into a Winding-≈øheet, and my va≈øt Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions into ≈øix foot of Earth, and I have none of its Pomps or Plea≈øures left either to go along with, or to follow after me, then will the Guilt of all ≈øtick clo≈øe to me, and rai≈øe a Cry on me as high as the Tribunal of God; a Cry that will draw down an everla≈øting Vengeance on my Head, and ring Peals of Thunder in my Con≈øcience for ever. Lord! what a poor Amends then is the momentary Injoyments of the Goods of this World to me, and that after a few
Years mu≈øt pa≈øs into another, and there langui≈øh away a long Eternity under the intolerable Angui≈øh of a damned Spirit.

And thus you ≈øee, upon a ju≈øt Survey of the Gains of this world, and the Lo≈øs of a Soul, how infinitely ≈øhort the Happine≈øs of the one is to make us any tolerable Compen≈øation for the Mi≈øeries of the other. And if the Gain of all the World be too little to countervail this Lo≈øs, what mi≈øerable Lo≈øers are the Generality of Men that forfeit their Souls upon a far le≈øs valuable Con≈øideration? For no Man was ever yet, or is ever like to be ≈øo pro≈øperous in his Sin, as to gain the whole World by it; that is a Scramble in which Millions are ingaged, and of which every one will be catching a Share. But, alas, for the Generality, the Purcha≈øe of Mens Sin is ≈øo ≈ømall and incon≈øiderable, that it is ≈øcarce a valuable Con≈øideration for the Soul of a Rat. For what doth the common Swearer get by all his ≈øen≈øle≈øs and impertinent Oaths, which are capable of ≈øerving no other Purpo≈øe but only to ≈øtop the Gaps of his Speech, or to man his Rage, that he may rave, and play the Fool a little more genteely? What doth the Drunkard gain by all his Intemperances, but only a ≈øhort Fit of frantick Mirth, and extravagant Jollity, which, after a few Hours, ends in a ≈øleeple≈øs Night, a ≈øick, and unea≈øy Stomach, and a ≈øotti≈øh Confu≈øion over all his Sen≈øes? What doth the envious and malicious Man get by all his ≈øtudied Mi≈øchiefs and Revenges? When he hath pluck'd out his Enemy's Eye, he cannot put it into his own Head, nor can he increa≈øe the Stock of his own Happine≈øs by dimini≈øhing his Adver≈øaries.
When he hath made another the wor≈øe, he is never the better for it; nor do his Injuries grow le≈øs by being retaliated: So that he vexes and di≈øquiets him≈øelf to no purpo≈øe, but to make his Enemy bleed; he keeps his own Wound green, and con≈øequently multiplies Evils in vain, and pro≈øecutes Mi≈øchief only for Mi≈øchief's ≈øake. I confe≈øs there are ≈øome Vices that are not altogether ≈øo unprofitable as the≈øe; in ≈øome Vices there is a Pro≈øpect of worldly Gain and Greatne≈øs, in others of ≈øen≈øitive Plea≈øure and Delight; but alas, when after a few days Injoyment of tho≈øe Gains and Plea≈øures, I am called away from them, and tran≈øported into a woful Eternity, there to expiate the Guilts of them with tho≈øe ≈øharp and everla≈øting Torments I ≈øhall be made to endure, how ≈øhall I be a≈øtoni≈øhed at my own de≈øperate Folly to think what a mad Bargain I have made? what an Happine≈øs I have ≈øold to purcha≈øe tho≈øe Gains? what a Mi≈øery I have incurred to gra≈øp and injoy tho≈øe Plea≈øures? O! now what would I give for a Goal-delivery from Hell, or but for the lea≈øt Mitigation of my Agonies and Torments! If I had all the Wealth that I purcha≈øed by my Sin, and ten thou≈øand times more, how willingly would I part with it to bribe my Flames, and corrupt my Tormentors? O! now I ≈øhall wi≈øh a thou≈øand and a thou≈øand times that I had rather cho≈øen to fami≈øh for want of Bread, than to injoy tho≈øe accur≈øed Profits and Plea≈øures that were the Fruits and Wages of mine Iniquities; but now alas it will be too late to Repent. As yet we have the Opportunity to retrieve our own Folly, and to revoke and cancel this our de≈øperate Bargain, and
by our ≈øerious Repentance and hearty Renunciation of the Temptations of this World, we may relea≈øe our ≈øelves from our Covenant with Death, and Agreement with Hell. But if we out-≈øtay our Opportunity a few Moments longer, till Death hath put an end to it, the fatal Bargain will be ≈øealed pa≈øt all Revocation.

above all ≈øublunary Natures; that is, in governing our Pa≈ø≈øions and Appetites, Words and Actions, according to tho≈øe Eternal Rules of Righteou≈øne≈øs which Right Rea≈øon dictates to us; and if in≈øtead of doing thus, we wholly re≈øign up our ≈øelves to the Dominion of our bruti≈øh and unrea≈øonable Inclinations, we thereby render our ≈øelves more de≈øpicable and infamous than the mo≈øt bea≈øtly Brutes in all the Creation, and even tho≈øe Goats, and Wolves, and Swine, and Tygers, whom we re≈øemble in our bea≈øtly Manners, could they ≈øee our Shame, would doubtle≈øly hi≈øs at us, and reproach us for Greater Bea≈øts than them≈øelves; for they all live up to the be≈øt of their Natures, and regularly pur≈øue the highe≈øt End for which they were created; whereas we who are Allyed to the noble≈øt of Beings, and are created and de≈øigned for the mo≈øt glorious Ends, do by our ba≈øe and unrea≈øonable Conde≈øcentions ≈øhamefully under-value our ≈øelves in pur≈øuing no Ends but what are extremely unworthy of us: So that it had been much more for our Honour and Reputation to have a≈ø≈øumed the Shape and Nature of Brutes, when we a≈ø≈øumed their Manners and Cu≈øtoms; for then our Actions would have very well become us, and neither God nor Men could have ju≈øtly upbraided us for them. But to lead the Lives of Brutes in the Shape and Nature of Men, is mon≈øtrous; 'tis to advance the Bea≈øt above the Man, to place our. Heels where Nature hath placed our Head, and become our own Rever≈øe and Antipodes.

div.head: OF THE AUTHORITY OF THE Holy Scripture.

q.p: Search the Scriptures, for in them ye think ye have eternal life.

div.p:
BY the Scriptures here mu≈øt be meant the Old Te≈øtament; for as yet the greate≈øt Part of the New was unrevealed, and the whole of it unwritten. They were tho≈øe very Scriptures was now preaching, owned and acknowledged to be the Word of God; for in them, ≈øays our Saviour, ye think ye have eternal life; which it's certain they did not think of any other Scriptures but only tho≈øe of the Old Testament; and they are they, ≈øays he, which te≈øtify of me. And to be ≈øure there were no other Scriptures which could te≈øtfy of Chri≈øt to the unbelieving Jews, but only tho≈øe of Mo≈øes and the Prephets, the≈øe being the only Scriptures
who≈øe Te≈øtimony they credited. But yet the Rea≈øon which our Saviour urges to move them to read the Old Te≈øtament, doth as much oblige us to read the New as well as the Old, as it did them to read the Old; for in them ye think ye have eternal life; that is, in them yet think ye have eternal Life promi≈øed, and all the Nece≈ø≈øaries to be believed, and done by you in order to your obtaining it, propo≈øed to you. And indeed as they thought, ≈øo it was; they had eternal Life propo≈øed to them in Hieroglyphicks; for that was the My≈øtery of their Holy of Holies, that was the Interpretation of their Land of Canaan, and the ≈øpiritual Sen≈øe of all their general Promi≈øes of good Things to come: They had all the Articles of Faith, and all the In≈øtances of Duty that were nece≈ø≈øary to their Attainment of eternal Life exhibited to them in the Writings of their Prophets, and the Types and Figures of their Law. For it was by this Rule alone that all the Holy Men of the Jewi≈øh Nation did live and believe; and either this was ≈øufficient to guide and direct them to eternal Life, or they were left under a fatal Nece≈ø≈øity of falling ≈øhort of it: It was the Law of the Lord that did enlighten their Eyes, and rejoyce their Hearts, and convert their Souls; and it was in keeping it that they found great Reward, P≈ø. 19.7, 8, 11. And therefore either they fell ≈øhort of the Reward of eternal Life notwith≈øtanding this their Illumination and Conver≈øion, or they found it in keeping that Law by which they were illuminated and converted; and if in keeping their Law they found eternal Life, then it's certain that in their Law they had it. So that the≈øe Words of our Saviour (for in them ye think ye have eternal life)
do not imply that they were mi≈øtaken in thinking ≈øo, or at lea≈øt they only imply that they were mi≈øtaken in thinking to obtain eternal Life by adbering to the prime and literal Sen≈øe of their Law without pur≈øuing the My≈øtery and Spiritual Meaning of it; which was indeed the Error of the Phari≈øees, with whom our Saviour is here di≈øcour≈øing. For the internal Sen≈øe and My≈øtery of their Law was the Go≈øpel, all who≈øe Articles of Faith, and Precepts of Duty, were (though darkly and ob≈øcurely) expre≈ø≈øed and repre≈øented in the Types and Figures of the Mo≈øaick In≈øtitution. And hence the Apo≈øtle tells, that both the Prie≈øts and their Oblations, did ≈øerve unto the example, and ≈øhadow of heavenly things, Heb. 8.5. So that the heavenly Things contained in the Go≈øpel were the ≈øub≈øtantial Idea's which tho≈øe Legal Types and Patterns contained and repre≈øented; and the ≈øame Author calls that Law a ≈øhadow of good things to come, Heb. 10.1. that is, it was an ob≈øcure Scheme or Prefiguration of the Mercies of the Go≈øpel, of which eternal Life is a principal Part. Since therefore the Law was nothing el≈øe but only the Go≈øpel in dark and ob≈øcure Cyphers, if in this we Chri≈øtians have eternal Life, in that the Jews had it al≈øo: And therefore the Rea≈øon which our Saviour here urges to oblige the Jews to ≈øearch the Scriptures of the Old Te≈øtament; [for in them ye think have eternal life] doth at lea≈øt equally oblige us Chri≈øtians to ≈øearch the Scriptures both of the Old and New. For if they had ju≈øt Rea≈øon to think they had eternal Life in the Old Te≈øtament, and were thereupon obliged to ≈øearch into it, we have rather more Rea≈øon to think that we have eternal Life in the New, ≈øince the New
Te≈øtament is nothing el≈øe but only the Old decyphered and unriddled; and therefore we mu≈øt not only have eternal Life in this, as they had in that, but we mu≈øt al≈øo have it far more expre≈øly than they. In the Pro≈øecution of this Argument therefore, I ≈øhall endeavour the≈øe Two Things.

list.item: I. To ≈øhew you that in the Holy Scriptures we have eternal Life.
II. That this is a very forcible Rea≈øon to oblige us to ≈øearch them.

div.p:
I. Fir≈øt, that in the Holy Scriptures we have eternal Life; that is, that in them we have eternal Life propo≈øed to us, together with all that is nece≈ø≈øary to be believed, and practi≈øed by us in order to our obtaining it; or in other words, that the Holy Scripture is a ≈øufficient Rule both of Faith and Manners to guide and direct us to eternal Happine≈øs. And this is one Article of the Faith of the Church of England, which we are required to explain to the People; for ≈øo in her ≈øixth Article our Church profe≈ø≈øes, that the Holy Scripture containeth all things nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation; ≈øo that what≈øoever is not read therein, or may be proved thence, is not required of any Man that it ≈øhould be believed as an Article of Faith, or be thought requi≈øite or nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation. Now to make the Scripture a ≈øufficient Rule as to all Things nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation, there are two Things nece≈ø≈øary; Fir≈øt, That it ≈øhould be full; and Secondly, That it ≈øhould be clear: both which the Holy Scripture is in an eminent Degree, as containing in it all that is nece≈ø≈øary to be believed, and done in order to eternal Life. And
this will evidently appear from the≈øe three following Propo≈øitions:
1. That the Holy Spirit in≈øpired the Writers of the Scripture with all that is nece≈ø≈øary to eternal Life.
2. That they preached to the World all tho≈øe Nece≈ø≈øaries with which the Holy Spirit in≈øpired them.
3. That all tho≈øe nece≈ø≈øary Truths which they preached, are comprehended in tho≈øe Sacred Writings of theirs of which the Holy Scripture con≈øi≈øts.

1. That the Holy Spirit infpired the Writers of the Scripture with all that is nece≈ø≈øary to eternal Life. For fir≈øt, our Saviour, by whom they were originally in≈øtructed, declares, that as the Father loved him, and ≈øhewed him all things that him≈øelf did, Joh. 5.20. ≈øo he had made known to them all things that he had heard of his Father, Job. 17.8. And then when he went from them, and cea≈øed to in≈øtruct them in his own Per≈øon, he promi≈øed that by his Spirit he would teach them all things, and bring all things to their remembrance what≈øoever he had ≈øaid unto them, Job. 14.26. and that by the ≈øame Spirit he would guide them into all Truth, Job. 16.13. If therefore the Spirit did perform this Promi≈øe to them, (as there is no doubt but he did) then we are ≈øure that he did teach them over again what≈øoever Chri≈øt had taught them before, and if Chri≈øt had taught them what≈øoever he had heard of his Father, (as he declares he had) then it is certain either that he taught them all Things nece≈ø≈øary to eternal Life, or that he him≈øelf had not heard from
his Father all Things that are nece≈ø≈øary thereunto.

2. That as they were taught by the Spirit, all Things nece≈ø≈øary to eternal Life, ≈øo what they were taught, they preached and delivered to the World. For ≈øo our Saviour commanded them to go forth into all the World, and teach all Nations to ob≈øerve all tho≈øe things which he had commanded them, Matth. 28.19, 20. Which Injunction of his they ≈øtrictly ob≈øerved; for ≈øo we are told, that in Obedience to it, they went forth, and preached every where, Mark, 16.20. And that their preaching extended to all Things nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation, is evident from their own Te≈øtimony: For thus St. Paul tells the Ephe≈øians that he had not ≈øhunned to declare unto them the whole Coun≈øel of God, Acts 20.27. And to be ≈øure in the whole Coun≈øel of God, all that is nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation mu≈øt be included. And concerning that Go≈øpel which he had preached to the Corinthians, he thus pronounces, By which al≈øo ye are ≈øaved, if ye keep in Memory what I preached unto you, unle≈øs ye have believed in vain, 1 Cor. 15.1, 2. but how could they be ≈øaved by that Go≈øpel he preached to them, unle≈øs it contained in it all Things nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation? And this very Go≈øpel which the Apo≈øtles in their con≈øtant Mini≈øtry propo≈øed to the World, St. James calls the ingrafted Word, which is able to ≈øave our Souls, Jam. 1.21. And for the ≈øame Rea≈øon it is al≈øo called the Word of Reconciliation, 2 Cor. 5.19. The Word of Salvation, Acts 13.26. And the World of Life, Acts 5.20. And the Savour of Life unto Life, 2 Cor. 2.16. And al≈øo the Power of God unto Salvation to every one that believes, Rom. 1.17. Neither of which it could be ju≈øtly ≈øtiled, ≈øuppo≈øing it to be defective in any
Thing nece≈ø≈øary to the eternal Happine≈øs of Men.

3. And la≈øtly, That all tho≈øe nece≈ø≈øary Truths which they preached, are comprehended in tho≈øe Writings of theirs, of which the Holy Scripture con≈øi≈øts. It is true, before the Chri≈øtian Doctrine was collected into tho≈øe Scriptures of which the New Te≈øtament now con≈øi≈øts, it was all conveyed by Oral Tradition from the Mouths of the Teachers, to the Ears of the Di≈øciples; but in a little Time tho≈øe holy Men who fir≈øt preached it, found an ab≈øolute Nece≈ø≈øity of committing it to Writing, as a much ≈øurer Way of pre≈øerving it uncorrupted, and tran≈ømitting it down to all ≈øucceeding Generations; for thus Eu≈øebius tells us,Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 2. c. 15. That the Romans not being ≈øatisfied with St. Peter's preaching of Chri≈øtianity to them, earne≈øtly de≈øired St. Mark, his Companion, that he would leave them in Writing, a ≈øtanding Monument of that Doctrine which St. Peter had delivered to them by Word of Mouth, which was the Occa≈øion, ≈øays he, of the Writing of St. Mark's Go≈øpel: Which thing St. Peter under≈øtanding by a Revelation of the Spirit, being highly plea≈øed with their earne≈øt De≈øire, he confirmed it by his own Authority, that it might afterwards be read in the Churches. It ≈øeems in tho≈øe Days the Romans did not think oral or unwritten Traditions a ≈øufficient Con≈øervatory of divine Truths, nor did their Bi≈øhops then forbid the reading of the Scriptures to the Laity in their own Language. After which he tells us,L. 3 c. 24. that St. Mathew and St. John were the only Di≈øciples of our Lord, who had left written Commentaries of the Things which they
had preached behind them; and it was, ≈øays he, Nece≈ø≈øity that impelled them to write. For Matthew having preached the Faith to the Hebrews, and intending to go from them to other Nations, wrote his Go≈øpel in his own Country-Language, that thereby he might ≈øupply the Want of his Pre≈øence to tho≈øe whom he left behind him. And afterwards when Mark and Luke had publi≈øhed their Go≈øpels, John who had hitherto only preached the Go≈øpel by Word of Mouth, being at length moved by the ≈øame Rea≈øon betook him≈øelf to write. And the Three former Go≈øpels, ≈øays he, arriving to the Knowledge of all Men, and particularly of St. John, he approved them, and with his own Te≈øtimony confirmed the Truth of them. From which Relation it's evident, that that which moved tho≈øe holy Men to commit their Go≈øpels to Writing, was this, that they judged it nece≈ø≈øary for the Con≈øervation of the Chri≈øtian Doctrine, that ≈øo the≈øe in their Ab≈øence might be ≈øtanding Monuments of the Faith, to preach that Go≈øpel to Mens Eyes which they had preached to their Ears: And if they wrote to pre≈øerve the Faith, to be ≈øure they would leave no nece≈ø≈øary or e≈ø≈øential Part of it unwritten. There are ≈øeveral Propo≈øitions in the≈øe Go≈øpels which, though very u≈øeful, are far from being e≈ø≈øential Parts of Chri≈øtianity; and can we imagine that tho≈øe holy Men who wrote on purpo≈øe to con≈øerve Christianity, ≈øhould take ≈øo much Care to write many Things which are not nece≈ø≈øary Parts, and in the mean time omit any Things that are? Eu≈øebius tells us of St Mark in particular, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ; i. e. he took great Care of this more e≈øpecially, not to pretermit any of tho≈øe Things which he had heard, (even from St.
Peter) nor to affix any thing to them that was fal≈øe: And if he were ≈øo careful not to omit any Thing, to be ≈øure he would be particularly careful not to omit any thing which he judged nece≈ø≈øary to the eternal Happine≈øs of Men. But what need we depend upon humane Authority, when as, if we con≈øult tho≈øe Sacred Writings them≈øelves, (which ≈øo far as they go, all Chri≈øtians allow to be the Word of God) we ≈øhall find they give this Te≈øtimony of them≈øelves, that they comprehend in them all Things nece≈ø≈øary to eternal Life. For thus the Writers of the New Te≈øtament te≈øtify of the Old, That they are able to make us wi≈øe unto Salvation through Faith which is in Je≈øus Chri≈øt, 2 Tim. 3.15. And if the Old Te≈øtament alone was able to do this, then much more the Old and New together; but how could they make Men wi≈øe to Salvation, if they were defective in any Article that is nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation? and then the ≈øame Author goes on and tells us, that all Scripture is given by In≈øpiration of God, and is profitable for Doctrine, for Reproof, for Correction, for In≈øtruction in Righteou≈øne≈øs; that the Man of God may be perfect, throughly furni≈øhed unto all good works, v. 16, 17. And if the Old Scriptures were ≈øufficient to make the Man of God perfect, and to furni≈øh him throughly unto all good Works, one would think that the New and Old together ≈øhould not be defective. For that the Scriptures of the New Te≈øtament as well as of the Old contain in them all Things nece≈ø≈øary to eternal Life, they them≈øelves do plainly te≈øtify of them≈øelves: For thus St. Luke in the Beginning of his Go≈øpel tells his Theophilus, to whom he writes, that fora≈ømuch as many had ≈øet forth a Declaration of
tho≈øe things that were ≈øurely believed among Chri≈øtians, it ≈øeemed good unto him al≈øo having had a perfect under≈øtanding of all things from the first, to write them down in order that he might know the Certainty of tho≈øe things wherein he had been instructed: From whence I infer, that ≈øuppo≈øing St. Luke performed what he promi≈øed, his Go≈øpel mu≈øt contain a full Declaration of the Chri≈øtian Religion: For, Fir≈øt, by promi≈øing to give an Account of tho≈øe Things which were ≈øurely believed among Christians, he engaged him≈øelf to give an entire Account of Christianity, unle≈øs we will ≈øuppo≈øe that there were ≈øome Parts of Chri≈øtianity which the Chri≈øtians of that Time did not ≈øurely believe. Secondly, In promi≈øing to give an Account of tho≈øe Things of which he had a perfect Under≈øtanding from the fir≈øt, and in which his Theophilus had been in≈øtructed, he al≈øo engages him≈øelf to give a compleat Account of the whole Religion, unle≈øs we will ≈øuppo≈øe that there were ≈øome Parts of this Religion which St. Luke did not perfectly under≈øtand, and in which Theophilus had not been before in≈øtructed. Thus al≈øo St. John te≈øtifies of his Go≈øpel, Chap. 20. 31. The≈øe things are written, that ye might believe that Je≈øus is the Chri≈øt the Son of God, and that believing ye might have life through his name. And if it be objected that by the≈øe Things the Apo≈øtle only means the Miracles of Chri≈øt which are the Motives of our Belief, and not his Doctrines which are to be believed by us; this is notoriou≈øly fal≈øe, ≈øince by the≈øe Things St. John means his Go≈øpel in which not only the Miracles, but the Doctrines of Chri≈øt are contained; and therefore in his fir≈øt Epi≈øtle, chap. 5. 13. he ≈øaith, The≈øe things have I written unto you that believe
on the name of the Son of God that ye may know that ye have eternal life, and that ye may believe, or continue to believe on the name of the Son of God; Where by The≈øe Things it's plain he means only that Chri≈øtian Doctrine which he had been teaching throughout the whole Epi≈øtle. From which two Places I argue, that all Things nece≈ø≈øary to eternal Life are written, becau≈øe he expre≈øly tells us that The≈øe Things were written to this end, that they might beget and nouri≈øh in us that Faith by which we may obtain eternal Life; but if that Faith which the≈øe written Things was de≈øigned to beget in us, be not ≈øufficient to eternal Life, then were the≈øe Things written in vain, and the End of writing them, which was that we might obtain eternal Life, by believing them, was wholly fru≈øtrated; but if that Faith were ≈øufficient to eternal Life, then the≈øe written Things which begot that Faith, and were the Object of it, mu≈øt contain in them all Things nece≈ø≈øary to eternal Life; for how can they beget in us a Faith that is ≈øufficient to eternal Life, unle≈øs they propo≈øe to our Faith all Things that are nece≈ø≈øary thereunto?

And thus I have endeavoured to demon≈øtrate from Scripture it ≈øelf, which all agree is the Word of God, and con≈øequently the mo≈øt concluding Authority in the World, that the Holy Scripture is in it ≈øelf a ≈øufficient Rule of Faith and Manners to direct Men to eternal Life. And if this be ≈øo, I would fain know by what Warrant or Authority any Man or Church, can pretend to obtrude upon the Faith of Chri≈øtians any unwritten Traditions, or Doctrines of Faith, and Rules of Wor≈øhip, not recorded in Scripture as of equal Authority with tho≈øe recorded
in Scripture, and equally nece≈ø≈øary to the eternal Happine≈øs of Men. For that there have been ≈øuch bold Impo≈øers in the Christian World Irenaeus a≈ø≈øures us in the 2d Chapter of his 2d Book again≈øt Here≈øies; where he tells us of a ≈øort of Hereticks who taught, that the Truth could not be found in the Scriptures by tho≈øe to whom Tradition was unknown; for as much as it was not delivered by Writing, but by Word of Mouth. And the≈øe HereticksDe Prae≈øcrip. Haeret. c. 25., as Tertullian ob≈øerves, confe≈ø≈øed indeed that the Apo≈øtles were ignorant, and that they did not at all differ among them≈øelves in their Preaching, but ≈øaid they revealed not all Things unto all Men; ≈øome Things they taught openly and to all, ≈øome Things ≈øecretly, and to a few; which ≈øecret Things were the unwritten Traditions which they ≈øought to impo≈øe upon the Faith of Chri≈øtians. And how far the Church of Rome it ≈øelf doth in this matter tread in the Foot≈øteps of the≈øe ancient Hereticks, is but too notorious: For thus in the Preface of their Catechi≈øm it is expre≈øly affirmed by the Council of Trent, that the whole Doctrine to be delivered to the Faithful, is contained in the Word of God, which Word of God is di≈øtributed into Scripture and Tradition. And in the Councel it ≈øelf they declare, and define, that the Books of Scripture and unwritten Traditions are to be received and honoured with equal pious Affection and Reverence: In which Words they expre≈øly own another Word of God be≈øides the Scripture, viz. Tradition, which they equalize with the Scripture it ≈øelf. And this is almo≈øt verbatim the very A≈ø≈øertion which both Irenaeus and Tertullian condemn for Here≈øy; and as they are the ≈øame, ≈øo we find they are grounded
on the ≈øame Authority: For tho≈øe very Texts of Scripture which tho≈øe ancient Hereticks urged for their Tradition, are urged by Bellarmin for the Tradition of his Church. Thus for their Tradition, as Irenaeus and Tertullian acquaints us, they urged that of St. Paul, We ≈øpeak Wi≈ødom among them that are perfect; and al≈øo, O Timothy, keep that which is committed to thy tru≈øt; and again, That good Thing which is committed to thee, keep: All which Texts are urged by Bellarmin in his 4th and 5th Books de Verbo Dei, in behalf of that Tradition which the Church of Rome contends for: And 'tis ≈øomething hard that that which was damned for Here≈øy in the Primitive Church, ≈øhould be made an Article of Faith in the pre≈øent Roman. Not that we do di≈øallow of Traditions univer≈øally received in all Churches and Ages; for we frankly acknowledge that what is now contained in Scripture was Tradition before it was Scripture, as being first delivered by Word of Mouth before it was collected into Writing; and therefore when≈øoever it can be made evident to us that there are any unwritten Doctrines bearing the ≈øame Stamp of Divine Authority with tho≈øe that are written, we are ready to recive them with the ≈øame Veneration as we do the Scriptures them≈øelves. For it is not their being written that doth authorize them, but their being from God, and our Saviour, and his Apostles; and therefore when once it's made appear to us that Christ or his Apo≈øtles taught ≈øo and ≈øo, that is ≈øufficient to command our A≈ø≈øent and Submi≈ø≈øion whether it be made appear from Scripture or Tradition. So that the Rea≈øon why we embrace ≈øome Doctrines and reject others, is not merely becau≈øe
the one are written, and the other not; but becau≈øe to us, who live at ≈øo great a di≈øtance from Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles, it can never be made ≈øo evident, that what is not written was taught by them, as what is. What is written hath been delivered down to us by the unanimous Tradition and Te≈øtimony of the Church of Chri≈øt in all Ages, which I am ≈øure can never be ju≈øtly pretended of any one of tho≈øe unwritten Traditions which the Church of Rome now impo≈øes upon the Faith of Chri≈øtians. Let them but produce the ≈øame unanimous Te≈øtimony that any one of tho≈øe Twelve Articles which they have thought meet to ≈øuperadd to the ancient Creeds, was taught by Christ or his Apo≈øtles, as we do that what is contained in Scripture was ≈øo, and we will as readily embrace it as any Propo≈øition in Scripture; but if this Article be neither to be found in Scripture, nor delivered down to us as taught by Chri≈øt or his Apo≈øtles, by the unanimous Te≈øtimony of the Church of Christ through all Ages, we mu≈øt crave their pardon if we cannot receive it as Part of the Word of God.
