It is ≈øufficient that we cannot err damnably in our Faith without ≈øome damnable Fault in our Wills; but if we eithre refu≈øe to enquire into this Revelation for what is nece≈ø≈øary for us to believe, or will only enquire into it with a Mind that is bya≈øs'd with wicked and ≈øinful Prejudices, or will not ≈øubmit our Under≈øtandings to it upon the cleare≈øt Conviction, there is no doubt but we may be ignorant, and we may be deceived in Things of the greate≈øt Moment, and it is but ju≈øt and fit that we ≈øhould: And if notwith≈øtanding the≈øe Faults we could not err, for God's ≈øake what Virtue would it be to be Orthodox? But if with hone≈øt, humble, and teachable Minds we will diligently enquire into divine Revelation, we ≈øhall there find all the Nece≈ø≈øaries to Salvation ≈øo clearly and plainly propo≈øed to us, that 'twill be morally impo≈ø≈øible for us either to be ignorant of, or deceived about them. So that by relying on Scripture you ≈øee we are expo≈øed to no other Uncertainties than ju≈øt what are nece≈ø≈øary to render our Faith a Virtue; and God doth as much require that our Faith ≈øhould be virtuous as that it ≈øhould be Orthodox; that it ≈øhould be the Act of an hone≈øt, humble, diligent, and teachable Mind, as that it ≈øhould be extended to all Things nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation. Now our Faith may be Orthodox without an infallible Certainty, but it cannot be virtuous and rewardable with it. To what purpo≈øe then do the Romani≈øts talk of an infallible certainty in Believing? Is it rea≈øonable to expect more certainty than God ever intended to
give? He hath given as much as is nece≈ø≈øary for hone≈øt Minds and no more, and whether Knaves and Hypocrites believe right or wrong is of no great Concernment. If therefore our Faith be liable to no other Uncertainty than ju≈øt what is nece≈ø≈øary to try our Hone≈øty, that is much better for us in Re≈øpect of the Virtue of our Faith than an infallible Certainty. Suppo≈øing therefore that the Church of Rome were as infallible as it pretends, it is certain that the Scripture is as infallible as that; but whether we relie upon one or t'other we are fallible ≈øtill. And could that Church render us as infallibly certain as it pretends, it would thereby pre≈øerve indeed the Orthodoxy of our Faith, but then at the ≈øame Time it would de≈øtroy the Virtue of it: For to believe right when we cannot believe wrong is fatal and nece≈ø≈øary; but to believe right when through our own Default we may be believe wrong, this is virtuous and remwardable.

By what hath been ≈øaid therefore, I think it is ≈øufficiently evident, that it is upon the Scripture we are to relie, and not upon the Church, e≈øpecially upon the Roman Church, for all Things nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation; and therefore ≈øince we are obliged to believe the≈øe Things upon pain of Eternal Damnation, it nece≈ø≈øarily follows that they mu≈øt be plain and clear, and Scripture; otherwi≈øe we could not be ju≈øtly ≈øo obliged to believe them. And thus I have ≈øhewn at large that the Scripture is the great Rule of our Faith and Manners, and that as ≈øuch, it is both full and clear, as containing in it all Things nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation, and propo≈øing them ≈øo plainly and clearly, as that upon an hone≈øt and diligent Enquiry all Men may find and di≈øcover them.

div.head: A Second Di≈øcour≈øe

q.p: Search the Scriptures; for in them ye think ye have eternal life.

div.p:
WHether the≈øe Words are to be rendred Indicatively, [Ye do ≈øearch the Scriptures] as ≈øome would have them, or Imperatively, [Search the Scriptures] as our Tran≈ølation renders them, amounts to the ≈øame thing; For if we render them Indicatively, [Ye do ≈øearch the Scriptures] it is evident, that they are ≈øpoken with Approbation, Ye do read the Scriptures, and ye do very well in ≈øo doing: For thus we find the Bereans commended for Scarching the Scriptures, and Timothy, for knowing them from a Child. And if to Search the Scripture be a commendable Practice, then to be ≈øure our Saviour here mentions it at lea≈øt with Approbation; and what he approves when done, that to be ≈øure he would have us do. Whether therefore it be delivered in the Form of a Command, or of a bare A≈ø≈øertion, it is equivalent to a Command, it being at lea≈øt an A≈ø≈øertion of a Thing which he approves, and con≈øequently would have all Men to Practi≈øe. But becau≈øe there is a numerous Party in the Chri≈øtian World which doth not only forbid the People to Search the Scriptures, but repre≈øents it as a Practice of very dangerous Con≈øequence, it is
hereby become nece≈ø≈øary that we ≈øhould not only a≈ø≈øert, but prove their Obligation to it, which otherwi≈øe would be very needle≈øs, there being nothing more plain and evident in it ≈øelf. Now to prove that the People are obliged to Search and Read the Scriptures, I ≈øhall as briefly as I can, argue the Point from the≈øe following Topicks.

list.item: 1. From the Obligations which the Jews were under-to Read and Search the Scriptures of the Old Te≈øtament.
2. From our Saviour's and his Apo≈øtles Approbation of their Practice in pur≈øuance of this their Obligation.
3. From the great De≈øign and Intention of Writing the Scriptures.
4. From the Direction of the≈øe Holy Writings to the People.
5. From the great Concernment of the People in the Matters contained in them.
6. From the ∆≤niver≈øal Sen≈øe of the Primitive Church in this Matter.

div.p:
1. From the general Obligation which the Jews were under the Read and Search their Scriptures. For ≈øo God requires them to keep the words which he commanded them, in their Hearts, and to teach them diligently to their Children, and to talk of them as they ≈øat in their Hou≈øes, and as they walked in the way, and when they lay down, and when they ro≈øe up, and to bind them as a ≈øign upon their hands, Deut. 6.6, 7, 8. And el≈øewhere, This book of the Law ≈øhall not depart out of thy mouth, but thou ≈øhatl meditate therein day and night, ≈øpeaking to the Children of I≈ørael in general, Jo≈ø.
1.8. And again, Ye ≈øhall lay lip the≈øe my words in your heart and in your ≈øoul, that your days may be multiplied, and the days of your Children, in the Land which the Lord ≈øware unto your Fathers to give them, as the days of heaven upon the earth, Deut. 11.18, 21. And to meditate on God's Law day and night, David makes a Part of the Character of the Ble≈ø≈øed Man, P≈øal. 1.3. Now if they could not keep God's Laws in their Hearts, as mo≈øt certainly they could not; if they could not teach them to their. Children; if they could not talk of them upon all ju≈øt and proper Occa≈øions, and in a word, if they could not meditate on them day and night without being very well acquainted with them by diligent Search and Reading them, it is mo≈øt certain that to Read and Search into them was their indi≈øpen≈øible Duty. Now if there be the ≈øame Rea≈øon why we ≈øhould Read the Scriptures as there was why the Jews ≈øhould, then the Obligation of the≈øe Commands mu≈øt extend to us as well as to them; becau≈øe the Rea≈øon of the Law is the Law; but 'tis evident, even beyond Contradiction, that there is no good Rea≈øon a≈ø≈øignable for the one, which is not of equal force for the other; and what≈øoever is objected by our Adver≈øaries in this Point again≈øt our Reading the Scriptures, is of equal validity again≈øt the Jews Reading them. It is Objected, That our Reading them, through our Incapacity to under≈øtand them, mu≈øt occa≈øion a great many Errors and Here≈øies in the Church. And why ≈øhould not their Reading them occa≈øion the ≈øame, ≈øince neither their Under≈øtandings were larger than ours, nor their Scriptures clearer and more intelligible than ours? It is farther objected, that becau≈øe of the many ill Examples recorded
in Scripture it is dangerous for the People to read it; becau≈øe of their Aptne≈øs to be mi≈øled and corrupted by Example. But I be≈øeech you, are there not more bad Examples in the Old Te≈øtament than in the New? And were not the Jews as apt to be corrupted by them as we Chri≈øtians? And therefore ≈øince the≈øe Objections do pre≈øs as much again≈øt their reading the Scriptures as ours, it is certain they ought to keep both from it or neither. Seeing therefore notwith≈øtanding the≈øe Objections God obliged the Jews to read them, it's plain they are not of Force enough to di≈øoblige us from doing the ≈øame.

2. From our Saviour and his Apo≈øtles Approbation of this Practice of the Jews in Pur≈øuance of their Obligation to it, it is al≈øo evident that we are obliged to the ≈øame. That the Common People of the Jews did ordinarily read the Scriptures in our Saviou's Time, is evident not only from the Text, Search the Scriptures (which if you take them Indicatively, are an expre≈øs Declaration that they did read them; and if you take them Imperatively, nece≈ø≈øarily imply that they them≈øelves owned that they ought to read them) but al≈øo from tho≈øe Que≈øtions which our Saviour frequently ask'd them in his Conferences with them; ≈øuch as, Have ye not read? Have ye never read in the Scripture? And hath not the Scripture ≈øaid ≈øo and ≈øo? Which Que≈øtion would be very Impertinent if reading the Scripture were not then ordinarily practi≈øed by that People. And that even their holy Women were then ≈øo well in≈øtructed in the Scriptures as to be able to in≈øtruct their Children, Timothy is a ≈øignal In≈øtance, who, though his Father were an Heathen, had known the holy Scriptures from
a Child, 2 Tim. 3.15. which knowledge he mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily have derived from his Grand-Mother Lois, and his Mother Eunice, who≈øe Faith St. Paul celebrates; 2 Tim. 1.5. And this Practice of reading the Scriptures which was ≈øo common among that People in our Saviour's time is ≈øo far from being di≈øcontinued either by him≈øelf or his Apo≈øtles, that it is always mentioned by them with Applau≈øe and Approbation. Thus the Bereans are commended as a People of a nobler Strain than tho≈øe of The≈ø≈øalonica, becau≈øe they ≈øearched the Scriptures daily whether tho≈øe Things which St. Paul had preached to them were ≈øo or no. And St. Paul is ≈øo far from reprehending Timothy for medling with the Scriptures whil≈øt he was a Lay-man, that he mentions it to his Honour, that he had known the Scriptures from a Child. And in all tho≈øe Pa≈ø≈øages wherein our Saviour takes it for granted that the Common People of the Jews did read the Scripture, we have not the lea≈øt Intimation of his di≈ølike of their Practice, which we ≈øhould certainly have had, had he apprehended it to be either dangerous or unwarrantable. Seeing therefore neither our Saviour nor his Apo≈øtles do in the lea≈øt di≈øallow of the Scriptures being read by the Common People, but on the contrary do expre≈øly commend it; this is a plain Argument that it was their Intention to perpetuate the Practice of it to future Ages. For ≈øeeing the Jews read the Scriptures in Obedience to an expre≈øs Command of God, as was ≈øhewn before, had our Saviour intended that they ≈øhould not continue it, he would doubtle≈øs have repealed that Command by ≈øome Countermand, which he was ≈øo far from doing that he not only every where allows of their
reading the Scriptures, but al≈øo expre≈øly approves and commends it; whereby he plainly e≈øtabli≈øhes the Obligation of that ancient Command in Obedience to which they did read them.

3. From the great De≈øign and Intention of Writing the Scriptures, it is al≈øo evident, that the People are ≈øtill obliged to Read them. It is plain the great De≈øign of Writing the Scripture was to in≈øtruct Men in the Knowledge, and per≈øuade them to the Practice of True Religion; For thus of the Scriptures of the Old Te≈øtament St. Paul tells us, That what≈øoever things were written aforetime, were written for our learning, Rom. 15.4. and for our admonition, 1 Cor. 10.11. And as for the New Te≈øtament, we are told, That it was written that we might believe that Je≈øus is the Chri≈øt the Son of God, and that believing we might have life through his name, Joh. 20.31. And St. Peter tells us, That he wrote both his Epi≈øtles to ≈øtir up the pure Minds of Chri≈øtians by way of remembrance, and to put them in mind of the words which were ≈øpoken before by the Holy Prophets, and of the Commandment of the Apo≈øtles of our Lord and Saviour, 2 Pet. 3.1. And St. John gives us this account of his Writing his Epi≈øtles, The≈øe things have I written to you that ye ≈øin not, 1 Joh. 2.1. And St. Jude, this of his, Beloved, when I gave all diligence to write unto you of the common Salvation, it was needful for me to write unto you, and exhort you that ye ≈øhould earne≈øtly contend for the faith which was once delivered unto the Saints, v. 3. The≈øe are the Ends for which the Scripture was written; but how can the Writing of it contribute to the≈øe Ends if we are not permitted to Read what is written? For the Scripture was written to the People as well as to the Clergy, as I ≈øhall
≈øhew by and by; but to what purpo≈øe ≈øhould it be written to the People to in≈øtruct and admoni≈øh them, if the People are not allowed to Read its In≈øtructions and Admonitions? What Influence could the Writing it have upon the People's Belief, that Je≈øus Chri≈øt is the Son of God, if they had been debarr'd from acquainting them≈øelves with what is written concerning him? How could it ≈øtir up their Remembrance, if they might not Read what it ≈øugge≈øted to their Memory? By what other way can it keep the People from Sinning, but by Motives and Per≈øua≈øtions? But how ≈øhould its Motives and Per≈øua≈øions affect their Minds if they are not allowed to con≈øult and under≈øtand them? Upon what Account can it move the People earne≈øtly to contend for the Faith once delivered to the Saints, if they are not allowed to learn from it either what that Faith is, or what tho≈øe Rea≈øons are which oblige them to contend for it? So that to write to the People on purpo≈øe to in≈øtruct and reform them, and at the ≈øame time to purpo≈øe to debar them from Reading it, is either to ≈øuppo≈øe, that the Writing will operate like a Charm, or to purpo≈øe a downright Contradiction. For how oddly would it have lookt, if in the afore-cited Pa≈ø≈øages, the Apo≈øtles had expre≈øt them≈øelves thus: The≈øe thinge are written for your Learning and Admonition; but 'tis by no means fit you ≈øhould learn from them what they teach and admoni≈øh you. The≈øe Things are written that ye ≈øhould believe that Je≈øus is the Chri≈øt and the Son of God; but they are not written that you ≈øhould enquire of them whether Je≈øus be the Chri≈øt or the Son of God. The≈øe Things are written to put you in Mind of what hath been ≈øpoken by the Prophets
and Apo≈øtles; but they were not written that you might acquaint your ≈øelves by them what the Prophets and Apo≈øtles ≈øpake. The≈øe Things are written that you ≈øhould not Sin; but beware you do not read them le≈øt the bad Examples recorded in them occa≈øion you to Sin. In ≈øhort, The≈øe Things were written to excite you earne≈øtly to contend for the Faith once delivered to the Saints; but you are by no means allowed to enquire into them le≈øt you ≈øhould mi≈øunder≈øtand them, and and ≈øo in≈øtead of contending for the Faith you ≈øhould contend for Here≈øie and Fal≈øe Doctrine. Had the Apo≈øtles thus expre≈øs'd them≈øelves, I appeal to any rea≈øonable Man whether the≈øe Pa≈ø≈øages would not have ≈øtartled his Under≈øtanding, and tempted him to que≈øtion whether the Authors of them were well in their Wits; and yet this mu≈øt have been their meaning, ≈øuppo≈øing that they meant that the People ≈øhould not read what they wrote.

4. From the Direction of the≈øe Holy Writings to the People, it is al≈øo evident, that the People are ≈øtill obliged to Read, or acquaint them≈øelves with them. For ≈øo we find the Law of Mo≈øes was delivered by God to all the People as well as to him and Aaron; and (as was ≈øhewn before) they were all of them commanded to ≈øearch and enquire into it. And ≈øo al≈øo were the Sermons of the Prophets, which are u≈øually prefaced with an, Hear O I≈ørael, Hear O Hou≈øe of Judah, Hear O Hou≈øe of Jacob, and Hear all ye of Judah. So al≈øo our Ble≈ø≈øed Saviour Preach'd his Sermons and Parables, not only to his Apo≈øtles, and Seventy Di≈øciples, but al≈øo to the People, and to the Multitudes. And ≈øo al≈øo his Apo≈øtles direct their Epi≈øtles, not only to the Saints, to the faithful in Chri≈øt Je≈øus, to the Beloved, which in
the Language of Scripture includes every Chri≈øtian; but al≈øo to all that are at Rome, to all that in every place call upon the name of Je≈øus Chri≈øt our Lord, to all the Saints which are in Achaia, to all the Saints which are at Philippi, to the twelve Tribes which are ≈øcattered abroad, to the Strangers ≈øcattered through Pontus, Galatia, &c. and to them which have obtained like precious Faith with us, that is, to all the Jewi≈øh Chri≈øtians di≈øper≈øed over the World. Seeing therefore the Scriptures were directed to all, as well Laity as Clergy, this not only gives a Right to all to Read them, but al≈øo lays an Obligation upon all to acquaint them≈øelves with them. For the very directing ≈øuch a Writing or Epi≈øtle to ≈øuch or ≈øuch Per≈øons, doth, in the Sen≈øe of all the World, imply, that he who writes doth de≈øign and intend, that they to whom he directs it ≈øhould Read and Peru≈øe it; and therefore, ≈øince the Scriptures were written to all, that is a plain Intimation, that it was the Intention of the Writers that all ≈øhould Read them. And for us not to Read what God hath written, and directed to us, is by implication of Fact, a Prophane Neglect and Contempt of his Mercy, and looks as if we either thought him ≈øuch an In≈øignificant Being, or our ≈øelves ≈øo little concerned in any thing that he can ≈øay or write to us, as that it would not be worth our while to receive, and peru≈øe the Contents of tho≈øe Sacred Epi≈øtles, which by the Hands of his Holy Penmen he hath vouch≈øafed to direct to us. Nor is it a ≈øufficient Excu≈øe for our Contempt, to ≈øay, that in Con≈øideration of our own Pronene≈øs to Err and Mi≈øtake, we ought to content our ≈øelves with this, that our Spiritual Guides ≈øhould Read God's Writings for us, and deliver the Sen≈øe and Contents
of them to us: For to be ≈øure, had God intended that the Prie≈øts only ≈øhould read them, he would have directed them only to the Prie≈øts, and ordered them only to deliver the Sen≈øe of them to the the People; and therefore ≈øince he hath directed them to both, this nece≈ø≈øarily implies that it was his Intention that both ≈øhould read them. For if God had not directed them to Men, neither Prie≈øts nor People were obliged to read them; and therefore ≈øeeing the great Rea≈øon why any Men ought to Read them is, becau≈øe they are directed to Men, this Rea≈øon obliges all Men to Read them; becau≈øe they are directed to all Men. For not to be highly concerned to know and under≈øtand what it is that God writes to us is an Argument that we have a very mean Regard both of his Maje≈øty, and his Mind, and Will. But to be ≈øure who≈øoever is highly concerned to know what ≈øuch a Writing contains, will, if he can, be very curious to peru≈øe it with his own Eyes at lea≈øt, ≈øuppo≈øing that it is not unlawful for him ≈øo to do; becau≈øe there is nothing gives that Satisfaction to a Man's Mind as the Information of his own Sen≈øe. So that for Men wilfully to neglect reading the Scripture which God hath ≈øo expre≈øly directed to them, and thereby not only licen≈øed but obliged them to read it, argues a very prophane Di≈øregard both of the Author of it, and of the Matter it contains; and for any Man, or Society of Men to forbid the People to read what God hath written and directed to them, is not only to deprive them of a Right which God hath given them, but al≈øo to acquit them of a Duty which he hath laid upon them For St. Paul in tho≈øe Epi≈øtles which he wrote to the Chri≈øtian People
in general of ≈øuch and ≈øuch Churches, ≈øtill takes it for granted that they would read them; as being not only warranted, but obliged thereunto by his writing them; for ≈øo Ephe≈ø. 3.3, 4. ≈øpeaking of that great My≈øtery of the calling the Gentiles which God had revealed to him, concerning which ≈øaith he, I wrote afore in few words, whereby when ye read ye may under≈øtand my knowledge in the my≈øtery of Chri≈øt. So al≈øo 2 Cor. 1.13. We write no other things unto you, than what you read, that is, than what you may at lea≈øt, and are obliged to read by vertue of our writing them to you. And as for his Epi≈øtle to the The≈ø≈øalonians, which he wrote to that whole Church, he gives charge that it ≈øhould be read to all the Holy Brethren, 1 The≈ø. 5.27. So al≈øo for that of the Colo≈ø≈øians, When this Epi≈øtle is, or hath been, read among≈øt you, cau≈øe that it be read al≈øo in the Church of the Laodiceans; and that ye likewi≈øe read the Epi≈øtle from Laodicea. Where you ≈øee he all along either ≈øuppo≈øes or requires that what he wrote to all ≈øhould be read by all and to all. If therefore this Authority of St. Paul be ≈øufficient to over rule the Authority of any pretended Succe≈ø≈øor of St. Peter, then it's certain that reading the Scripture is ≈øtill the Duty of Lay-men notwith≈øtanding any Papal Prohibition to the contrary.

5. From the great Concernment the People have in the Matters contained in Scripture, it is al≈øo evident that they are obliged, if they are able, to read it and acquaint them≈øelves with it: For as for the Matters which the Scriptures contain, they are ≈øuch as are of everla≈øting Moment to the People as well as to the Clergy. The Articles of Faith which the Scripture propo≈øes are as nece≈ø≈øary to be believed
by the People as by the Clergy. The Precepts of Life which the Scripture pre≈øcribes are as nece≈ø≈øary to be practi≈øed by the People, as by the Clergy. The Promi≈øes and Threats with which the Scripture inforces tho≈øe Precepts are as nece≈ø≈øary to be con≈øidered by the People as by the Clergy: And ≈øeeing both are equally concerned in the great Matters which the Scriptures contain, what Rea≈øon can be a≈ø≈øigned why both ≈øhould not be obliged to acquaint them≈øelves with them? I know 'tis pretended that it is the proper Office of the Clergy to ≈øtudy the Scriptures for the People as well as for them≈øelves, and that therefore the People are obliged to receive the Sen≈øe of the Scriptures upon Tru≈øt from their Teachers without making any farther Enquiry. But I be≈øeech you, are you ≈øure that your Teachers are infallible? That they are not ≈øo is mo≈øt certain, it being notorious that mo≈øt of the prevailing Here≈øies of Chri≈øtendom were fir≈øt ≈øet on broach by the Teachers of the Church, and it is impo≈ø≈øible they ≈øhould be infallible, who have ≈øo often actually erred even in Matters of the highe≈øt Moment. Suppo≈øe then what is fairly ≈øuppo≈øable, that your Teachers ≈øhould mi≈ølead you, and not only into dangerous but damnable Errors; are you ≈øure that they ≈øhall be damned for you, and that you ≈øhall e≈øcape? If ≈øo, then Here≈øy in the Laity can never be damnable if they receive it upon Tru≈øt from their Teachers; and con≈øequently their Souls are as ≈øafe under the Conduct of fal≈øe Teachers as true; provided always that right or wrong they believe what is taught them. But if your ≈øelves mu≈øt give an Account to God as well for your Faith as for your Manners, and are liable in your own Per≈øons to eternal Damnation
(as mo≈øt certainly you are) as well for Here≈øy as Immorality, then it is the mo≈øt unrea≈øonable Thing in the World that you ≈øhould in all Things be obliged to believe your Teachers upon Tru≈øt; for at this rate a Man may be eternally damned, meerly for believing what he is obliged to believe. No, by no means; this I am forbid under the penalty of being deprived of the Benefit of Prie≈øtly Ab≈øolution. So that in ≈øhort they will allow me to make U≈øe of my Rea≈øon if I have been bred an Heretick in order to my Reconciliation to their Church, but if I have never been an Heretick I mu≈øt never u≈øe my Rea≈øon to examine the Truth either of my Church or Religion; that is to ≈øay, I may u≈øe my Rea≈øon when there is no other Remedy, and I mu≈øt continue a Heretick if I do not: But it were much better that I had never had Occa≈øion to u≈øe my Rea≈øon at all. So that according to the≈øe Men the U≈øe of our Rea≈øon in Religion is only the lea≈øt of two Evils; it is not ≈øo bad as to continue a Heretick, but if I had never been one it would be very bad, and a certain Way to make me one; which methinks looks very odd, that the U≈øe of my Rea≈øon ≈øhould be nece≈ø≈øary to reduce me from Here≈øy, and the di≈øu≈øe of it as nece≈ø≈øary, when I am reduced, to pre≈øerve me from relap≈øing into Here≈øy. 'Tis a memorable Pa≈ø≈øage of the Bi≈øhop of St. Mark in the Council of Trent, that Seculars are obliged humbly to obey that Doctrine of Faith which is given them by the Church, without di≈øputing or thinking farther of it. Where by the Church he means the Clergy a≈ø≈øembled in that Council. So that according to this Man's Doctrine the Faith of the People is a meer Bea≈øt of Burthen, that right or wrong mu≈øt
bear all the Load that the Prie≈øts ≈øhall agree to lay upon it; and though it ≈øhould feel it ≈øelf oppre≈ø≈øed by them with never ≈øuch gro≈øs Contradictions or Ab≈øurdities, it mu≈øt think no farther of it, but tamely trudg on without ≈øtarting or bogling. At this Rate what Tricks may not the Prie≈øts play with the Faith of the People? Let them invent what Doctrines they plea≈øe to ≈øerve the Intere≈øt of their own Ambition and Covetou≈øne≈øs, the People mu≈øt believe them without asking why; or if they ≈øhould ask why, they mu≈øt expect no other An≈øwer but this, becau≈øe we have thought to define and declare them. For it is by no means allowable that the People ≈øhould exerci≈øe any private Judgment of their own, about Matters of Faith; no, I confe≈øs it is not, where the Matters propo≈øed to their Faith are fal≈øe and erroneous; becau≈øe it is a thou≈øand to one but one time or other the People will di≈øcover the Frauds and Impo≈øtures of the Prie≈øts, and this would ≈øpoil all. But if the Matters of Faith are true, in all Probability the farther the People enquire into them the better they will be ≈øatisfied about them; and if in the Exerci≈øe of their private Judgments they ≈øhould in ≈øome particulars err, that is far more tollerable than that they ≈øhould be utterly deprived of the Means of being able to give an An≈øwer to every one that asks them a Rea≈øon of the Hope that is in them. But when God hath given the People rea≈øonable Faculties on purpo≈øe that by them they may be able to di≈øtingui≈øh what is true from what is fal≈øe, for any Party of Men to forbid them the U≈øe of the≈øe Faculties in di≈øtingui≈øhing what is true from what is fal≈øe in Religion, in which above all Things they
are mo≈øt highly concerned, it is a mo≈øt injurious U≈øurpation upon the common Rights of humane Nature. For by this Means our be≈øt Faculty is rendred u≈øele≈øs to us in our greate≈øt Concerns; and whereas God gave it to us on purpo≈øe to guide and direct us, we are utterly deprived of it's Guidance where we have mo≈øt need of it, and where it will prove mo≈øt f√†tal to us if we ≈øhould happen to err and go a≈øtray.

div.head: A DISSUASIVE FROM APOSTACY.

q.p: Holding faith, and a good con≈øcience; which ≈øome having put away, concerning faith have made ≈øhipwrack.

div.p:
THe≈øe Words are a part of St. Paul's Charge to his Son Timothy, wherein he Pathetically Exhorts him as a Valiant Bi≈øhop, to take all po≈ø≈øible Care to pre≈øerve the Purity of the Chri≈øtian Doctrine in his Dioce≈øs of Ephe≈øus, which at that time abounded with fal≈øe Teachers, who≈øe Bu≈øine≈øs it was to ≈øow the Tares of Here≈øie and fal≈øe Doctrine in that large and fruitful Field, the Cultivation whereof St. Paul had committed to his Charge. And that he might di≈øcharge this Office the more effectually, the Apo≈øtle warns him in the fir≈øt Place to take Care of him≈øelf, that he did not ≈øuffer his own Faith and Manners to be depraved and corrupted by tho≈øe lewd and irreligious
Principles which tho≈øe Antichri≈øtian Seminaries were then ≈øcattering among his People; that ≈øo he might be an Example to his Flock, as well as a Teacher of pure and undefiled Religion. And this, v. 18. he pre≈ø≈øes upon him from the Con≈øideration of what had been foretold of him by Divine In≈øpiration, before ever he entered upon his Mini≈øtry; viz. That he ≈øhould war a good warfare, that is, prove a con≈øtant and couragious Champion of the Chri≈øtian Faith; which Prophe≈øies, he exhorts him to u≈øe his utmo≈øt endeavour to verifie both in his Profe≈ø≈øion and Practice, by holding, or as it is in the Original, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , having, or keeping faith and a good con≈øcience; which later, viz. a good con≈øcience, ≈øome having put away, concerning the former, viz. Faith, have made ≈øhipwrack.

Before we proceed to the De≈øign of the≈øe Words, it will be nece≈ø≈øary briefly to explain ≈øome Terms in them; as,
1. What is meant by Faith.
2. What by a good Con≈øcience.
3. What by putting away a good Con≈øcience: And
4. What by making ≈øhipwrack of the Faith.

1. As for the fir≈øt, What is here meant by keeping the Faith? I an≈øwer, By this Phra≈øe Faith, we are to under≈øtand the Chri≈øtian Creed, or ≈øummary of tho≈øe nece≈ø≈øary and e≈ø≈øential Doctrines whereof the Chri≈øtian Religion is compo≈øed: For at that time there was little el≈øe profe≈ø≈øed and taught in the Chri≈øtian Churches, but only the fundamental Principles of Chri≈øtianity, together with the neare≈øt
and mo≈øt immediate Inferences from them; ≈øo that few then mi≈ø-believed but ≈øuch as mi≈ø-believed in Fundamentals, and every Error in Doctrine was generally a Here≈øie. The Chri≈øtian Faith in tho≈øe Days lay within a narrow compa≈øs, and ≈øo it continued till the Wantonne≈øs and Curio≈øity of ≈øucceeding Ages ≈øtarted di≈øputable Opinions, and as they prevailed, adopted them into the Family of Faith; in≈øomuch, that in proce≈øs of Time, ≈øundry Opinions were received, that were never ≈øo much as heard of, in the Apo≈øtolical Age; and as ≈øoon as they were received, they were pre≈øently declared nece≈ø≈øary Articles. And as for the contradictory Opinions, though Chri≈øtianity was little or nothing concerned whether they were true or fal≈øe; yet they ≈øeldom underwent any milder Name than Here≈øie, or gentler Doom than Damnation; which hath been one of the grand Occa≈øions of all the Ruptures and Divi≈øions that have happened in the Chri≈øtian World. But as for the Faith which the Apo≈øtle here ≈øpeaks of, it was of a much le≈øs Bulk than what it is now arrived to by rolling through the wild Opiniatry of Sixteen Di≈øputation Ages, which by degrees have ≈øwelled it from a ≈øhort ≈øcript into a large Volume. For if we look into the New Te≈øtament, and into the Writings of the mo≈øt Primitive Fathers, we ≈øhall find the Sums of Chri≈øtian Faith therein contained, con≈øi≈øting of very few Articles, and tho≈øe ≈øuch only as are e≈ø≈øential to Chri≈øtian Religion, and ≈øuch as wherein almo≈øt all the differing Per≈øua≈øions of Chri≈øtians do to this Day concenter. To hold the Faith therefore is to per≈øevere immovably in the Profe≈ø≈øion of the true Christian Doctrine, ≈øo far as in us lies, and not to
be prevailed upon to de≈øert or for≈øake it, either through Fear of Per≈øecution, or Hope of Temporal Advantage, or the Knavi≈øh Arts and Sly In≈øinuations of fal≈øe Teachers.

2. The ≈øecond Term here to be explained, is, What is meant by keeping a good Con≈øcience? Con≈øcience in general is nothing but our practical Judgment directing us what we ought to do, and what to avoid, and approving or reproving, according as we follow its Directions, or run counter to them. The Con≈øcience therefore is good or bad, according as the Directions are which it gives for the Government of our Lives and Actions. If our Judgment be fal≈øe and erroneous, and directs us to do what we ought to avoid, or to avoid what we ought to do, it is a bad Con≈øcience, that in≈øtead of being a Light to guide our Steps in the Paths of Righteou≈øne≈øs, is only a wandring Night-fire that leads us into Bogs and Quagmires. As on the contrary, A good Con≈øcience is our practical Judgment well informed, and truly directing us in the Cour≈øe of our Actions what we ought to do, and what to avoid: For a good Con≈øcience is the true Eccho of God within us, that faithfully re≈øounds his Voice, and upon all Opportunities of Action, repeats after him to our Wills and Affections. To keep a good Con≈øcience therefore implies two Things: Fir≈øt, To maintain in our Minds a true Sen≈øe of Good and Evil, and ≈øo far forth as in us lies, to pre≈øerve our practical Judgment pure from all fal≈øe Principles of Action, and not to ≈øuffer either our vicious Inclinations or worldly Intere≈øt to warp and ≈øeduce it, and cau≈øe it to mi≈øtake Evil for Good, and Good for Evil. Secondly, It implies
our following the Dictates and Directions of a good Con≈øcience, our doing what it bids, and ab≈øtaining from what it forbids, and faithfully re≈øigning our ≈øelves to its Conduct and Government, and not to be prevailed upon by any Temptation what≈øoever to act counter to its Sen≈øe and Per≈øua≈øion. In ≈øhort, To keep a good Con≈øcience is to live in a ≈øtrict Conformity to the Dictates of a well-informed Judgment, and not to allow our ≈øelves in any Cour≈øe of Action which this Vice-God within us forbids or di≈øapproves.

3. The Third Term to be explained in the Text, is, What is meant by putting away a good Con≈øcience; which being directly oppo≈øed here to keeping a good Con≈øcience, mu≈øt denote the Contraries to it. To put away a good Con≈øcience therefore is either, first, to corrupt our own Judgment of Things and Actions out of vicious Affection or worldly Intere≈øt, and impo≈øe upon our ≈øelves fal≈øe Notions of Good and Evil; or, ≈øecondly, to act directly contrary to our Sen≈øe and Per≈øua≈øion; to leave undone tho≈øe Things which our own Con≈øcience tells us we ought to do, and to do tho≈øe things which it tells us we ought not to do. In ≈øhort, to put away a good Con≈øcience is to live in any known Cour≈øe of Sin, either of Omi≈ø≈øion or Commi≈ø≈øion; to practi≈øe Contradictions to our own Judgments, and to follow the Inclinations of our Wills again≈øt the Light and Conviction of our Con≈øciences.

4. The last Enquiry, is, What is here meant by making ≈øhipwrack of the Faith? which being here ≈øet in Oppo≈øition to holding or keeping the Faith, mu≈øt ≈øignifie oppo≈øitely, and con≈øequently mu≈øt denote not holding and keeping it; or which is the
≈øame thing, lo≈øing and abandoning it: For in this Allegory, the true Chri≈øtian Faith is repre≈øented as a Ship, and a good Con≈øcience, or a pure and holy Life as the Pilot, that ≈øteers and governs it. And indeed, in that State of Things there was no other Pilot, but Purity of Con≈øcience and Holine≈øs of Life was able to conduct and pre≈øerve this Ship, and carry it ≈øafe through tho≈øe ince≈ø≈øant Storms of Per≈øecution, wherein at that time it was to≈øs'd and agitated. For when Chri≈øtians have once thrown off the Obligations of a good Con≈øcience, by abandoning them≈øelves to a wicked and di≈ø≈øolute Life, what is there left to re≈øtrain them from abandoning their Faith when it ≈øtands in Competition with their Worldly Ea≈øe and Intere≈øt? And though there ≈øhould be no Competition between their Faith and Intere≈øt, but they might freely enjoy them both without any di≈øturbance; yet their wicked Lives will naturally tempt them to corrupt their Faith with wicked Principles; of which later in the next Ver≈øe, he gives an eminent in≈øtance in Hymenaeus, who had not wholly de≈øerted Chri≈øtianity, but only renounced one Fundamental Article of it, viz. The Re≈øurrection of the Dead: As of the former, he gives another In≈øtance in Alexander, who as it ≈øeems probable, had through the Fear of Per≈øecution de≈øerted Chri≈øtianity it ≈øelf.

The Words thus explained may be re≈øolved into this Sen≈øe, That Mens living wickedly again≈øt the Convictions and Obligations of their Con≈øcience, doth very much expo≈øe them to Apo≈øtacy from true Religion into gro≈øs and impious Errors. Thus to the love of money, which is the root of all evil, the Apo≈øtle attributes Mens Erring from the Faith, 1 Tim. 6.10.
And that which expo≈øed tho≈øe ≈øilly women, 2 Tim. 3.6. to the Seduction of fal≈øe Teachers, was their being laden with ≈øins, and led away with divers lu≈øts. And the ≈øame Apo≈øtle a≈øcribes Demas's Apo≈øtacy to his Covetou≈øne≈øs, or inordinate love of this pre≈øent World, 2 Tim. 4.10. But that I may evince this Truth more fully, I ≈øhall give you ≈øome particular In≈øtances of the mighty Tendencies there are in every vicious Cour≈øe of Life to Error and Apo≈øtacy from true Religion.

list.item: 1. It corrupts and debauches Men's Rea≈øon and Under≈øtanding.
2. It renders the Principles of true Religion unea≈øie to ther Minds.
3. It deprives Men of the highe≈øt Encouragements to Con≈øtancy and Stedfa≈øtne≈øs in Religion.
4. It weakens the natural Force of their Con≈øciences, which is the greate≈øt Re≈øtraint from Apo≈øtacy.
5. It ≈øtrengthens the Temptations to Apo≈øtacy.
6. It provokes God to give us up to the Power of Delu≈øion.

div.p:
1. Living in any known and willful Cour≈øe of Sin, corrupts and debauches Men's Rea≈øon and Under≈øtandings. So long as a Man lives in any known Sin he doth not only live without, but again≈øt his Rea≈øon, which in≈øtead of being the Guide of his Actions, hath nothing at all to do with them, but like an idle Spectator, doth only behold the bruti≈øh Scene without any Part or Concern in it. And whil≈øt a Man thus abandons him≈øelf to the Government of his own blind Will, and lives not only in the perpetual Neglect, but Contempt of his Rea≈øon, it is impo≈ø≈øible for him not to wa≈øt and impair it. For
as our rational Faculties are improved and perfected by Exerci≈øe, ≈øo they naturally langui≈øh and decay, through Di≈øu≈øe and inactivity; and con≈øequently the le≈øs U≈øe we make of them in the Government of our Lives and Actions, which is their proper Office and Employment, like standing Waters they mu≈øt corrupt and putrifie. And indeed there is no impure Lu≈øt but doth by its own natural Efficacy di≈øable Mens Rea≈øon and Under≈øtanding: For while we are in the≈øe Bodies, our Mind is fain to work by bodily In≈øtruments, and to make U≈øe of Brains, and Blood, and Spirits, in all its Operations; and according as their Temper is good or bad, its Operations will be more or le≈øs perfect: But while a Man indulges him≈øelf in any impure Affection, that will naturally di≈øtemper the≈øe Organs of his Mind, and indi≈øpo≈øe them for the U≈øe of his Rea≈øon. For ≈øo Madne≈øs, which is ≈øuch a Di≈øtemperature of the Brain, and Blood, and Spirits doth wholly alienate them from the U≈øe of Rea≈øon and Di≈øcour≈øe, is u≈øually found to be the Effect of ≈øome wild and extravagant Affection, ≈øuch as Pride, or Covetou≈øne≈øs, Anger, or Fearfulne≈øs, Jealou≈øie, or Lu≈øt; and if the≈øe Pa≈ø≈øions, being once arrived to their utmo≈øt Rage and Exce≈øs, do ≈øo often run into down-right Madne≈øs and Di≈øtraction, to be ≈øure every inordinate Degree of them mu≈øt be a Tendency towards it, a great Di≈øturbance of Mind, though not a total Di≈øtraction; and how much they exceed their due Bounds and Mea≈øures, by ≈øo much they mu≈øt taint and vitiate the≈øe nece≈ø≈øary In≈øtruments of our Mind and Rea≈øon. Thus every inordinate Lu≈øt doth by a natural Influence di≈øturb Mens Rea≈øon, and ≈øully the clearne≈øs of their di≈øcerning Faculties. So that
what Clearne≈øs is to the Eye of the Body, that Purity from vicious Affection is to the Eye of the Mind; it brightens its Apprehen≈øions, and renders its Conceptions of Things more quick, di≈øtinct, and vigorous: Whereas on the contrary, all di≈øorderly Affection doth more or le≈øs cloud and di≈øturb the Brain, chill or inflame the Spirits, hurry them into tumultuous Motions, or render them li≈øtle≈øs and unactive; by which continual Di≈øorders, our di≈øcerning Faculties mu≈øt by Degrees be extreamly weakened and confounded. And whil≈øt the Mind is thus lo≈øt in the Fogs of inordinate Affection, it is an ea≈øie Matter to ≈øeduce and mi≈ølead it, it being through the Dimne≈øs of its ≈øight apt to be impo≈øed upon by fal≈øe Colours, and tinctured with Prejudice and undue Apprehen≈øions of Things. Weak Minds are ea≈øily abu≈øed, e≈øpecially in Matters of Religion, which being placed beyond the Pro≈øpect of Sen≈øe, require a ≈øeverer Attention in order to the forming of right Apprehen≈øions concerning them; and therefore the more Men weaken their Under≈øtandings by their Lu≈øts, the more they mu≈øt be expo≈øed to Errors and Delu≈øions. But them,

2. Living in any known Cour≈øe of Sin, renders the Principles of true Religion unea≈øie to Mens Minds. Whil≈øt a Man leads a wicked Life, his Religious Principles, if they are pure and true, will perpetually reproach and upbraid him: For there are no Contraries in Nature more irreconcilable to one another than true Faith and bad Manners; the great De≈øign of all true Faith being to move and per≈øuade Men to ab≈øtain from all Ungodline≈øs, and to live ≈øoberly, righteou≈øly, and godly in this pre≈øent World. If therefore a Man's Faith be true and genuine,
he cannot live wickedly without acting again≈øt the full Per≈øua≈øion of his own Mind, which mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily render him very unea≈øie; for in this State of Things he acts with a ≈øelf-condemning Judgment, and every Compliance with his Inclination ≈øets him at odds with his Rea≈øon; all the while he is meditating any wicked De≈øign, he ≈øtruggles with his Con≈øcience, and confronts and outrages his own Convictions; and when he hath acted it, every Reflection he makes on it is a bitter Invective again≈øt him≈øelf: Thus ≈øo long as the Principles of true Religion po≈ø≈øe≈øs his Mind, he finds him≈øelf continually hagg'd and oppre≈ø≈øed by them; they ≈øit as an unea≈øie Load upon his Soul, and will not ≈øuffer him to Sin in quiet, but perpetually cau≈øe his ≈øinful Delights to go off with an ungrateful Farewel, and recoil upon him in many a ≈øickly Qualm and Convul≈øion. In which State of Things he hath no other Remedy, but either to for≈øake his Principles, or his Lu≈øts; or to live in perpetual Variance with him≈øelf; and therefore, if he ≈øtill re≈øolve to Sin on, in all probability he will ≈øoon grow quite weary of true Religion, and quit his Mind as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øibly he can of tho≈øe ≈øtern and inflexible Principles which create the≈øe Di≈øcords in his Brea≈øt. And whil≈øt he is in this Temper it will be an ea≈øie matter to pervert him to any Religion that will give Ea≈øe to his ≈øtraitlaced Con≈øcience, and ca≈øt a more favourably A≈øpect on his Lu≈øt: for being re≈øolved to follow his vicious Inclinations he now ≈øees through them, and under≈øtands by them; and whil≈øt his Mind runs upon the fal≈øe Bia≈øs of his Lu≈øts, that Religion which is mo≈øt grateful to them will ≈øeem mo≈øt rea≈øonable to him. Shew him a way
how he may wor≈øhip God acceptably without the Expence of a ≈øtrict Attention, and the inward Devotion of a pure Heart, and heavenly Affections; meerly by numbring ≈øo many Prayers on a String of Beads, by ≈øeeing a Prie≈øt act over ≈øuch a Set of Ceremonies, and hearing him in varied Tones ≈øometimes pronounce, and ≈øometimes murmur a Form of Words in an ∆≤nknown Language; and though at fir≈øt view it may ≈øeem very ab≈øurd to him, yet the very Loo≈øne≈øs and Carnality will be apt to engage his Affections to it, and then they by degrees will go near to wheedle his Under≈øtanding into a more favourable Opinion of it. Propo≈øe to him an Expedient how he may go to heaven at la≈øt without undergoing the Severities of a ≈øincere Repentance and Amendment; tell him there is a certain Church in the World who≈øe Prie≈øts, if he confe≈øs his Sins to them with any Degree of Sorrow and Remor≈øe, have full Power to Pardon and Ab≈øolve him; ≈øo that if he do but take Care not to die without Confe≈ø≈øion, however he lives he cannot mi≈øcarry for ever. He may indeed go into a very hot Place called Purgatory, and there ≈øuffer a while very grievous Things before he get to Heaven; but if in≈øtead of parting with his Lu≈øts while he lives, he will part with his Mony when he dies, he may at ea≈øy Rates purcha≈øe of that Church ≈øuch a Number of Ma≈ø≈øes, Requiems, and Indulgencies, as will in all Probability ≈øoon procure his Di≈ømi≈ø≈øion from tho≈øe temporary Sufferings into eternal Happine≈øs: How odly ≈øoever this Doctrine may appear to his Rea≈øon, to be ≈øure it will be charming enough to his Lu≈øts; and when once a Mans Lu≈øts are retained the Cau≈øe is half carried at the Bar of his Judgment. And ≈øo
in all other In≈øtances it is a great Di≈øadvantage to true Religion, and as great an Advantage to fal≈øe, that Mens Faith and Rea≈øon are ≈øo much ≈øwayed and bya≈øs'd by their Lu≈øts. For though there is no Religion can be true but what is pure and holy, yet it is the Holine≈øs of true Religion that doth provoke their Lu≈øts again≈øt it, and 'tis their Lu≈øts that do provoke their Rea≈øon; and when all is done there is nothing doth more ≈øtrongly incline, or frequently pervert depraved and wicked Minds to fal≈øe Religion than its Complyance with their vicious Affections, though this very Thing is one of the mo≈øt certain Signs in Nature of its Fal≈øhood.

3. Living in any known Cour≈øe of Sin deprives Men of the greate≈øt Encouragements to Con≈øtancy and Steadfa≈øtne≈øs in the true Religion: For doubtle≈øs the highe≈øt Encouragement to Per≈øeverance in the Truth again≈øt all Oppo≈øitions and Temptations, is the Hope of tho≈øe glorious Rewards that await them in the World to come. 'Twas this that guarded the Faith of the antient Martyrs ≈øafe through all the Rage and Cruelty of their Per≈øecutors, their having an Eye to the Recompence of Reward, the Sight of which in≈øpired the drooping Souls with an invincible Courage; made them de≈øpi≈øe Racks, and Wheels, and Flames, and exalt and triumph under the mo≈øt exqui≈øite Torments. 3. Con≈øider the ≈øoul Di≈øhone≈øty of it: For, be≈øides that our Religion being the mo≈øt ≈øacred Pledg committed to us by God for our own U≈øe, and the U≈øe of our latest Po≈øterity, we cannot vicou≈øly de≈øert and abandon it without betraying of God, and fal≈øifying our Tru≈øt to him; and which is wor≈øe, without ≈øquandering away the mo≈øt ine≈øtimable Good that ever he committed to Men, upon

been ≈øo perfidious as to renounce his God and his Religion, he hath no one Principle remaining in him upon which you can fa≈øten any la≈øting Confidence. For when a Man for≈øakes his Religion out of any vicous Affection, he doth in Effect make this publick Declaration to the World, By this my own Act and Deed I do here for ever renounce all the Obligations to Honesty and fair Dealing with God or Men, and am re≈øolved for the future to be deaf and inexorable to all the Importunities of Con≈øcience and Religion. From henceforth I will li≈øten to no other Call but that of my worldly Interest; when that bids me be hone≈øt, I will be honest, and when it bids me play the Knave, I will play the Knave ;and therefore for the future I warn all that know me to trust me no farther than they can make it my Interest to be true, and not to venture the mo≈øt trifling Matter in which they are unwilling to be wronged, either upon my Faith, or Word, or Oath, without demanding of me ≈øuch ample Securities as may render it impo≈ø≈øible for me to wrong them without wronging my ≈øelf. For this is the Principle I now intend to live by, That is always best and fittest to be done,

4. Con≈øider the ≈øhameful Cowardize of it. The Advantages of true Religion are great enough to encourage a Mind of any Con≈øtancy or Firmne≈øs to charge through the greatest Difficulties the World can interpo≈øe between them and him. And who but an infamous Coward would ever endure to be hector'd out of ≈øo va≈øt a good by the weak and impotent Evils of this World; which if they do their wor≈øt can only rob him of a few tran≈øitory Enjoyments, which without their Con≈øtraint he mu≈øt ere long take his leave of for ever? 5. And La≈øtly, Con≈øider the va≈øt Hazard and In≈øecurity of a Man's parting with his Religion in Compliance with his vicious Affections: For that which moves him to it is only his Pro≈øpect of living at Ea≈øe a few Years longer, or gratifying ≈øome covetous De≈øire or Ambition; but whether he obtain the≈øe Ends by parting with his Religion, is va≈øtly hazardous and in≈øecure. But then ≈øuppo≈øe this ≈øhould not happen; ≈øuppo≈øe my Con≈øcience ≈øhould be ≈øtupid and in≈øen≈øible enough to bear the Guilt of my Apo≈øtacy without Remor≈øe or Relenting; yet my Pro≈øpect of Gain and Advancement in this World is extreamly hazardous and in≈øecure. And though for a while they may think fit to u≈øe me as a proper Tool to ≈øerve a pre≈øent De≈øign, yet to be ≈øure they will u≈øe me to longer than they needs mu≈øt; and when I have done their Work, I mu≈øt expect to be thru≈øt out to make room for ≈øuch as they can more ≈øafely depend on. And ≈øo I have done with the fir≈øt Inference: But then,

2. From hence I infer, How cautious a Man
ought to be in changing his Religion, or any Principles of it, lea≈øt that which induces him to it be not ≈øo much his Conviction as his profligate Con≈øcience. And when once a Man is ≈øo prepo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed

div.p:
1. When you fall under any Temptation to Change, ask your own Soul whether your Prejudice lye on the ≈øide of your pre≈øent Religion, or of that which you are tempted to turn to? There is no Man that ≈øincerely profe≈ø≈øes any Religion, but mu≈øt be ≈øtrongly prejudiced for it, e≈øpecially if he imbibed it betimes, and was principled in it by his Education; for how can he ≈øincerely profe≈øs it without engaging his Affections towards it, and heartily e≈øpou≈øing its Intere≈øt? For though I confe≈øs it is a Fault for Men ≈øo to preingage them≈øelves
to any Religious Principles, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as are not exceeding clear and evident (and ≈øuch are all the Fundamentals of Christianity) as to ≈øhut their Ears again≈øt all contrary Rea≈øons, and ob≈øtinately re≈øolve never to part with them, or ≈øo much as to admit into Con≈øideration any Argument or Evidence again≈øt them; yet after all it is impo≈ø≈øible for any ≈øincere Profe≈ø≈øor of any Religion, whether it be true or fal≈øe, to be ≈øo indifferently affected towards it as not to ≈øide with it in his Will as well as in his Faith and Judgment; ≈øo that whenever he is tempted to de≈øert it, the Temptation mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily find him ≈øtrongly preingaged for it; and unle≈øs it bring a long with it ≈øufficient Evidence not only to convince his Rea≈øon, but al≈øo to captivate his Prejudice, it will never be able to prevail. For if ever the Man loved his Religion, his Pa≈ø≈øion will contend for it as well as his Rea≈øon; ≈øo that all Arguments again≈øt it, be they never ≈øo ≈øtrong and cogent, will at fir≈øt e≈øpecially find a difficult Acce≈øs to and an ungrateful Reception in his Mind; and though he is ≈øo overborn by the Strength of the Evidence again≈øt it that he can no longer forbear doubting and ≈øu≈øpecting it, yet ≈øtill he is very loth to part with it, and ≈øtill he wi≈øhes it were true, though he is not able to evince it ≈øo, till after having endured a long Siege of ≈øtrong and pre≈ø≈øing Arguments he is driven at length out of all his Defences, and then his Prejudice yields as well as his Judgment to ≈øurrender up his erroneous Faith to the prevailing Power of his Convictions: This is the natural Temper of every ≈øincere Profe≈ø≈øor of any Religion. When therefore you are at any Time tempted to change your Religion, before you proceed, pau≈øe a while, and con≈øider ≈øeriou≈øly how you ≈øtand di≈øpo≈øed, and which way your Heart is

For a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelves if the Temptation to Change find you lukewarm and indifferent, or ≈øo much as ea≈øy and plyable to its Propo≈øals; if it finds you unaver≈øe to admit of a contrary Per≈øua≈øion, or forward to catch at every Shew of Evidence again≈øt that Religion which you have hitherto profe≈ø≈øed, or ready to be ≈øtagger'd out of it upon the fir≈øt Appearance of any Rea≈øons or Probabilities again≈øt it; if, I ≈øay, you find any of the≈øe evil Symptons upon you when you are fir≈øt tempted to change, you have great Rea≈øon to ≈øu≈øpect that you are a fal≈øe Hypocrite to that Profe≈ø≈øion which you have hitherto made; that there is ≈øome vile Affection in you that hath got the A≈øcendant of your Religion and your Con≈øcience, and that if in this Temper you proceed to a Change, you will be found to be a Convert of your Lu≈øts and not of your Convictions.

2. When you fall under any Temptation to change your Religion, examine whether you have not entertained ≈øome Di≈øta≈øt to it in your Affections, before you proceed any farther; whether you have not entertained ≈øome Quarrel again≈øt it upon the account of the Di≈øturbance it gives you in your vicious Delights and Enjoyments; or becau≈øe it too ≈øeverely exacts of you univer≈øal Sanctity of Life and
